p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the 20th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
private session in the 47th Parliament on
1. The committee resolved to present the following 90 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 90 petitions:
Workplace Relations

Employee conditions and remunerations (in real terms) are being eroded by employers who are posting record profits. One big reason for this is that it is incredibly difficult to undertake industrial action, more so in Australia than in almost if not any other country. On the other hand, an employer can hold employees to ransom by not providing them any pay rises until they agree to cuts in conditions.

Current rules impose time-consuming and costly processes on unions or other groups wishing to undertake industrial action. And even after action is approved the Fair Work Commission can withdraw the approval based on the action potentially causing an economic impact to the employer (which is the main threat industrial action is supposed to provide).
We therefore ask the House to remove all barriers to industrial action from the Fair Work Act.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN5565)
World Health Organization
Reject the proposed changes to the World Health Organization (WHO) Treaty which hands over Sovereign State power to the WHO.
The removal of the words "Non Binding" form the document must be rejected.
Otherwise we must Opt Out of the Treaty.
If we do not Opt Out we are AUTOMATICLY controlled by this new treaty.
The new treaty gives the WHO unprecedented powers to control information, force lockdowns and vaccinations using untested and experimental drugs.
This violates the principal of informed consent and self determination of the people as set forth in Article 1 of the United Nations Charter.
We therefore ask the House to Reject the WHO Treaty or if the treaty is passed by the WHO to withdraw from the World Health Organization and immediately cease finding the WHO.
This affects all Australian Citizens and as such should be put to a Referendum.
from 355 citizens (Petition No. EN5566)
Renewable Energy

The consultation period is open on whether the Illawarra marine environment should become an industrial zone. Many concerned Australian citizens believe our marine environments should be cared for to become more ecologically rich and sustainable for all life, including social sustainability for residents as well as sustainable for the leisure, tourism and other industries the region is known for. The proposal by the government to change the Illawarra coastal area into an industrial zone and then into a wind farm, appears to be a threat to the sustainability and aesthetics of this area, as well as to current industries and businesses in the region. Australian citizens desire more protection for the marine environments, beaches, estuaries, harbours of the Illawarra, and do not desire to turn these areas into industrial zones, nor wind farms.

We therefore ask the House to assist concerned citizens of Australia to protect and enhance their marine and coastal areas, and not to assist any persons nor to assist any groups to change the marine areas of the Illawarra into an industrial zone as proposed, nor into a wind farm as proposed.
from 43 citizens (Petition No. EN5568)
Nuclear Energy

With the plasma fusion energy industry growing overseas and the development of AI, quantum computing, robotics, new materials, and technologies, the industry is now being used and developed around the world. We know plasma fusion produces no harmful emissions or radioactive waste fuel. Australia needs to join with the US NRC Decision to separate fusion energy regulation from nuclear energy fission regulation and join the UK to continue to have fusion in its environment legislation outside the nuclear agency and under a new regulatory framework being raised to cater for this. This is in line with plasma fusion power plants physically incapable of having a meltdown or having radioactive waste. The IAEA does not recognise plasma fusion in its industry, nor does the nuclear proliferation treaty acknowledge plasma fusion as an issue. Plasma fusion power will create a new world of industry, jobs, technology, education and leadership and does not threaten sovereignty.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation in relation to the use of plasma fusion energy development and in line with international regulations similar to the US NRC Decision to separate Fusion Energy Regulation from Nuclear Energy Fission regulation and the UK continued management of fusion in its environment legislation outside the nuclear agency and develop a new regulatory framework to cater for this.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN5571)
Australian Broadcasting Corporation

The ABC has shown increasing bias in its selection of political interviewees and commentators, culminating in the platforming of political statements that are provably false or in favour of one party over others without challenge. This has led to a significant decline in the quality of news broadcasting and the use of public funds to promote political agendas.

We therefore ask the House to form an independent inquiry or commission to investigate this trend and provide actionable solutions to combat it. We also ask that the House considers the implementation of laws surrounding the broadcast of known misinformation and provably false information as fact.
from 78 citizens (Petition No. EN5572)
Australian Electoral Commission

The Voice to Parliament AEC information booklet contained campaign material provided by the House to the AEC. Under current legislation and regulations, the AEC is not allowed to alter this information. There were several provably false statements in this material, some of which were contradictory to the information about the process of the referendum and the proposed changes to the constitution. As a result, the AEC was forced to publish and circulate misinformation which will inevitably damage public faith in the electoral processes and democracy in Australia.

We therefore ask the House to consider implementing legislation that would require the AEC not to publish provably false information, no matter how it is provided. We ask that the House considers extending this to other government agencies to ensure that public money is not spent on misinforming the people of Australia and subsequently damaging the good governance of the Commonwealth.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN5573)
Parliamentary Representation
Indigenous Australians lost their chance for having a direct say in our government when the "voice" referendum was rejected.

A way of allowing indigenous representation is to increase the numbers of senators from the ACT and the Northern Territory and allowing those increased numbers to be voted for only by Indigenous Australians.
Those voting for the indigenous representation in the increased territory senate representation should also be allowed to vote in their normal state or territory senate elections.
This is a complicated situation but gives indigenous peoples a real voice in parliament.

Section 122 of the Constitution states the Australian Parliament may allow territory representation 'in either House of the Parliament to the extent and on the terms which it thinks fit'. This means the Australian Parliament can decide how many senators, if any, a territory may have.

We therefore ask the House to increase the numbers of senators for the ACT and Northern Territory with the proviso they are elected by indigenous peoples from across the nation and those elections are a special consideration where the indigenous person does not have to be resident in the territory and may also vote in their state electorate.
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN5574)
Elections and Referendums

Noting that certain media publications, based on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's analysis of ongoing poll results published by the Australian Electoral Commission, "called" the result of the 2023 Voice referendum prior to the close of polling in Western Australia.

And noting that the publication and broadcast of such claims could reasonably be said to potentially affect the votes of electors who were yet to cast their vote, including a propensity to cast an invalid result dues to the perceived lack of impact of that vote.
The publication of any electoral results in any District, prior to the close of polling in all Districts, could have a detrimental effect on the franchise of Western Australian voters.

We therefore ask the House to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, s327 Interference with political liberty etc. to include an offence for publishing electoral results, or any part there of, prior to the close of all polling places; or through other means prohibit the same.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN5575)
Australian Curriculum: Civics Education

There is a pressing need to address political illiteracy in our country. The failures of recent referendums have laid bare a stark reality—a significant proportion of Australians lack a fundamental understanding of government and politics, which engenders a profound distrust in the system. These range from a basic understanding of the constitution, the history and impact of referendums, how our voting system works, the history of government, and knowledge of existing political parties. It's clear that education should play a vital role in filling this information gap for our future.

We therefore ask the House to rnment to incorporate political education into the national school curriculum. This will ensure that the young generation obtains a comprehensive understanding of the workings of our political system to be able to make informed voting decisions that effect the future of this country. The introduction of such education would equip students with the knowledge necessary to tackle misinformation and counteract apathy, fostering a populace that understand, appreciate, and trust in our democratic structures. We call upon the government to take urgent action on this matter.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN5576)
Middle East

The persistent hostilities in Gaza between Hamas and the Israeli Government have spiraled into a severe humanitarian crisis. The relentless violence has led to an alarming number of civilian casualties, massive destruction of infrastructure, and alleged grave human rights violations by both parties involved. This crisis not only threatens regional stability but also undermines international peace, law, and human rights standards. The distressing images and reports emanating from Gaza are a stark reminder of the human toll this conflict is exacting on innocent lives.
We therefore ask the House to urge the Australian Government to utilise its diplomatic leverage and global standing to advocate for an immediate ceasefire and de-escalation of violence.

To call for an impartial international inquiry into the alleged human rights violations, we aim to ensure accountability, justice, and adherence to international law. Additionally, we urge the mobilisation of humanitarian aid to alleviate the suffering of the affected populations and foster a conducive environment for peace and stability.

We firmly believe that a proactive stance by Australia can contribute significantly towards mitigating the crisis, upholding human rights, and promoting a peaceful resolution to the ongoing conflict in Gaza. This action is not only a moral imperative but also resonates with Australia's commitment to global peace, justice, and human rights. Through this petition, we aspire to galvanise our government's resolve to act decisively and collaboratively on the international stage to address this grave humanitarian crisis.
from 81 citizens (Petition No. EN5578)
First Nations Australians

The Voice to Parliament referendum raised that the living conditions of Australia's indigenous population, particularly those in rural and remote communities, is far below that of the rest of the Australian population.
Australia decisively voted against creating a constitutionally enshrined advocacy group in the referendum, with the No campaign advising that there was little to no information to go in.

Actionable information appears to be key towards a bipartisan solution forward, and an investigation into *all* unnatural indigenous deaths, be that malnutrition, violence, negligence of emergency services, or deaths in incarceration, can provide that information.
A Royal Commission into indigenous deaths in custody has taken place, but there is no context in which to understand how big a part of the picture this information plays.

In order to paint a complete picture into the struggles experience by Australia's Indigenous population, the Australian Federal Government must investigate *all* unnatural indigenous deaths, in and out of custody.
All contributing factors to death must be considered, be they racial profiling, negligence, curable medical conditions or injuries, family or social violence, or substance abuse.

This is an investigation that acknowledges racial factors in play, and also avoids vague terms such as "systemic racism" and "white supremacy". As such, it have minimal issue gaining bipartisan support.

We therefore ask the House to launch a Royal Commission, or independent inquiry, into *all* indigenous deaths in rural and remote communities over the past forty years, publishing full results to the Australian public.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN5579)
Energy

In today's challenging economic climate, Australian households are facing an unprecedented struggle to keep up with rising costs. Essential commodities and services such as housing, groceries, and especially electricity are becoming increasingly hard to afford. Amid the skyrocketing prices, we, the undersigned, recognize that electricity plays an even more crucial role in maintaining the standard of living, from lighting our homes to powering essential appliances. Despite its essential status, residential electricity is currently taxed with a GST of 10%. One in four Australian households are finding it hard to pay their energy bills, a pressure amplified by the already high housing and grocery costs. Other essential provisions like healthcare, water, and fresh food are exempt from GST, this should extend to residential electricity which everyone needs to live in the modern world.

We therefore ask the House to categorize residential electricity as an essential service, so it can be exempt from GST. This shift in policy would make a significant difference, providing immediate relief for those grappling to make ends meet. A change is not only economically justifiable, it's a moral imperative. This significant gesture would lighten financial burdens and exemplify a government genuinely invested in the welfare of its citizens.

Rising inflation, driven not by wage growth or consumer spending, but by unchecked corporate greed, is plunging already financially strained citizens into even deeper poverty. It is scandalous that mega-corporations exploit an economic crisis to unjustifiably inflate prices and amass extraordinary profits.

We therefore ask the House to invoke a Corporate Windfall Tax immediately, aimed directly at these profiteers. The aggressively amassed wealth serves as evidence of the price-gouging contributing to the current inflation and structuring such a tax would disincentivise these predatory pricing practices. The funds generated from this tax should be channeled towards supporting low-income individuals and families, via policies such as raising the tax-free threshold, creating additional public housing, and increasing JobSeeker payments. Rising inflation demands effective action aimed at the cause, not just raising interest rates which harms low and middle-income earners even more. We need it urgently, effectively, and glaringly targeted at the orchestrators of this financial turmoil. Let's tax greed, foster fairness, and direct support to those who most need it.

from 1,523 citizens (Petition No. EN5594)
Nuclear Energy

The introduction of new nuclear technology necessitates a review of existing legal frameworks to guarantee safety, security, and responsibility for peaceful purposes. Fusion technology is no exception. There is a need to consider whether the current international legal frameworks for the safe, secure and peaceful uses of nuclear technology are applicable and fit for purpose for fusion energy systems. While fission and fusion both produce energy, there are fundamental differences, distinct technological requirements and characteristics which change the hazard potential and key safety issues.

The objective of nuclear law is to provide a legal framework for conducting activities related to nuclear energy and ionising radiation in a manner which adequately protects people, property, and the environment. Over the decades, nuclear law has evolved to address the unique challenges of fission based power generation and the Convention on Nuclear Safety (CNS) [27] and other related international legal instruments such as the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) [28], together with IAEA safeguards, have all played an important role, complemented by legally non-binding IAEA safety standards and nuclear security guidance.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy and separate fusion out of nuclear into the environment legislations.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5595)
Nuclear Energy

The cornerstone of the current international legal framework for nuclear safety is the CNS [27], which establishes fundamental safety principles for the design, construction and operation of nuclear installations, and emphasizes the objective of preventing accidents and

mitigating their potential consequences. The IAEA Nuclear Safety and Security Glossary [29] does not include fusion facilities under the category of nuclear installations, however Contracting Parties to the CNS may consider certain fusion power plants as being a nuclear installation (i.e. a land based NPP) for the purpose of the CNS. In doing so, the Contracting Parties should note that a potential limitation arising from the definition of a nuclear installation is that a land based NPP ceases to be a nuclear installation for the purposes of the CNS "when all nuclear fuel elements have been removed permanently from the reactor core" [27]. Currently, nuclear fuel for fission based plants is commonly understood as being fissionable nuclearmaterial in the form of fabricated fuel elements.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy. We ask that the House initiate the International Atomic Energy Agency's (IAEA) milestones approach to start Australia down the path of setting up the regulatory framework needed for the nuclear fusion power industry development in Australia.

Skin Cancer is known as our 'national cancer'. 2 in 3 of us are likely to do battle with it, our rates are 12 times the global norm, it costs our healthcare system over $1.4b a year and kills one Aussie ever 6 hrs. In the last two decades since a formal skin cancer screening model was proposed—and deemed too expensive, advances in technology, talent and treatment pathways have significantly improved. Meaning a more efficient and effective model is now a viable option for Government investment. Economic modelling suggests a 30/1 return in savings to the healthcare system, not to mention the thousands of lives saved every year from a co-ordinated pop-up skin check program, targeting high risk communities. Non-profit charity Skin Check Champions has worked on a viable model for this program for over a decade, checking more than 10,000 Australian's and gathering data and improving their strategy to inform such an initiative. Their average rate of detection is up around 1 in 25. Which is far higher than any other model previously proposed. The key is technology, talent and targeting. Together, with Federal and State Departments, we believe it's time Australia back a 'Targeted National Skin Check Program' and start leading the world in the early detection of skin cancer, rather than skin cancer deaths.

from 44 citizens (Petition No. EN5626)
Paid Parental Leave Scheme
In Australia, around 48,000 babies require the help of a Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) or Special Care Nursery (SCN) due to prematurity or sickness at birth.

Babies can spend weeks or months in specialised care and this can have a significant impact on the entire family unit with parents often forced to stop work earlier than expected, facing additional and unexpected financial pressures, trauma and very often, facing ongoing mental health challenges.

Under the current Australian Government Paid Parental Leave (PPL) Legislation, eligible parents who are the primary carer of a newborn receive up to 20 weeks' paid parental leave at the national minimum wage. Eligible working dads and partners (including same-sex partners) receive two weeks leave paid at the national minimum wage.

Sadly, for the parents of premature and sick babies, current legislation doesn't consider the needs of parents with babies who spend their first weeks or months of life in a NICU or SCN, therefore separating parents from their vulnerable babies far too early.
We believe all parents should be given the same opportunity to support their baby in hospital.

We therefore ask the House to please introduce additional Paid Parental Leave entitlements for families with a baby born requiring specialised care. We propose that primary carers receive one week of extra Parental Leave Pay for every week a baby is in the hospital beyond two weeks, with a maximum of 14 weeks extra pay. For fathers and partners, we recommend an additional two weeks of extra Dad and Partner Pay.

Middle East

Innocent civilians on both sides, whole families including women and children, are being killed in this conflict which will surely add to the cycle of hatred and revenge that has been perpetuated for generations. There are active peace movements in Israel and Palestine, as well as a pro-democracy movement in Gaza which offer the best hope of a lasting peace in the Middle East. The Australian Government should prioritise supporting these movements above supporting the military actions of the Netanyahu government which will only lead to a new wave of hatred and the formation of more terrorists.

We therefore ask the House to press for an immediate ceasefire between Israel and Hamas and to support the efforts of humanitarian organisations and peace movements in Israel and Palestine which hold the key to a lasting peace. We ask the House to condemn human rights violations on both sides and to make the ending of historic cycles of hatred and revenge a key foreign policy objective, including studying the forces that give rise to terrorism and prioritising the avoidance of these conditions.
from 255 citizens (Petition No. EN5632)
Middle East
The Australian government and especially the Federal Opposition are not taking enough action to address the serious human rights violations by Israel and Hamas.
We therefore ask the House to make representations to the ICC to prosecute the Israeli Government and the identifiable leaders of Hamas, both in and outside of the Israel/West Bank/Gaza region.
from 64 citizens (Petition No. EN5633)
War Widows Day
In 2022, War Widows Day was declared an observed day in NSW and QLD, and was shortly followed by declaration in the ACT, SA and WA in 2023.

With more than 40,000 war widows remaining nationally, and most states and territories now recognising their contributions, we believe it is time for a national day, as do many others in our community.
War widow/ers are the bereaved spouse of Australian veterans who have passed away as a result of war, injuries or illnesses sustained in war or related to their service to Australia.

For years during and following their loved one's service they have cared for and supported their loved ones. They have sacrificed their own freedoms and opportunities to enable their loved one's service and to care for them when that service has ended.

There is no agreement between them and the government to do this, they do it because of their love, devotion and commitment to the person who wears the nations' uniform. Veterans sign up because they are called to duty, in the background though the system expects that families will support them, which they do, right to the very end. We believe they deserve to be acknowledged and honoured in their own right.

We therefore ask the House to legislate to establish a National War Widows Day on 19 October annually under the powered conferred on the Parliament in s51 of the Constitution. Further, the affairs of Defence and Veterans is a national responsibility (Veteran Covenant).
from 483 citizens (Petition No. EN5634)
Labor Government
The Labor Party are not governing our commonwealth with respect for its constituents.
60.7% of Australians voted no in the referendum but the Labor Party are still pursuing a Treaty that the majority of Australians don't want.
The Labor Party are also pursuing a misinformation and disinformation bill that will restrict what people can post and read on the internet.
Under the Labor Government the price of food has risen 8.2% Housing 10.4% Gas 28% Electricity18.2% and insurance 17.3%
The Australian constitution states in section 51 "The parliament shall subject to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the commonwealth with respect to..".
The Labor Party pursuing these agendas is obviously not good governance and it's not laws for peace or order these laws are opposite of a democratic society.

By signing this petition, you are stating that you have no confidence in the Labor Party. You believe that they are reckless and does not serve the majority of its constituents. And that you wish to vote for a new parliament at the earliest possible time.
We therefore ask the House to request the Governor General to call for an immediate election at the earliest possible time.
from 18,390 citizens (Petition No. EN5636)
Middle East

The current conflict in Palestine has degenerated into a situation tantamount to an ethnic cleansing of the Palestinian people. As Australians we must condemn Israels actions, which are in flagrant violation of international humanitarian law. Since October 7, Over 10,000 Palestinians have been killed in the West Bank and Gaza, they have been denied access to water, electricity and fuel and have been prevented access to humanitarian aid. Hospitals and refugee camps have been deliberately targeted and white phosphorous has been used against civilian populations. Each of these things constitute a breach of international law, and yet our government has not upheld the values of the Australian people by condemning this. Now is the moment in history to do the right thing, it is not too late to save lives in Palestine.

For this reason, we the undersigned call on the Australian government to condemn in the sternest terms Israels actions in Palestine and call for an immediate ceasefire as well as the expulsion of the Israeli ambassador to Australia.

We therefore ask the House to move a motion to condemn in the sternest terms Israels actions in Palestine and call for an immediate ceasefire, along with the expulsion of the Israeli ambassador to Australia.
from 2,049 citizens (Petition No. EN5639)
Banking and Financial Services
The Australian public do not want to live in a cashless society.
We therefore ask the House to introduce legislation making it illegal for any and all businesses (including state and federal businesses) to not accept cash.
from 1,552 citizens (Petition No. EN5640)
Charitable Organisations
When only a small percentage of the Australian population regularly attend religious services, yet everyone pays the bill for it.
Churches should be taxed the same as every other business
We therefore ask the House to start taxing all religions equally and end all religious tax exemptions
from 184 citizens (Petition No. EN5643)
Immigration Detention

We believe it is time to shine a light into the darkness of Australia's immigration detention regime. Between 2001 and present day, tens of thousands of people seeking Australia's protection have been held in immigration camps that are now privatised, offshore, and beyond the reach of Australia's courts and most of the media.

During this period there have been at least 37 cases of suicide related to immigration detention, allegations of torture, the systemic abuse of men and women, and numerous articles and papers on the devastating impact of this privatised detention model. It is estimated this regime has cost Australian tax payers over $9.65 billion from July 2013 to the 2021-2022 financial year.

Numerous investigations have revealed a system beyond the reach of national or human rights oversight. This lack of transparency, the legal fiction of these camps being the responsibility of PNG and Nauru, and a lethal disinterest in the wellbeing of those held in detention has created untold suffering for those detained and those tasked with caring from them in detention.

We therefore ask the House to accept the call for a Royal Commission into Australia's Immigration Detention, to shine a light in this darkened chapter of our national story. Apart from the vital job of truth telling for workers, asylum seekers and taxpayers, such a commission would hear the evidence, reflect on the evidence, and produce a set of recommendations that would go to issues of transparency, legality, and human rights compliance.
from 2,068 citizens (Petition No. EN5644)
Local Content Broadcasting

The Prominence Framework for Connected Television Devices is a transparent attempt to ensure that the government's propaganda outlets, the ABC and SBS, will receive speical priority on smart TV devices. The people of Australia have been propagandised enough over the last four years, during the so-called pandemic and Voice referendum campaign. We don't want any more. Perhaps the reason "local content" is struggling to find an audience is because people are tired of it; it's not providing what they want. The very notion is Orwellian in its intrusiveness. I don't want the government having a node in my home.
We therefore ask the House to reject any prominence framework legislation put before it.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN5646)
New Vehicle Efficiency Standard

We, concerned citizens, call for the implementation of the latest European emission standards (or equivalent) for all vehicles sold in Australia. The current standards are inadequate in addressing air pollution and climate change. By adopting more stringent regulations, we can significantly reduce harmful emissions, leading to improved air quality and better public health. This move aligns with the Federal Government's responsibility for national environmental policies and demonstrates our commitment to a sustainable future.

We therefore ask the House to enact legislation for the adoption of these updated emission standards, ensuring a cleaner, healthier Australia for generations to come. This critical measure will have a profound impact on our environment and the well-being of our citizens.
from 136 citizens (Petition No. EN5647)
Rail Infrastructure

The Sydney to Melbourne rail system is in need of a significant upgrade. Outdated infrastructure and technology result in slower travel times, increased emissions, and hinder economic progress. It's clear that a modernized rail network is essential for our nation's future.

We therefore ask the House to prioritize and fund the comprehensive rail upgrades proposed by Philip Laird. These upgrades include the construction of three major track deviations in New South Wales, upgrading the track to modern engineering standards, and enabling the use of tilt trains. These improvements will lead to faster travel times, reduced emissions, and economic prosperity.
from 91 citizens (Petition No. EN5648)
Rail Infrastructure

Australia's current transportation system heavily favours road transport, leading to a significant carbon footprint and numerous concerns regarding safety and maintenance. The rail sector, unfortunately, has been neglected since the steam era, resulting in an underutilized and outdated mode of transportation. This situation is unsustainable and detrimental to our environment and economy. We must shift our focus towards a more balanced and eco-friendly approach to transportation.

We therefore ask the House to reevaluate the subsidies allocated to road transport and redirect them towards the revitalization of rail infrastructure. This critical step will not only lead to a substantial reduction in CO2 emissions but also enhance the safety and efficiency of our transportation networks. By prioritizing rail, we can stimulate economic growth, create jobs, and foster regional development. Additionally, this redirection of subsidies will contribute to the reduction of micro-plastic pollution, safeguarding our environment for future generations. It is within the power of the Federal Government to lead this transformation towards a more sustainable and prosperous Australia.
from 136 citizens (Petition No. EN5653)
Human Rights
We need an urgent ceasefire in Australia. Innocent people are dying in atrocious numbers. Killing and more killing is not the answer.
Two fires put together do not put the fire out, they make the fire stronger.
We need as a collective human race to ceasefire.
Please.

We therefore ask the House to please put forward the urgent request for a ceasefire in all wars. Allow people to seek refuge in other countries, please allow medical assistance and please from the bottoms of your hearts please hurry.
from 7,663 citizens (Petition No. EN5654)
Skilled Migration Program
494 holders that are isolated in regional areas of Australia, should have the right to apply for PR after two years living and working in Australia instead of three ATO years.

We therefore ask the House to consider all 494 holders to have an immediate right to apply for permanent residency after completing two years working and living regional areas of Australia instead of three.
from 1,098 citizens (Petition No. EN5655)
Middle East

As of 7th November 2023, the Palestine Ministry of Health reports that at least 10,000 civilians have been killed in the last 31 days, including 4,104 children and 2,641 women. According to the UN, one child is killed and two children are injured every ten minutes in Gaza. This must stop. 2.3 Million people are homeless with inadequate humanitarian aid, scarce food, no running water, no sanitation. The hospitals that are still operating have no power, no analgesia, no antibiotics. Operations such as Caesarian sections and amputations are being performed without anaesthesia. It is estimated that there are 50,000 pregnant women in Gaza right now . Over 1000 children are missing and thought to be under rubble.
We are watching this happen and looking to our leaders for action but they are sitting on their hands and doing nothing to stop it.
We therefore ask the House to :
1. Demand an immediate ceasefire in Gaza now to end Israeli bombing and military attacks on Gaza.
2. Call for the opening of sufficient and effective humanitarian corridors to allow aid and fuel to enter Gaza immediately.
3. Protect healthcare workers, alongside all civilians, in Gaza .
4. Advocate for Palestinians in Gaza to be put under United Nations protection with a UN peacekeeping force
The violence and mass murder of civilians and healthcare workers must stop now.
from 35 citizens (Petition No. EN5657)
First Home Super Saver Scheme
First applied for the FHSSS in 2018 (was only $8000 released), however was not able to purchase a home and ended up recontributing the release.

6 years later and am now in a better position, including salary sacrificing to the scheme, but am unable to reapply despite still not having bought my first home due to restriction of only being able to apply for it once.
We therefore ask the House to be allowed to reapply for the FHSSS if one has not purchased a first home and has recontributed the previous amount released under the FHSSS.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5658)
People with Disability

The recent Senate Inquiry 'Assessment and support services for people with ADHD' report recommended the installation of a Federal Minister for Disability. However, this measure was not unanimously supported. There has also been debate regarding whether or not ADHD will be considered for the NDIS.

This renders those with ADHD, and other disabilities that are not recognised and supported by the NDIS, but that are recognised and protected under the provisions of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (Cth), at risk across a range of aspects of life: education, funding support, employment, and adjustment supports. Whilst the need for a Federal Minister for Disability is considered, we urgently request that an interim measure be remedied.
Time is the enemy of vulnerable members of our community.
We therefore ask the House to
i) Install a Federal Minister for Disability as a matter of national urgency.

ii) Consider that an interim statutory provision is made using the Ministers of State Act 1952 for the Prime Minister to appoint a member of either house of Parliament to be an assistant minister to a minister. We request The Hon. Anthony Albanese PM to appoint an assistant minister to the Minister for the NDIS as an interim measure to support those Australians with disability who do not qualify for support under the NDIS, but who are recognised and protected under the provisions of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (Cth).
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN5659)
Nuclear Energy
Join the US and UK in getting Fusion Energy Sooner.

This week the Department for Energy Security and Net Zero and the US Department of Energy announced that they had formed a partnership to speed up the demonstration and commercialisation of FusionEnergy.
This week the UK passed laws that separate fusion from fission to aid in its earlier commercialization development.
The UK and US have increased funding to fusion, which gives many industries work

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy. As well as implement new legislation separating Fission and Fusion for the commercialization and development of a Fusion Industry in Australia and the building of power plants to argument the renewables and Hydrogen system and also develop an international fusion industry in SE Asia and extend it internationally to China, India and Africa.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5664)
Middle East

The conflict between Israel and Hamas and other armed groups has taken a devastating toll on civilians. The level of casualties is unprecedented. With each day that passes more lives are lost and the humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza is getting worse.

A ceasefire would put a stop to unlawful attacks by all parties, halt the mounting death toll in Gaza and enable aid agencies to get life-saving aid, water and medical supplies into the Strip to address the staggering levels of human suffering. It will also allow hospitals to receive life-saving medicines, fuel and equipment they desperately need and to repair damaged wards.
A ceasefire would also provide the opportunity for independent international investigations to take place into the war crimes committed by all parties.
We therefore ask the House to call on an immediate ceasefire and put an end to the ongoing humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza.
from 54 citizens (Petition No. EN5665)
Electoral Roll

At every election, there are hundreds of thousands of Australian citizens who are disqualified from voting for no reason other than that they live overseas. They may carry an Australian passport, pay tax in Australia, receive government benefits and or own Australian property. Yet, they have no say in how the Australian Government governs these matters.

This is because overseas Australians are subject to different voting eligibility rules compared to Australians at home under sections 94 and 94A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Cth). This law states that once an Australian is enrolled as an overseas voter they will be removed from the electoral roll after 6 years and will not be included again until they return to Australia for a certain period.

Relevantly, of the almost 600,000 Australians living or working overseas at the time of the 2022 election, only 6% were registered as eligible overseas voters. This means there are hundreds of thousands disenfranchised Australians. Given the right to vote underpins our democracy, this law only serves to undermine our electoral system.

We therefore ask the House to : (1) amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act so that overseas Australians can enrol and stay enrolled to vote like all other Australian citizens; 2) ensure all overseas diplomatic missions provide pre-polling stations so that overseas Australians have the same opportunity to vote; and (3) direct the Australian Electoral Commission to promote enrolment for and voting by overseas Australians.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN5666)
Climate Change

Solar Radiation Management (SRM) techniques, such as the injection of particles into the atmosphere, fundamentally interfere with the climate system, including the global hydrological cycle and monsoons, leading to potential disruptions and unpredictable changes in weather patterns.
SRM fails to address the root causes of climate change, namely greenhouse gas emissions, and only provides a temporary masking of warming effects without solving the underlying issues.

Risks to Ocean Ecosystems: These methods do not halt or reverse ocean acidification, a profound and dangerous problem threatening marine life and coral reefs, as they do not reduce atmospheric CO2 concentrations.

Global Governance and Cooperation Risks: SRM could lead to unilateral actions, creating significant climate risks for many and potentially becoming a source of conflict between nations. It stands in contradiction with the objectives of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the Paris Agreement.

Intergenerational Justice Issues: Techniques like SRM would need continuous application; if disrupted, they could lead to rapid and large-scale planetary warming, a phenomenon known as "termination shock," which could be worse than the effects of climate change they aim to mitigate.

We therefore ask the House to immediately cease all activities related to Solar Radiation Management and geoengineering. The potential risks and uncertainties associated with these practices far outweigh any perceived short-term benefits. We must instead focus our efforts on sustainable solutions that address the root causes of climate change.
from 180 citizens (Petition No. EN5667)

subdebateinfo.title: Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action

p.span: Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action

In 2019, 12 countries signed the Intergovernmental Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action for which UNICEF, YOUNGO and the Children's Environmental Rights Initiative are the joint custodians, but Australia still has not signed the Declaration. As Earth goes into climate emergency whilst we embark on the UN Decade on Ecosystem Regeneration to resuscitate her, it is ever more urgent and more critical for the first generation to feel the effect of climate change and the last generation who can do something about it, to be united to avoid intragenerational confrontations. Therefore, it is imperative for the government to recognise and mobilise the enormous capacity of children and youth to be mighty agents of change by consistently considering the latter's specific needs, rights, and perspectives in climate actions at all levels. The Declaration represents an opportunity for Australia to commit to the adoption of a comprehensive framework to rectify the widespread omission of children and youth from climate policies across different tiers of government. We have already squandered 30 years, there is simply no more time for mankind to be divided and conquered by this climate crisis due to infighting between younger and older members of this last generation who can ensure the survival of our future generations. Let's put our Earth where our mouth is!
We therefore ask the House to debate and vote on a motion urging the executive government to sign the Intergovernmental Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN5668)
Skilled Migration Program

We, the undersigned, hereby submit this petition urging the Parliament of Australia to consider reducing the duration of the 494 visa from 3 years to 2 years, aligning it with the duration of the visa 482.

The 494 visa, introduced to address regional skill shortages, has become a crucial pathway for skilled migrants to contribute to regional development. However, the current disparity in visa duration between the 494 and 482 visas has raised concerns within our community.

Reducing the 494 visa duration to 2 years will provide consistency across the visa system, fostering a fair and equitable approach for all skilled migrants. This alignment would not only simplify the immigration process but also contribute to the overall effectiveness of Australia's migration policies.
We understand the need for flexibility in immigration policies, and we believe that harmonizing the duration of the 494 visa with the 482 visa is a positive step toward achieving this goal.
We therefore ask the House to review and consider this proposal to the benefit of skilled migrants, regional communities, and the nation as a whole.
Thank you for your attention to this matter. We look forward to a positive response that reflects the inclusive and dynamic nature of Australia's migration policies.
from 105 citizens (Petition No. EN5672)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Allied Health Services

p.span: Goods and Services Tax: Allied Health Services

The removal of GST on exercise physiology services in Australia is crucial for fostering public health and well-being. By exempting these services from the Goods and Services Tax, the government encourages greater accessibility to exercise physiology, making it more affordable for individuals seeking preventive and rehabilitative care. This move promotes a healthier society, reducing the burden on the healthcare system by preventing chronic conditions and supporting those with existing health issues. Additionally, it incentivises people to prioritise physical activity, addressing the growing concerns of sedentary lifestyles. Ultimately, the elimination of GST on exercise physiology services aligns with a proactive approach to healthcare and overall community welfare.

Exercise physiology is a highly respected and evidence based health profession, as demonstrated by the inclusion of exercise physiology services in the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA), National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), personal injury (work cover) schemes and private health insurance; and by the employment of exercise physiologists in public and private hospitals.

"Exercise physiology services have been included in Medicare since 2006 and despite former Treasurer Costello's assertions in 1999 that Medical services would be GST-free if they attracted a Medicare benefit, exercise physiology is subject to GST"
We therefore ask the House to remove GST from exercise physiology services
from 3,903 citizens (Petition No. EN5674)
Nuclear Energy

In September, US Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm announced the Biden administration's ambitious goal of establishing a commercial nuclear fusion facility within the next decade as part of the nation's shift towards clean energy.
Public-private partnerships in the UK and US fusion programs have been initiated.

Note: The IAEA Nuclear Safety and Security Glossary does not include fusion facilities under the category of nuclear installations, however, Contracting Parties to the CNS may consider certain fusion power plants as being a nuclear installation (i.e. a land-based NPP) for the purpose of the CNS.

In doing so, the Contracting Parties should note that a potential limitation arising from the definition of a nuclear installation is that a land-based NPP ceases to be a nuclear installation for the CNS "when all nuclear fuel elements have been removed permanently from the reactor core". Currently, nuclear fuel for fission-based plants is commonly understood as being fissionable nuclear material in the form of fabricated fuel elements.
Is Australia reviewing its nuclear laws to safeguard Australia and when will Australia join the US and UK to commercialise Fusion?

We therefore ask the House to seek international legal advice amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy. The IAEA Nuclear Safety and Security Glossary does not include fusion facilities under the category of nuclear installations,s
from two citizens (Petition No. EN5675)
Health Care: Maternity Services
I draw your attention to the closure of private maternity units.

The Federal Government is responsible for the national maternity crisis unfolding in hospitals across Australia, particularly in regional and remote communities. Closures of private maternity units and shortages are a threat to the long-term viability of private health insurance, particularly for women and young girls when private maternity services are no longer available. The closures of these private facilities are forcing pregnant women to shift to the already burdened and understaffed public healthcare system, which is seeing burn out and resignations of trained and experienced health care professionals and maternity units going on bypass. The latest closure being Cairns Private Hospital maternity unit and Epworth Private Hospital in Geelong.

If private obstetricians, particularly in regional and remote areas are not granted admitting rights to birth their private patients in public hospitals in return to being on call support for public patients in public hospitals, the future of private maternity is questionable. Women should have the right to choose where they want to birth and have the choice to choose an obstetrician to provide continuity of care through to delivery and postnatal care.

We therefore ask the House to address the ongoing closures of private maternity units across Australia. We also ask the House to allow health care professionals, particularly obstetricians in regional and remote areas to have access to a digital passport which allows them to work across the public and private sector, allowing women a choice of birthing.
from five citizens (Petition No. EN5676)
Fuel

The current cost of living is making it extremely difficult for people in Australia. The previous government cut the excise on fuel to make it more affordable for families which relieved some of the financial stress. The current Government are spruiking a financial surplus of 22 billion dollars, however it is harder for families to survive financially with the interest rates going up regularly (12 rises under the current government). The Prime Minister stated he would reduce the cost of living if he won the last election, but this has not been the case.

If the Government cut the excise on fuel for 12 months by 50%, it would only use around 6 billion dollars from this surplus. It would greatly reduce the cost of travel, especially for country people where public transport is not an option.

Around 28% of Australian residents live in rural or remote areas, many of whom have a mortgage as well, therefore, many would appreciate the extra financial saving to pay for the additional power costs and general living costs.
We therefore ask the House to move a motion to cut the fuel excise by 50% for the next 12 months.
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN5678)
Centrelink
Centrelink continues to make more complex confusing rules and regulations for Australians who have worked more than 50 years by the age of retirement
They are also penalised when they make a decision to move to another country due to the Excessive cost of living in Australia
The complex matrix of entitlements need to be simplified
The unreasonable timeframes for reply and lengthy delays in assisting and processing
These are just a few of the examples why we need a royal commission into their conduct
We therefore ask the House to request a Royal Commission into the conduct of Centrelink when dealing with elderly pensioners and their conduct
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN5679)
Renewable Energy
We, the petitioners, call upon the Federal Government to commit to a moratorium on all large-scale wind, solar, pumped hydro and related transmission projects until:
1. a bond is held from start of project with guaranteed finance in place to cover decommissioning and full project removal, disposal and rehabilitation costs at end of life;
2. appropriate regulations are in place to protect threatened and endangered species;
3. large scale renewable projects are subject to full State government approval processes and be made impact-assessable not code-assessable;
4. an appropriate land access framework to protect the environment, cultural heritage and existing land users is established;
5. the financial impact upon existing rate payers and their Local Councils is negotiated as compensation for the use of infrastructure and any damage thereto;
6. Australia's food security is protected by prohibiting large scale renewable projects on prime agricultural land; (See Paris Agreement Article 2 (1) (b))
7. all large-scale renewable projects comply with the same regulations that apply to agriculture and mining;
8. large scale renewable projects are added as a trigger to the EPBC Act;
9. a mandatory code of conduct is established to govern the renewable energy sector and renewable energy proponents' conduct with affected communities.
10. Effective and efficient recycling and disposal of 'renewable projects' end of life infrastructure.
11. A secure, sovereign, energy generation plan is determined, to ensure citizens and businesses are able to access reliable, affordable and dispatchable electricity.
We therefore ask the House to to commit to a moratorium on all 'renewable energy' projects.
from 3,794 citizens (Petition No. EN5680)
Personal Information and Privacy

Discontinue all requirements for My Gov ID app login replacing My Gov login for the ATO (Australian Taxation Office) website. Some users are being locked out of essential services because My Gov login options have been taken away, replaced by My GovID app, which should not be forced on the public, but given as an option. Many of the Public have chosen not to use it as it has shown to be faulty in the past and an insecure way to store identity details from attackers that could gain full access to users accounts. A MyGov login option should be provided alongside the My Gov ID app's login where presented.
We therefore ask the House to provide a My Gov login option alongside the MyGovID app login option where presented.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN5681)
Nuclear Energy

The IAEA is now clearly aiming to start developing fusion-specific safety standards echoing the results of healthy debates among the meeting participants from various horizons (R&D, Academic, Regulatory Bodies, Private Industries, NGOs) which stressed the importance to clearly separate fusion from fission standards. We can start some unambiguous work at the International level as started nationally in UK and the USA for example.

We therefore ask the House to review the laws and regulations in regards to fusion and amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, amend the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act 1998 and repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy. We ask that the house initiate the International Atomic Energy Agency's (IAEA) reviewing approach to start Australia down the path of setting up the regulatory framework needed for the nuclear fusion power industry development in Australia.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN5683)
Occupied Palestinian Territories

The people of Palestine have long been suffering barbaric abuse and unjust death at the hands of the Israel Defense Forces and State of Israel. These actions have been consistently and knowingly backed by Australia, who refuse to respect the wishes of the Palestinian people, nor even hear their plights.

Australia is one of a minority of states that do not even consider the State of Palestine to be a real country, instead solely recognising Israel. This means that the Palestinian people do not have a proper diplomatic method to have their voices heard by the Australian government. This has resulted in a consistent favouring of Israel by successive Australian governments, which contributes to the destruction of Palestinian heritage, the continued illegal occupation of the West Bank and the ever rising death toll of Palestinians, of which 99% are innocent civilians.

By recognising the State of Palestine, we will be able to listen to their voices and make more informed decisions regarding the long-lasting dispute. We will be able to talk to them and, more importantly, they will be able to talk to us and engage in negotiations between our governments. This will help contribute to lasting peace in the region and the end of the dispute.

We therefore ask the House to immediately recognise the State of Palestine, establish a diplomatic mission with the State of Palestine, including the creation of embassies and consulates, and work with the State of Palestine towards lasting peace and the end of the Israel-Palestine conflict.
from 97 citizens (Petition No. EN5685)
Armenia

Despite the overwhelming consensus of historians that the Ottoman Empire and Turkish government deliberately and systematically engaged in a genocide against the Armenian people and identity throughout its historical borders through the use of massacres, death marches, forced Islamisation and other horrific acts, the Australian government does not recognise the Armenian genocide. This damages the Australian government's image, betrays its commitment towards civil rights, and is a morally wrong stance to take on the matter. The Armenian genocide happened and Australia should officially recognise that it did.
We therefore ask the House to officially recognise the Armenian genocide, condemn the Armenian genocide and condemn Türkiye, Azerbaijan and Pakistan's explicit denial of the Armenian genocide.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN5686)
Whistleblower Protection

In recent years, Whistle-blowers have been subject to ongoing court proceedings, which are now culminating in likely convictions or sentences of imprisonment. Whistle-blowers are a cornerstone to maintain public trust and faith in all institutions (government, private, or public). The appearance and perception of how they have been dealt with in recent years acts as a strong deterrent to future Whistle-blowers.

Already the decision to become a Whistle-blower is a heavy burden; knowing the costs in terms of loss of employment, public scrutiny, and possible attempts to defame, ridicule, or smear their character. Now add the looming spectre of criminal charges, years of court proceedings, a criminal conviction and imprisonment; this will push those Whistle-blower's to instead maintain silence, keep the status quo, and turn a blind eye to wrongdoing and corruption. Corruption won't just exist under these circumstances, it will flourish.
To prosecute Whistle-blowers for bringing the most serious of crimes to light is an injustice, and as famously written many years ago 'an injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere'.

We therefore ask the House to strengthen Whistle-blower protections to give them immunity from prosecution, exemption from liability, and protections against defamatory statements or damaging allegations without merit.
from 80 citizens (Petition No. EN5691)
Middle East
We respectfully submit this petition to the Australian Parliament, urging immediate action to advocate for a ceasefire in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories.
We bear witness to civilian death, injury and trauma, and grieve for the loss of all lives; of women and men; old and young; Palestinian and Israeli.
We acknowledge the historical and geopolitical factors contributing to the conflict and recognise the urgent imperative of a just and lasting resolution.
The impact of this conflict is felt keenly by Australians from diverse backgrounds, each with their own connections and perspectives; all with an indelible humanity.
We therefore ask the House to :
1. Use its diplomatic influence to call for an immediate and unconditional ceasefire in the region by all parties and their allies.
2. Call for the immediate release of all civilian hostages and political prisoners held by any party.
3. Advocate for the promotion and protection of political freedoms and the right for peaceful assembly within Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories.
4. Work with international organisations to ensure the delivery of essential humanitarian aid to those in need, without discrimination.
5. Support international efforts aimed at ending the occupation of Palestinian territories and expansion of illegal settlements.
6. Actively contribute to international efforts aimed at facilitating dialogue between all parties involved.
7. Support diplomatic efforts that promote the aspirations of Israelis and Palestinians, respecting their right to self-determination.
8. Support and participate in international investigations into alleged war crimes by any and all parties involved.
from 832 citizens (Petition No. EN5694)
Migration

During the COVID-19 pandemic, our critical and essential workers emerged as true heroes, demonstrating unwavering dedication to our community. They risked their health, worked tirelessly, and made invaluable contributions to our society. It's time to show our appreciation by granting them permanent residency in Australia.

We therefore ask the House to an government to recognize the exceptional sacrifices and contributions of these COVID-19 heroes by granting them permanent residency. This act of kindness would not only acknowledge their selfless dedication but also provide them with a secure and promising future in Australia.

Granting permanent residency to these heroes aligns with Australia's values of inclusivity and appreciation for community contributions. It encourages them to continue their vital work in our critical sectors, ensuring a bright future for them and their families in our country.

By offering permanent residency, we express our gratitude for their sacrifices and dedication during the pandemic. It sends a powerful message that Australia values their contributions and wishes to provide them with the stability and recognition they deserve.

We urge the government to take this important step to honor our COVID-19 heroes and create a more inclusive and appreciative society. Let's make Australia a place where everyone feels welcome, and where giving back to the community is both appreciated and celebrated. This is an opportunity to express our heartfelt gratitude and to ensure a brighter future for those who have done so much for us all.
from 59 citizens (Petition No. EN5695)
Medicare: Imaging Services

MRI Referrals from GPs aren't bulk billed or covered by medicare because they haven't come from a specialist. At $300+ per MRI they are unaffordable to everyone but especially to pensioners. This needs to be fixed.
We therefore ask the House to Make it so GP Referred MRIs are fully covered by bulk billing/Medicare.
from 165 citizens (Petition No. EN5699)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Allied Health Services

p.span: Goods and Services Tax: Allied Health Services

To remove Goods and Services Tax from Exercise Physiology services to put us on par with other Allied Health professions such as Physiotherapy, Occupational Therapy, Speech Pathology and Chiropractics, to name very few Allied Health services that aren't currently effected by GST.

Exercise Physiology was a relatively new Allied Health profession when GST was removed from a large number of Health Services in the 1998 'Health Services in Goods and Services Tax (GST) Reform in Australia' which states that a Health Services which is recognised by and receives benefits from Medicare is exempt to Goods and Services Tax, with Exercise Physiology being recognised under Medicare since 2006.
The addition of GST to Exercise Physiology services creates burden on the industry as it increases the costs for each appointment which will be passed onto the patient or absorbed by the business.
This is an issue because:

If cost is passed onto the patient, it may reduce likelihood of rebooking, even if treatment needs to be continued. It also creates confusion for clients, due to this many EP services are charging at a lower rate to compensate for this which may lead to devaluation of EP services.

If the tax is absorbed by the business it may affect the ability of some services to remain open to the public, if GST is impacting on the business' ability to generate income. Meaning that some Allied Health practices may be reluctant to offer Exercise Physiology service.
We therefore ask the House to Remove GST from Exercise Physiology Services
from 165 citizens (Petition No. EN5701)
Middle East
I am condemning what is happening in Gaza.
We therefore ask the House to representative to act on behalf of every Australian citizen who condemn what's happening in Gaza to stop killing innocent civilians specially women and kids.
from 250 citizens (Petition No. EN5704)
Nuclear Energy

The EU parliament has passed laws to allow fusion to be developed, putting it as how future tech is more often delayed than advanced. Also, the ban in Australia on the development and building of nuclear power may now allow fusion and its separation from fission. Those laws originally took time for negotiations and demonstrations from many stakeholders to get made. Fusion is not part of the international Atomic energy or other nuclear laws at present. Pointed out in the IAEA Fusion Outlook 2023 Safety, security, safeguards, nuclear law and liability. They do not classify the development of fusion as nuclear because the definitions in laws specifically refer to fission energy. So all the non-proliferation treaties are not relevant to fusion, nor are all sovereign states that have banned or restricted nuclear developments as based in law on the IAEA recommendations and regulations. This will need to be tested, as laws need to be tested and so there will hence be delays which will be of benefit to fusion, like say, developing and building an electrical fusion generation plant in preference to Fission reactors in Australia.

We therefore ask the House to amend SECT 140A of the ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION ACT 1999, repeal or amend any other legislation prohibiting the use of nuclear fusion energy and retain the prohibition on nuclear fission energy. Instigate a committee of international fusion energy and industry advisers, and nuclear lawyers to review laws.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN5705)
Personal Information and Privacy
It's been proven that Google and other streaming services use microphone app on devices to listen to what people say .this needs to stop .
We therefore ask the House to investigate why apps like google and others are breaking Australia law by illegally listening to your conversation while using device
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN5706)
Intellectual Property

Large tech companies are using large data sets to train neural networks without regard for the legality of their use of the data. Many authors have found out by accident that their copyrighted works have been used without permission for this purpose.

We therefore ask the House to enact laws to prohibit the development or use of neural networks which were trained on copyrighted works without the copyright-holder's permission. Also to prohibit the development or use of neural networks trained on images or videos of people who have not provided explicit and uncoerced authorisation for their likeness to be used in this manner.
from 48 citizens (Petition No. EN5707)
Anindilyakwa Land Council

We the Anindilyakwa people and traditional owners and extended families of the Groote Archipelago ask for clarity into the findings of the Auditor General report No 29 of 2022-23,- Governance of the Anindilyakwa Land Council.

This federal parliamentary tabled report showed that members of the Anindilyakwa Land Council executive and Board of Directors may not have acted in their employed and elected roles in good faith for the governance of the people of the Groote Archipelago. The report outlines numerous examples of conflicts of interest that may not be in line with their expected terms of employment or elected positions.

We therefore ask the House of Representatives to call for an independent investigation into potential gross misconduct of terms of employment of the Anindilyakwa Land Council executive and elected positions of the Board of Directors, in order to restore good faith in the Anindilyakwa Land Council's ability to govern the people of the Groote Archipelago in their best interests and with out prejudice.
from 235 citizens (Petition No. PN0579)
Migration

The former visa holder's mother is currently residing in her own home but now requires in-home care. The failure to reinstate the visa will force the mother of the visa holder out of her home and into a nursing home contrary to her wishes. The cost of nursing home place and related care will be a burden on the Australian Tax Payers and deprive someone else of a nursing home place.
We therefore ask the House to demand the relevant minister to set aside the decision in AAT matter 2023/5174 and reinstate the visa of the applicant in that matter.
from 63 citizens (Petition No. PN0587)
Aged Care
A hands-on face-to-face audit will identify any shortfalls that the Laura Johnson Home may have in the running of the Home so they can act on the recommendations accordingly.
We therefore ask the House to support a hands-on face-to-face audit of the Laura Johnson Home's leadership and management at the workplace.
from 143 citizens (Petition No. PN0588)
Telecommunications

This petition is to ask the House of Representatives to lobby Telstra on our behalf, for drastically improved mobile phone coverage to the local area of Texas and surrounding suburbs, by installing new towers and/or upgrading existing infrastructure so towers are not operating at double capacity, causing black spots, dropouts and failed calls which leads to safety concerns for the health and safety of locals.
If you support the above statement I ask you to join with me (Matthew Dawson of Beebo QLD) by signing this petition please.
from 642 citizens (Petition No. PN0589)
Middle East

The United Nations and its various bodies, and international human rights organisations, have all stated that the ongoing siege of Gaza and Israel's actions in Gaza since October 7 2023, represent clear violations of international law, which could amount to war crimes; crimes against humanity; and genocide. These crimes are codified in Division 268 of the Commonwealth Criminal Code, meaning Australia has the jurisdiction to investigate and prosecute persons involved in their commission, regardless of their nationality or on the territory where the crime took place. An undisclosed number of dual citizens of Australia and Israel were part of the over 360,000 reservists summoned by the Israel Defense Force (IDF) following the October 7 Hamas attack to "join the fight". These reservists were subsequently flown, some individually and some via repatriation flights, to Israel to join the IDF's attack on Gaza and throughout the Occupied Palestinian Territory. Given the catastrophic situation and the unfolding genocide in Gaza,

We therefore ask the House to establish an urgent parliamentary inquiry to inquire into the involvement of Australian nationals in the IDF's operations in the OPT and an Australian Federal Police investigation of those individuals involved in the IDF's offensive. For the safety of Australia, we must ensure that we are committed to upholding our laws so that citizens alleged to be involved in the commission of grave crimes are investigated and prosecuted. Such an inquiry should request that Israel cooperate fully with the inquiry and any investigation.
from 12,872 citizens (Petition No. PN0591)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 108 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Partner Visas
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4109 concerning Partner visas. As advised by the Secretariat of the Standing Committee on Petitions, the correspondence was only received recently on 26 July 2023 due to a technical error. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government acknowledges the important role family migration plays in delivering social outcomes for Australia and contributing to social cohesion by strengthening family and community bonds in Australia. The Family Stream of Australia's Permanent Migration Program seeks to facilitate the reunification of family members of Australian citizens, permanent residents and Eligible New Zealand citizens. The Partner category allows Australian sponsors to sponsor their spouse, de facto partner or prospective partner.

The processing of visa applications backlogs remains a priority for the Australian Government. The Department of Home Affairs continues to consider and utilise various strategies to deliver as many places as possible, and reduce Family visa backlogs while not compromising on risk settings.

From 2022-23, the Partner program moved to a demand driven model. Granting Partner visas on a demand driven basis provides the flexibility to meet demand for Partner visas in a given program year, and assist in mitigating future growth in the Partner visa pipeline and processing times.
In 2022-23, first stage Partner processing times have improved compared to the previous program year.
In June 2023, the first stage Partner processing time at the 50th percentile (median) was five months, a reduction from 8 months in June 2022.
In June 2023, the first stage Partner processing time at the 75th percentile was 6 months, a reduction from 13 months in June 2022.
In relation to the cost of Partner visas, the Visa Application Charges (VAC) prescribed in Schedule 1 of the Migration Regulations 1994 are taxes imposed on visa applicants.

They are classified as general taxation and set by Government in accordance with policy objectives, where a range of considerations are taken into account; including the size and composition of the Migration program. As general taxation, all revenue is returned to Government to provide services to the community.

As to the sponsorship framework, the Migration Amendment (Family Violence and Other Measures) Act 2018 established a new family sponsorship framework, separating Family sponsorship and visa applications. This framework only applies to the Sponsored Parent (Temporary) visa, introduced on 1 July 2019. The expansion of this framework to other visas is currently on hold.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4109 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence to the Hon Stephen Jones MP, Assistant Treasurer, concerning Petition EN4125 on Reinstating Job Keeper for individuals receiving the Disaster Recovery Allowance (DRA).
Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The JobKeeper Payment was implemented by the previous government as a targeted and temporary measure to support the connection between businesses and their employees during the period of greatest disruption arising from the COVID-19 pandemic. JobKeeper ceased on 31 March 2021.

The Disaster Recovery Allowance (DRA) is a short-term income support payment to assist individuals who can demonstrate their income has been affected as a direct result of a disaster. When available, DRA assists employees, small business persons and farmers who experience a loss of income as a direct result of a major disaster. It is payable for a maximum of thirteen weeks from the date at which a person has, or will have, a loss of income as a direct result of a disaster. DRA is taxable.

The Government considers these arrangements are appropriate to meet the short term needs of those experiencing the immediate impacts of natural disaster events. A range of other Commonwealth support payments may be available when an individual's Disaster Recovery Allowance ends. This includes the JobSeeker Payment.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4177 with three signatures, concerning delayed processing times of Bridging B visa (BVB) applications, and the request to reduce processing times of BVB applications to 10 business days. I apologise for the delay in responding.
