The Department of Home Affairs endeavours to process all visa applications in a timely manner and aims to provide a fair and reasonable service to clients at all times.

Bridging visas (BV) allow the visa holder to stay lawfully in Australia while they are dealing with the Department on a range of matters, such as waiting on the outcome of a visa application or review of a visa decision. A BV is not a substantive visa.

A BVB can be granted to those who have substantial reasons to travel during the substantive visa application process, with BVB applications assessed by the area responsible for finalising the applicant's associated substantive visa application. BVB processing times can be impacted by workload peaks experienced by the relative visa program, and whether the application is complete or additional information is required.

Separately, from 1 August 2022, the Department has facilitated faster BVA, BVB and BVC application processing times and reduced BV lodgement administrative burden for applicants by introducing a new online lodgement capability via a webform instead of lodging in-person or by posting a paper application form. The online form is available on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help- support/departmental-forms/online-forms/bridging-a-b-c-visa-application-online.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4177 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 26 July 2023 concerning petition EN4271, which relates to the processing of Skilled Regional visas (subclass 887). I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is aware of the significant backlog of subclass 887 visa applications that existed at the beginning of the year. Since January 2023, the Department of Home Affairs has finalised over 19,000 subclass 887 visas, at a rate of approximately 3,225 finalisations per month. This is in comparison to an average of around 180 finalisations per month, which occurred for the whole of the 2021-22 program year.

Reducing the number of on-hand visa applications, including in the subclass 887 caseload, continues to be a priority for the Government. The Department has significantly reduced the subclass 887 visa backlog, and currently has only approximately 700 visa applications remaining on-hand.
The Department continues to process these applications with the intention to further reduce the total number on-hand.
Thank you for bringing these concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence received 11 August 2023 enclosing Petition EN4400, with 12 signatures, concerning the "New Skilled Visas (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2019" (the Bill).

The Australian Government recognises the important role Skilled Regional Provisional visa holders, including subclass 491 visa holders, play in supporting regional economies, employers and communities, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic through their commitment to living, working and studying in regional areas of Australia while on a pathway to permanent residence.

The Bill was consequential to the Migration Amendment (New Skilled Regional Visas) Regulation 2019, which created two provisional skilled regional visas (subclass 491 and subclass 494). The Bill intended to amend seven Acts to provide that holders of these provisional skilled visas would have the same access to welfare payments and Government services as permanent visa holders where eligible. The Bill did not contemplate amendments to legislation concerning the acquisition of residential property.

The 2019-20 Budget measure 'New Regional Visas—population package' was announced as one of a number of measures not proceeding in the 2022-23 October Budget. The original Bill lapsed with the end of the 46th Parliament.

Ministerial Orders provide eligibility for Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) (subclass 491) and Skilled Employer Sponsored Regional (Provisional) (subclass 494) visa holders to enrol in Medicare, subject to any waiting period that may apply, and a clear pathway to permanent residence is available.

Holders of subclass 491 and subclass 494 visas are able to apply for the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa in the Regional Provisional Stream after three years, provided they meet the eligibility criteria for that visa, including having complied with the conditions of their skilled regional visa. Australian permanent residents have access to government payments, services and benefits subject to any waiting periods that may apply.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4400 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 7 November 2022 referring petition EN4419 concerning Parent visas. As advised by the Secretariat of the Standing Committee on Petitions, the correspondence was only received recently (on 26 July 2023) due to a technical error. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government acknowledges the important role family migration plays in delivering social outcomes for Australia and contributing to social cohesion by strengthening family and community bonds in Australia. The Family Stream of Australia's Permanent Migration Program seeks to facilitate the reunification of family members, including partners, children and parents, of Australian citizens, permanent residents and Eligible New Zealand citizens.

The permanent Parent visa program of the Family Stream consists of non-Contributory and Contributory visa subclasses. For program year 2023-24 (commencing on 1 July 2023), 8,500 places have been allocated to the permanent Parent visa program. This number has been retained from program year 2022-23, and represents almost a doubling of places compared to 2020-21 and 2021-22 program years, when 4,500 places were allocated to the program.

The number of places allocated to the permanent Parent program is decided annually as part of the permanent Migration Program planning process. The Government determines the number of places for the Migration Program following public consultations, and sets the program with Australia's immediate and longer-term economic and social needs in mind. Each year, Migration Program settings are announced alongside the Federal Budget.

Processing times for permanent Parent visa applications are impacted by a range of factors, including the number of places allocated to a program each year within the broader migration program and the level of demand. High volumes of permanent Parent visa application lodgements, which for a number of years exceeded annual migration planning levels, have impacted on processing times and the number of on-hand applications within these categories.

In addition to the permanent Parent visa program, the Government facilitates short-term family reunification through temporary visas, which allow for a temporary stay in Australia, but provides no direct pathway to permanent residence:

The Sponsored Parent (Temporary) visa (SPTV) (subclass 870) allows parents of Australian sponsors to visit Australia for up to three or five years at one time, for a combined maximum stay of up to 10 years.

Visitor visas are available for the purposes of a short term stay in Australia, including family visits. The Visitor visa (subclass 600) includes the Sponsored Family stream, which enables eligible persons to sponsor a relative for short-term stays in Australia. Visitor visa policy also allows for parents of Australian citizens or permanent residents to be granted Visitor visas (subclass 600) with visa validity periods greater than the standard 12 months.

On 27 April 2023, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, released an outline of the Government's proposed migration strategy 'A Migration System for a More Prosperous and Secure Australia.'

The Strategy maps the Government's approach for a better targeted, more efficient and outcomes-focused migration system, and notes the need for a reform of the Family program. The Migration Strategy is being developed and will be released at a later date.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4419 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence received 27 July 2023 enclosing Petition EN4433, with 666 signatures, concerning government services eligibility and residential property acquisition for Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) subclass 491 visa holders.
The Australian Government recognises the important role these visa holders play in supporting regional economies and communities.

Holders of subclass 491 visas are able to apply for the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) subclass 191 visa in the Regional Provisional stream after three years, provided they meet the eligibility criteria for that visa—including having complied with the conditions of their skilled regional visa. Once granted, this visa would provide access to government payments, services and benefits available to Australian permanent residents, subject to any waiting periods that may apply.

On 27 April 2023, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, released 'A Migration System for a More Prosperous and Secure Australia—Outline of the Government's Migration Strategy' (the Strategy), which is informed by the Migration Review.
The Strategy notes the importance of working with State and Territory governments to plan our migration intake by:
Aligning investments in infrastructure, services and housing, with joint action across governments to address barriers to increasing housing supply; and
Establishing a greater role for States and Territories in identifying their migration needs and priorities, especially in regional Australia.
The Migration Review is considering how to best support regional areas and is reviewing policy settings of regional visa programs to ensure they are fit for purpose.
Your concerns have been passed to the Migration Review team for their consideration as part of the overall review.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4433 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence received 26 July 2023 enclosing Petition EN4448, with 272 signatures, concerning the requirement for Skilled Work Regional (provisional) subclass 491 visa holders to live, work and study in a regional area for at least three years.
The Australian Government recognises the important role Skilled Regional Provisional visa holders play in supporting regional economies, employers and communities.

Holders of subclass 491 visas are able to apply for the Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191) visa in the Regional Provisional stream after three years, provided they meet the eligibility criteria for that visa (including having complied with the conditions of their skilled regional visa). Once granted, the subclass 191 visa provides access to government payments, services and benefits available to Australian permanent residents, subject to any waiting periods that may apply.

On 27 April 2023, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, released 'A Migration System for a More Prosperous and Secure Australia—Outline of the Government's Migration Strategy' (the Strategy), which is informed by the Migration Review.
The Strategy notes the importance of working with State and Territory governments to plan our migration intake by:
Aligning investments in infrastructure, services and housing, with joint action across governments to address barriers to increasing housing supply; and
Establishing a greater role for States and Territories in identifying their migration needs and priorities, especially in regional Australia.

The Migration Review is considering how to best support regional areas and is reviewing policy settings of regional visa programs to ensure they are fit for purpose. Your concerns have been passed to the Migration Review team for their consideration as part of the overall review.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4448 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Human Rights: China
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023, enclosing Petition EN4660, with eight signatures, concerning the request to grant political asylum to Chinese students currently in Australia. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Australia has a long history of providing resettlement for refugees and others who are displaced as a result of conflict, persecution and human rights abuses. Australia also fulfils its international obligations by offering protection to non-citizens who are already in Australia.

Individuals, including Chinese nationals, who arrive lawfully in Australia, seek asylum and are found to engage Australia's non-refoulement (non-return) obligations may be granted permanent protection, subject to fulfilling relevant visa criteria.
Each case is assessed on its merits and decisions are not based on broad assumptions about the safety in particular countries. Updated country of origin information, from
a range of open-source material, is available to all delegates from the Department of Home Affairs to help them in making informed visa decisions.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4660 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 about a petition lodged with the Standing Committee on Petitions (EN4675) raising concerns about the proposed Chalumbin Wind Farm development (now known as Wooroora Station Windfarm).

I understand that some members of the community have concerns regarding the Wooroora Station Windfarm project. The project is being assessed by a public environment report (PER) under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). The EPBC Act process will ensure adequate consideration of the issues identified in the lodged petition.

The PER assessment approach requires the proponent to undertake a rigorous environmental assessment of all potential impacts on matters protected under the EBPC Act. The PER must contain enough information about the action and its relevant impacts to allow an informed decision on whether an approval should be granted.

As required under the EPBC Act, the public were provided an opportunity to comment on the draft PER. The public comment period extended from 8 December 2022 to 9 January 2023. The proponent was required to summarise the public comments and address them in the final PER, which was made available for public viewing on 29 March 2023.

All relevant information on the project, including its impacts, public comments, and social and economic matters, will be considered when a decision on whether or not to approve the project is made. I am unable to make any further comments on this matter as the final decision maker on the proposal.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Refugee and Humanitarian Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4685, with 60 signatures, concerning the Refugee and Humanitarian (Class XB) visa applications for Ms Shan Khan Amy Horwood's two sons and their families. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I am advised that these visa applications were received by the Department of Home Affairs and are undergoing processing. Your correspondence has been attached to the file and will be included in the consideration of the application.
I appreciate that Ms Horwood and the petition's signatories are concerned for the safety of the applicants and the time taken to process their application.
The Australian Government continues to work to ensure each case is considered and that those at risk of harm who meet visa requirements are resettled to Australia as soon as possible.

Humanitarian visa processing is a complex process and will take some time. Processing times can also vary according to the particular circumstances of the applicant, their location (be it inside or outside their home country), and their ability to travel, provide documents or access Australian Government officials.
The Department will make contact with the applicant or the authorised recipient should further information be required or when the application is finalised.

Under Australia's Humanitarian Program priority is given to the most vulnerable applicants who are assessed as refugees by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and formally referred to Australia for resettlement, and those proposed by immediate family members (i.e. spouses and minor aged children) or relatives residing in regional areas in Australia. Thank you for bringing Petition EN4685 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 27 March 2023 enclosing Petition EN4799, with 15 signatures, concerning no access for jabbed people to Australia without health insurance. I apologise for the delay in responding.

In the absence of Medicare eligibility, stemming from reciprocal health coverage, all visitors to Australia are strongly recommended to make arrangements for private health insurance, regardless of whether or not Condition 8501 (Maintain adequate health insurance) is a visa condition. This ensures all visa holders are fully covered for any unplanned medical and /or hospital care they may need while in Australia.

In instances where Condition 8501 is applied to a visa (mandatory or discretionary) the applicant must provide evidence of holding private health insurance policy with an Australian or overseas registered private health insurer. This evidence must be provided before a visa application can be granted (in the case of primary applicant Student visas, health cover must be obtained through an Australian registered private health insurer). The list of visas subject to mandatory and discretionary Condition 8501 is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/meeting-our- requirements/health/adequate-health-insurance.

Any implementation of international border requirements is undertaken by the Department and the Australian Border Force, upon the advice from the Department of Health and Aged Care and/or Health Minister. As of the 6 July 2022 travellers to Australia are able to travel to and from Australia, without being required to declare their COVID-19 vaccination status.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4799 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Refugee and Humanitarian Visas
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 April 2023 enclosing petition EN4824 with 254 signatures for the Turkish Family Scheme visa. I apologise for the delay in responding.
Australia's Humanitarian Program operates flexibly to respond effectively to global resettlement needs and international humanitarian crises as they arise.

Australia's initial response to those affected by the earthquakes and aftershocks in Turkiye and neighbouring countries focused on providing a range of financial and material aid to Governments and affected populations. The aim was to quickly assist those in immediate need and to assist local communities to rebuild vital infrastructure.

The Department of Home Affairs prioritised processing for those displaced persons in Turkiye who had already lodged an application for a refugee or humanitarian visa, and found themselves in especially urgent and compassionate circumstances as a result of the recent earthquakes.

Prioritisation will occur on a case by case basis, in line with advice from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees so that we can assist those most vulnerable who are faced with persecution, substantial discrimination or violation of human rights, focusing on vulnerable women and children.

Applications lodged under the Special Humanitarian Program will be prioritised and processed as quickly as possible. In all cases, including where a person may need medical support available in Australia, mandatory visa requirements including health and security will be needed before visas can be finalised.

People who have existing refugee and humanitarian visa applications already lodged with the Department can contact immigration.ankara@dfat.gov.au to update the Department about their current circumstances.

People who have not lodged a visa may apply, further information can be found on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/what- we-do/refugee-and-humanitarian-program.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4824 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
International Students
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 17 May 2023 enclosing Petition EN4842, with 7645 signatures, concerning Student visa holder work hours. I apologise for the delay in responding.

A return to the work limitation for Student visa holders from 1 July 2023, was announced at the Jobs and Skills Summit in September 2022. Further clarification was provided in a Government announcement on 21 February 2023, advising that from 1 July 2023, the period of work allowed per fortnight would be increased from 40 hours to 48 hours. On 9 May 2023, the Australian Government also announced that student visa holders already working in the aged care sector as at 9 May 2023 can continue to work unrestricted hours in the aged care sector until 31 December 2023.
The phased introduction of unrestricted work hours over the COVID-19 pandemic was a temporary measure to address critical workforce shortages.

The reintroduction of enforcement of work hour restrictions reinforces that the primary purpose of a Student visa holder is to undertake study in Australia. While the allowable work hours may provide for surplus funds for a student, it is expected that international students already have the financial means to support their educational and living costs whilst undertaking study in Australia. Criteria for the grant of a Student visa includes that the visa applicant has access to sufficient funds to meet the costs and expenses of living and studying in Australia. Australia's plan to allow 48 hours work per fortnight for Student visa holders is a 20 per cent increase in previously allowable work hours, and is more generous than the student visa work hours ordinarily permitted by other countries such as the UK, US, Canada and NZ. Further, during study breaks, Student visa holders are able to work full-time. If a student is also undertaking Work Integrated Learning that is approved as part of their registered course, this is exempt from the work hour limit.

I acknowledge the concerns raised in the petition in regard to worker exploitation. The Government is committed to ensuring all workers have the opportunity to make a positive contribution to the Australian economy, without fear of exploitation.

Student visa holders enjoy the same rights under Australian workplace law as all other employees, including access to the Fair Work Ombudsman (FWO), and are covered by the minimum employment standards prescribed in the National Employment Standards (NES). Student visa holders are also part of the agreement in the Assurance Protocol, an arrangement between the Department of Home Affairs and the FWO that allows visa holders to seek help from the FWO without fear of visa cancellation if they have breached their work- related visa conditions. Information regarding workplace rights and entitlements is provided in Student visa grant letters. The FWO website also provides dedicated migrant worker resources and information in multiple languages.

The Government has also been working towards implementing the recommendations of the Migrant Workers' Taskforce. On 5 June 2023, the Government announced that they will protect workers at risk of exploitation with a package of measures that target employers who seek to exploit temporary visa holders and ensure workers can speak up without fear of reprisal. The Government will also provide $50 million in funding to resource the Australian Border Force for this and other enforcement and compliance activities. Further information can be found at: https://minister.homeaffairs.gov.au/AndrewGiles/Pages/albanese-govt-to- tackle-worker-exploitation.aspx.

Furthermore, earlier this year, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil appointed Ms Christine Nixon AO, APM to undertake a Rapid Review into the Exploitation of Australia's Visa System. The review was established to complement the work that is being progressed to address migrant worker exploitation, and to identify proposals for both systemic reform and discrete measures to prevent, deter and sanction individuals who seek to abuse Australia's visa system to exploit vulnerable migrants.
The draft Rapid Review Report has now been submitted to Minister O'Neil, for consideration. Thank you for bringing Petition EN4842 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 17 May 2023 to Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil enclosing Petition EN4857, with 417 signatures, concerning a Permanent residency pathway for family members on long-term Bridging visas. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.
The Family Stream of Australia's Permanent Migration Program seeks to facilitate the reunification of family members of Australian citizens, permanent residents and Eligible New Zealand citizens.

Some categories of the Family Stream allow applicants to remain in Australia, as the holder of a Bridging visa. A Bridging visa A (subclass 010) is granted to eligible applicants in association with an ongoing application and will allow the person to stay lawfully in Australia while awaiting the outcome of their visa application or review of the visa decision. The Bridging visa does not provide a holder with a pathway to permanent residency.

The processing of visa applications backlogs remains a priority for the Australian Government. The Department of Home Affairs continues to consider and utilise various strategies to deliver as many places as possible, and reduce Family visa backlogs while not compromising on risk settings.

Processing times for the Family Stream are impacted by a range of factors, including the number of places the Government allocates to a program each year and the level of demand for each visa category. High volumes of Family visa application lodgements, which for a number of years exceeded annual migration planning levels set for these programs, have impacted on processing times and the number of on-hand Family stream visa applications, especially application for Parent and Other Family visas.
The Government does not intend to create a pathway to permanent residency for Bridging visa holders who are awaiting a decision on an application for a visa in the Family Stream.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4857 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Energy
Dear Chair
Thank you for referring a copy of petition EN4917 presented to the House of Representatives on 9 May 2023, regarding new policies to put batteries in every household in Australia.
The Australian Government has committed $200 million in grant funding for the Community Batteries for Household Solar Program to deliver 400 community batteries nationwide.
This program will help to lower household electricity costs, reduce emissions, support the grid and provide shared storage for up to 100,000 households.
The government's $1.7 billion Energy Savings Package (announced through the 2023-24 Budget) will help households, local councils, and businesses to access energy upgrades.

This package includes $1 billion to the Clean Energy Finance Corporation to provide low-cost finance for around 110,000 homes to undertake energy upgrades that save energy (which could include battery systems). The Energy Savings Package also includes $300 million to support energy efficiency upgrades to around 60,000 social housing properties. The initiative will target a range of high value energy upgrades, with some jurisdictions considering the installation of solar PV and battery systems.

I acknowledge the concern about rising household energy bills. There are further possibilities for rebates and assistance available in the states and territories which may be available for households and support the installation of household batteries at www.energy.gov.au/rebates.

The government will continue to consider new policies that help households to reduce their energy bills as part of its commitment to reduce emissions to 43 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030 and to lift renewable energy supply to 82 per cent by 2030.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Defence Personnel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 regarding Petition EN4991—Protected Identity for our Veterans and their families.

Defence Protected Identity status is a Defence policy afforded to some current serving ADF members. Defence has published information about this policy entitled Defence Protected Identity Status and its application. This information is available at: https://www.defence.gov.au/news-events/releases/2023-04-13/record-correction-defence-protected-identitv-status-and-its-application
I also refer to my answer to Question in Writing no. 194, from the Member for New England, answered on 14 August 2023.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Attachment
The Hon. Barnaby Joyce, MP submitted a question in writing to the Minister for Defence, on 15 June 2023.
In respect of the publication of names of members or former members of the Special Air Service (SAS) charged with war crimes:
1. Has any consideration been given to a legislative change to prevent publication of their identities.

2. Have any representations been made by the Department of Defence, the Australian Defence Force (ADF) or the Department of Veterans' Affairs (or their respective Ministers) in relation to any changes to legislation pertaining to the publication of identities; if so, when and what was the nature of those representations.

3. Have any views been sought from the Department of Defence, the ADF or the Department of Veterans' Affairs (or their respective Ministers) in relation to changes to legislation pertaining to the publication of identities; if so, when and what was the nature of the information sought.

4. What mechanisms are put in place to ensure the safety of any named SAS member, and their families, when they are identified as having partaken in operations that may make them a target for reprisal actions.
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the questions:

4. There is not a position, nor has there ever been, to publish details of individuals with an active Protected Identity (PID) status. In the event an individual's PID status was compromised, this would be handled in accordance with Defence policies and on the circumstances of that matter.

If Defence PID status is not applicable, but another national security requirement to protect an individual's information is identified, Defence will make an application to the court to protect such information.
Irrespective of a person's identity status, protected or not, Defence complies with its obligations in accordance with the Privacy Act 1988.
Energy
Dear Chair
Thank you for referring petition EN4992 presented to the House of Representatives on
22 May 2023, regarding the use of low emission coal power and gas to meet Australia's energy demands.

The Australian Energy Market Operator's Integrated System Plan (ISP) is a 'whole of system plan' based on rigorous economic modelling and engineering analysis. It demonstrates that new renewables with new transmission, firmed with hydro, batteries and gas, is the lowest cost way to supply electricity to Australian homes and businesses as coal fired generation retires. The Australian Government is implementing the ISP through the Powering Australia Plan, which will deliver $20 billion of investment to modernise the grid through Rewiring the Nation. This will drive down power prices and reduce emissions by boosting renewable energy. The low-cost financing through Rewiring the Nation will facilitate lower total project costs, and therefore lower costs for consumers. The Government is delivering projects and programs, such as the Capacity Investment Scheme, to make sure there is enough flexible, dispatchable generation to keep the supply of electricity reliable and affordable.

The Government is progressing a range of reforms which are aimed at securing sufficient supply of gas for the domestic market, putting downward pressure on prices and ensuring the market is more resilient to future shocks. While we invest in cleaner and cheaper energy for the future, gas will continue to play a role as a flexible fuel supporting the transition to renewables, particularly as coal fired generation leaves the system. The Government is developing a Future Gas Strategy which will provide a medium (to 2035) and long-term (to 2050) plan for gas production and consumption in Australia. A consultation paper was released on 3 October 2023 seeking input on the role gas could play in the future.

The Government accepts the science of climate change and is committed to taking real and significant climate action at home and establishing Australia as a constructive climate partner internationally. The Government has demonstrated this commitment by legislating targets to reduce Australia's emissions by 43 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030 and achieving net zero by 2050. The Government takes its primary advice on climate science from the Bureau of Meteorology and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. This advice aligns with the advice and evidence reported by all major national and international scientific organisations, including the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the Australian Academy of Science, the World Meteorological Organization, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the United Nations.

Households and businesses have been facing unacceptable energy price rises because of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The Government's Energy Price Relief Plan shields Australians from the worst impacts of price increases and provides immediate help with power bills in the short term, while our commitment to supporting a transformation to renewable energy in the medium and longer term will decrease our reliance on volatile coal and gas prices, delivering 82 per cent renewables by 2030, the cheapest form of electricity generation.

This plan is expected to reduce electricity price increases by 25 percentage points and reduce expected retail gas price increases by around 16 percentage points in 2023-24, compared with before the Australian Government's plan was announced. This plan, along with energy bill relief is expected to reduce inflation by three quarters of a per cent in 2023-24.

The Australian Government is partnering with state and territory governments to deliver up to $3 billion of electricity bill relief for eligible households and small businesses. From July 2023, the fund will deliver up to $500 in electricity bill relief to eligible households and up to $650 to eligible small businesses. The latest information on the amount, eligibility, timing, and frequency of rebates in each jurisdiction can be found at www.energy.gov.au/energy-bill-relief-fund.

In addition to targeted energy bill relief, the Government is funding a $1.7 billion Energy Savings Plan to ensure households, businesses and communities can take advantage of the savings from smarter energy use.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Business Innovation and Investment Visa
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 enclosing Petition EN4999, concerning processing times for Business Innovation and Investment (Permanent) (subclass 888) visas. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I understand the desire of subclass 888 visa applicants to obtain permanent residence, and I recognise their frustration with the time taken to process these applications. Reducing the number of on hand visa applications and reducing visa processing times are priorities for the Australian Government. The Department of Home Affairs is drawing flexibly on its global network of visa officers to process applications in line with the Government's commitment to supporting economic recovery and addressing skills shortages.

Skilled migration visa applications are currently processed according to priorities set out in Ministerial Direction No. 100. Ministerial Direction No. 100 prioritises skilled visa programs that directly address workforce shortages and enable employers to fill skilled vacancies more quickly. While the processing of the subclass 888 visa is afforded a lower priority within this Direction when compared to other skilled visa cohorts, I have asked the Department to focus on processing these applications as soon as possible. This is only feasible now because of the recent progress made in reducing processing times across other skilled visa programs.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4999 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Sponsored Parent Visa
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2023 enclosing Petition EN5001, with 217 signatures, concerning visa pathways for parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Government acknowledges the important role family migration plays in delivering social outcomes for Australia and contributing to social cohesion by strengthening family and community bonds in Australia. The Family Stream of Australia's Permanent Migration Program seeks to facilitate the reunification of family members, including partners, children and parents, of Australian citizens, permanent residents and Eligible New Zealand citizens.

The permanent Parent visa program of the Family Stream consists of non-Contributory and Contributory visa subclasses. For program year 2023-24 (commencing on 1 July 2023), 8,500 places have been allocated to the permanent Parent visa program.
This number has been retained from program year 2022-23, and represents almost a doubling of places compared to 2020-21 and 2021-22 program years, when 4,500 places were allocated to the program.

The number of places allocated to the permanent Parent program is decided annually as part of the permanent Migration Program planning process. The Government determines the number of places for the Migration Program following public consultations, and sets the program with Australia's immediate and longer-term economic and social needs in mind.
Each year, Migration Program settings are announced alongside the Federal Budget.
In relation to current settings for the permanent Parent program mentioned in the Petition, I can advise:

The Visa Application Charge for Parent visas only partially offset the cost of Parent migrants to the Budget, noting that Parent migrants draw upon Government services over the span of their lifetime in Australia.

The Balance of Family test aims to ensure that only those with close ties to Australia are eligible for a limited number of Parent visa places in the Migration Program. The test requires Parent visa applicants to demonstrate that at least half of their children are lawfully and permanently resident in Australia or, alternatively, that more of their children reside lawfully and permanently in Australia than in any one single country overseas.

Processing times for permanent Parent visa applications are impacted by a range of factors, including the number of places allocated to a program each year within the broader migration program and the level of demand. High volumes of permanent Parent visa application lodgements, which for a number of years exceeded annual migration planning levels, have impacted on processing times and the number of on-hand applications within these categories.

In addition to the permanent Parent visa program, the Government facilitates short-term family reunification through temporary visas, which allow for a temporary stay in Australia, but provides no direct pathway to permanent residence:

The Sponsored Parent (Temporary) visa (SPTV) (subclass 870) allows parents of Australian sponsors to visit Australia for up to three or five years at one time, for a combined maximum stay of up to 10 years.

Visitor visas are available for the purposes of a short term stay in Australia, including family visits. The Visitor visa (subclass 600) includes the Sponsored Family stream, which enables eligible persons to sponsor a relative for short-term stays in Australia. Visitor visa policy also allows for parents of Australian citizens or permanent residents to be granted Visitor visas (subclass 600) with visa validity periods greater than the standard 12 months.

On 27 April 2023, the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon. Claire O'Neil MP, released an outline of the Government's proposed migration strategy 'A Migration System for a More Prosperous and Secure Australia.' The Strategy maps the Government's approach for a better targeted, more efficient and outcomes- focused migration system, and notes the need for a reform of the Family program. The Migration Strategy is being developed and will be released at a later date.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5001 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2023 regarding petition EN5004, which asks to halt the proposal of a windfarm off the coast of Newcastle and Port Stephens.

The Australian Government knows how important our ocean environments are to our culture, and our livelihoods. Australia's oceans are also home to some of the best offshore wind resources in the world. Harnessing this can help us provide emissions-free power to our communities for generations to come.

We are backing the offshore wind industry because it will pave the way for energy and job security. But in developing this industry, we know how important it is to balance the impact on industries and our environment.

On 12 July 2023, I declared an area offshore of the Hunter, New South Wales as suitable for the development of offshore renewable energy infrastructure. The declaration followed an extensive public consultation process that took place from 23 February to 28 April 2023.

The Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water undertook consultation from 23 February to 28 April 2023 to listen to the views of the community. The consultation was undertaken across the Port Stephens, Newcastle, Lake Macquarie and Central Coast regions using the following methods:
Advertising through newspapers, radio, and social media
Letterbox drop of flyers encouraging the community to make submissions
Detailed information about the proposal and how to make a submission on the department's website
Targeted stakeholder meetings with federal, state and local government agencies, industry, business, and community groups

Seven community drop-in sessions from 6 March to 9 March 2023 in Wamberal, Doyalson, Swansea, Newcastle, Bar Beach, Nelson Bay, and Hawks Nest to answer questions and to encourage the community to make submissions.

I received nearly 2,000 submissions from community members, local organisations and industries. Many submissions raised concerns on visual amenity, the safe management of shipping to and from the Port of Newcastle, and environmental matters, such as the potential impacts on marine life.

After considering the feedback, I decided on a smaller footprint than the originally proposed zone- balancing the views of the local community, local industries and marine users. Listening to feedback and ensuring the zone can coexist alongside whale migration, bird and sea life, and our shipping industry, the zone has been moved to at least 20 km offshore and was reduced in area by about a third. To help manage these concerns, I will place conditions on future feasibility licence holders requiring consultation with specific groups and users of the area. I also limited the height of turbines to a maximum of 260 metres.

This strikes an appropriate balance between harnessing the job and economic opportunities of establishing offshore wind in the Hunter, while maintaining the environmental protections that make this area such a unique and vibrant part of Australia.

Wind farm developers have applied for feasibility licences in the Hunter offshore wind zone, and those applications are now being reviewed. Developers will need to specify how their proposed plans benefit local industry and the local economy.

Once granted feasibility licences, developers must undertake detailed assessments of their planned wind farm's impact on marine users and the environment, and have their projects approved under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999(EPBC Act). Offshore wind farm proposals that do not get EPBC Act approval will not proceed to construction.

During the feasibility licence stage, individual developers will work with communities and other marine users, such as the fishing industry, to refine their project proposals to ensure existing users can continue to use Australia's oceans, sharing the space with this new industry. It is also at this stage that specific project details, such as the number of turbines, will be determined.

Feasibility licence holders will be required to seek feedback on their proposed projects and must demonstrate, to the satisfaction of the Offshore Infrastructure Regulator, how they will share the area with existing users.

The Government is currently developing regulations that will set out the details and requirements of management plans to be developed in the feasibility stage, including the requirement for licence holders to undertake further consultation.

Restrictions may be placed around specific infrastructure to manage safety, as is the case with other marine infrastructure to ensure the safety of offshore workers and other users of the marine environment, and to protect vessels and the infrastructure from damage, as well as when any approved offshore wind projects are under construction to ensure safety for marine users and construction workers. However this will be done in consultation with existing sea users through management plans.

The exact details of these restricted areas will be determined on a project-by-project basis. Even once offshore wind farms become operational, safety zones can only extend to a maximum of 500 metres around individual turbines or substations. There will be no exclusion zones put in place around the whole of a wind farm, and recreational fishers will be free to fish between turbines.

The Hunter offshore wind zone opens the door for a new industry in the Hunter that could create over 3,000 construction jobs and another 1,560 ongoing jobs for the region and be a boost for the local economy. The Government expects projects to deliver for local communities and meet community expectations, and projects will be allowed to progress on that basis.
Thank you again for bringing these concerns to my attention.
Yours Sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Department of Home Affairs: IMMIAccount
Dear Ms Templeman
I refer to your correspondence of 19 June 2023 enclosing Petition EN5034, with
3 signatures, concerning issues being experienced by users seeking to access the Department of Home Affairs' lmmiAccount system. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Department acknowledges some users of lmmiAccount have been unable to access the service during periods of exceptionally high demand in recent weeks and months. I also acknowledge the particular challenges this poses for users to lodge applications during business hours, including migration agents seeking to deliver services across the business day (9am to 5pm).

lmmiAccount is currently experiencing very high, sustained and increasing level of demand from individual clients and registered migration agents. Please be assured the Department is actively working to address current system capacity issues. This is a complex task and will take some time to complete. I would like to advise that remediation work by the Department undertaken since mid-June 2023 resulted in a direct and measurable positive impact on overall system stability and availability, with substantial reductions in the number of users receiving error messages while seeking to access and use lmmiAccount in the lead up to the end of the 2022-23 financial year.

The Department has met with representatives from the Migration Institute of Australia (MIA) to discuss these issues. It is providing regular updates to both the MIA and Law Council of Australia to share with their members on these ongoing activities.

The Department is monitoring lmmiAccount closely and will continue to work with industry users to introduce longer term system capability enhancements to support performance and stability, and improve security at the same time.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5034 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Defence Procurement: Submarines
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 presenting Petition EN5066—Ban purchase of Nuclear Powered Vessels including Submarines. I have given careful consideration to the matters raised by the petitioners.

The Albanese Government recognises that the first responsibility of a government is to provide for the safety and security of its people. The AUKUS partnership is a core pillar of the Albanese Government's national security policy to protect our nation, its interests and security. We confront the most challenging strategic circumstances since the Second World War, and we do so at a time where Australia's economic connection with the world has never been greater.

This was at the core of the Defence Strategic Review and the Government's response, delivered in April 2023, which recognised that we must invest in our defence capabilities now: to defend Australia; deter through denial any attempt to project force against Australia; and protect Australia's economic connection to our region and the world.

The Albanese Government also recognises that we must contribute to the collective security of the Inda-Pacific because our security and prosperity depend on the stability and security of our region. Yet we need to contend with the reality that our region is witnessing the largest conventional military build-up the world has seen in decades. We do not question the right of countries to invest in and develop defence capabilities, but this must be done transparently and with strategic reassurance. We need to ensure the Inda-Pacific remains a region where all countries—big or small—are able to act in their sovereign interest to shape their own future free from coercion.

The acquisition of conventionally-armed, nuclear-powered submarines will enable Australia to better contribute to a sovereign and resilient Inda-Pacific and to deter aggression more effectively. For a maritime trading nation like Australia maintaining a submarine capability advantage over potential adversaries is vital. Closing or blocking sea lanes would have a devastating impact on Australia's economy and security; and of partners in South East Asia, the Pacific, and globally. By investing in these high-end capabilities, Australia is contributing to unimpeded sea lanes and the conditions for a more stable, secure and peaceful region.

The decades of experience offered by the United Kingdom and the United States programs will support Australia in becoming a world leader in nuclear stewardship. Australia is developing a comprehensive safety management system including operations, procedures and infrastructure. Australia is also establishing a system of regulation targeted to the unique needs and circumstances of Australia's conventionally-armed, nuclear-powered submarine program. This will include the establishment of a new independent statutory regulator.

Together with Australia's existing regulatory framework and bodies, we will ensure the program operates in line with domestic and international best practice for safety, security and environmental standards.

Since 1960, Australia has hosted over 285 visits by United Kingdom and United States' nuclear-powered vessels with over 1,800 days in port. These visits are now expected to be longer and more frequent, enabling Australia to develop critical experience with nuclear-powered submarines at sea and at port. Submarines are an essential part of Australia's naval capability, providing a strategic advantage in terms of surveillance and protection of our maritime approaches.
The future security environment of the lndo-Pacific region means that over time the ability of diesel-powered submarines to meet Australia's capability needs will diminish.

Only conventionally-armed, nuclear-powered submarines will meet Australia's defence requirements in the decades ahead. No other platform matches the stealth, endurance, mobility and mix of capabilities a nuclear-powered submarine provides. This enhanced capability will keep maritime threats further away from Australia's shores.
Thank you again for forwarding the Petition EN5066 for my consideration.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Cost of Living
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5068 about a proposed inquiry into the cost of living. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Government understands that cost of living and higher interest rates are putting many Australians under a lot of pressure. This is why our highest priority is rolling out $23 billion in cost-of-living relief.
These measures have been carefully calibrated and methodically designed to take some of the edge off these inflationary pressures. They include:
A record investment in bulk billing,
Reducing the cost of medicines by up to half, for at least six million Australians,
Electricity bill relief that will benefit more than five million eligible households and one million eligible small businesses,
Cheaper child care and Paid Parental Leave,
Support for those who need it most, through expanded access to the Parenting Payment, and a higher rate for recipients of eligible working age and student payments, and
More affordable housing, through the largest increase to Commonwealth Rant Assistance for 30 years and the commencement of the Housing Australia Future Fund.

The Government is also investing in the foundations for future growth by investing in our people and their skills, supporting small businesses to innovate and grow, investing in our strategic industries and renewable energy, and modernising our industrial base.
The Government is focused on dealing with the immediate challenges Australians are facing and building a stronger, more productive, and more resilient economy for the future.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Western Australia: Defence
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 concerning Petition EN5088. The topics raised by Petition EN5088 were considered as part of a holistic analysis of Australia's defence posture and planning during the independently-led Defence Strategic Review (the Review). On 24 April 2023, the Government released the public version of the Review, the Government's response to the Review, and the National Defence Statement 2023.

The Government's response to the Review sets out a blueprint for Australia's strategic policy, defence planning and resourcing over the coming decades. This blueprint articulates a plan to better protect all of Australia, including in the North West.

Through implementation of the Review, this Government will strengthen the Australian Defence Force (ADF) into a fully integrated and focused force to deliver enhanced and joined-up combat power across the maritime, land, air, space and cyber domains.
The Government's immediate actions to reprioritise Defence's capabilities in line with the recommendations of the Review include:
The acquisition of nuclear-powered submarines through AUKUS to improve our deterrence capabilities;
Developing the Australian Defence Force's (ADF) ability to precisely strike targets at longer-range and manufacture munitions in Australia;
Improving the ADF's ability to operate from Australia's northern bases;
Initiatives to improve the growth and retention of a highly skilled Defence workforce;
Lifting our capacity to rapidly translate disruptive new technologies into ADF capability, in close partnership with Australian industry; and
Deepening of our diplomatic and defence partnerships with key partners in the Inda-Pacific.
The Australian Government will bolster investment in Australia's northern bases, committing
$3.8 billion over the next four years, including:
$2 billion for critical air bases stretching from RAAF Base Learmonth through Cocos (Keeling) Islands, as well as air bases in the Northern Territory and northern Queensland;
$1 billion for upgrades to land and joint estate capabilities;
$600 million in maritime estate investments including HMAS Coonawarra, HMAS
Cairns and the Harold E Holt Naval Communications Station, and;
An additional $200 million towards the acceleration of additional projects.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles

subdebateinfo.title: Taylor, Mr Julian Richard of Living

p.span: Taylor, Mr Julian Richard of Living
Dear Ms Templeman
I refer to your correspondence of 19 June 2023 regarding Petition EN5096. I apologise for the delay in responding.

As you are aware, Home Affairs Portfolio Ministers have personal intervention powers under the Migration Act 1958 (the Act), which allow them to grant a visa to a person in immigration detention, if they think it is the public interest to do so. The power is non-compellable, that is, the Ministers are not required to exercise, or consider exercising their power. Further, what is in the public interest is a matter for the Minister to determine.

The Department of Home Affairs is currently considering the implications of the High Court's recent decision in Davis v Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs & Ors and DCM20 v Secretary of Department of Home Affairs & Anor on Ministerial Intervention requests. Further information about the Department's approach will be made available in due course.

Notwithstanding the circumstances of the individual case referred to in this petition, the Department has a statutory duty to remove unlawful non-citizens from Australia as soon as reasonably practicable under section 198 of the Act. As Julian Taylor was an unlawful non- citizen in immigration detention, the Department must comply with this duty.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5096 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
AUKUS
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 June 2023 presenting Petition EN5099.

On 22 March 2023, I provided a Ministerial Statement to the House of Representatives setting out the Australian Government's strategic rationale for Australia's acquisition of conventionally armed, nuclear-powered submarines.
This statement is can be accessed at pages 2058-2062 of Hansard, or at:
https://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/genpdf/chamber/hansardr/26431/0097/hansard_frag.pdf;fileType=application%2Fpdf
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Cost Intellectual Property: Music
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 August 2023 regarding the petition EN5134, Fair pay for music played: Remove the radio caps!

The Australian Government strongly support is Australian artists and creators, as demonstrated by Revive, the Government's National Cultural Policy. However, the Government also recognises that the removal of the radio broadcast royalty caps would impact a range of stakeholders, including regional and remote radio broadcasters, and therefore any reforms need to be carefully considered.
The Government will continue work to develop an understanding of the likely impacts on relevant stakeholders before finalising its position on the removal of the radio broadcast royalty caps.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Cybersafety
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your letter dated 1 August 2023, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning Petition EN5139 which calls for a ban on online access to pornography for individuals under the age of 18. I apologise for the lateness of my response.
The Albanese Government is committed to minimising the harm that comes from children accessing content online that is not appropriate for them, including online pornography.

The Online Safety Act 2021 (the Act) imposes a range of measures to protect children from exposure to adult content. Additionally, the Government has recently delivered its response to the eSafety Commissioner's Roadmap for Age Verification, which considered further measures to mitigate the impact of online pornography on children.

span.span: Current measures in the Online Safety Act which restrict access to pornography

p.span: The Act establishes an Online Content Scheme, which empowers the eSafety Commissioner to request or require takedown of illegal and restricted online content. Most pornographic content falls under the eSafety Commissioner's powers to respond to material that is, or is likely to be, classified as Rl 8+, Xl 8+ or refused classification under Australia's classification framework.
The hosting of pornographic material by Australian online service providers is prohibited under Australian law. As a result, most pornographic material accessed by Australians is hosted overseas.

For material hosted in Australia, the eSafety Commissioner can respond to X18+ material by issuing a removal notice to the service provider, and to Rl 8+ by requiring that the material can only be accessed by adults by placing the content behind a Restricted Access System (RAS). The purpose of a RAS is not to prevent access to age-restricted content, but to ensure access is limited to people who are 18 years and over.

For material that is illegal or seriously harmful that is, or would likely be, refused classification (such as child sexual abuse material), the eSafety Commissioner has a stronger set of powers to require removal of this material no matter where it is hosted.

On 31 March 2023, the eSafety Commissioner delivered the Roadmap for Age Verification (the Roadmap) to the Australian Government. The Roadmap explores if and how age verification and other measures could be used to prevent and mitigate harm to children from online pornography.

The Roadmap found that currently, age verification and age assurance technologies are new and still evolving and come with privacy, security, and governance considerations. The Roadmap made a number of recommendations, including that the Government invest in research, education, awareness, and resources, that the eSafety Commissioner continue work to implement the Online Safety Act, and that the Government should pilot age assurance technologies, before seeking to mandate them.

In developing its response to the Roadmap, the Government focused on what actions are likely to lead to tangible and practical protections for children from pornography. I have asked the eSafety Commissioner to commence work on a set of mandatory, enforceable industry codes to address children's access to online pornography as soon as practicable. These codes are the most effective lever to deliver improved protections for children in the short- to medium-term.

The codes are required under the Act, and for the first time will require platforms to do more to protect children from exposure to online pornography. Importantly, these codes will be mandatory, and will apply to all different sections of the digital industry- including social media platforms, app stores, content hosting services, internet service providers and device manufacturers. With a complex challenge such as this, we need all parts of the online ecosystem to play a role.

These codes will be critical in lifting industry's standards. The code development process will also provide vital information on what a pilot of age assurance technologies might look like in the Australian context. The Government will seek fu1iher advice from the eSafety Commissioner once the codes are on track, including in relation to how a pilot might support and complement the codes.

The Government is also taking action to strengthen our online safety framework. On 22 November, I announced the start of consultation on proposed amendments to the Online Safety (Basic Online Safety Expectations) Determination 2022, which is established under the Act. The Determination articulates Government's minimum expectations for online service providers to improve protections for users, including from harmful content. The eSafety Commissioner has the power to require service providers to report on their compliance with these expectations, driving transparency around industry's actions.

Under the proposed amendments, industry would be expected to consider the best interests of children in the design and operation of their services. An amendment would also make explicit that age assurance technologies are an important tool to prevent harm to children online. It is clear that some age assurance technologies and complementary measures are already being deployed across commercial platforms to prevent a range of harms to children and the Government wants to see industry continue to develop and invest in these technologies.

Countries around the world are grappling with the problem of age assurance and how best to protect children from harmful content. The Government is closely monitoring international and industry developments, and on 10 November 2023 Australia joined the governments of France, Belgium, Denmark, Estonia, the Netherlands, Spain and the United Kingdom in a joint statement at the Paris Peace Forum, calling for global initiatives to reinforce the protection of children online.

We also want to make sure children and young people can access age-appropriate consent and respectful relationships education, and are providing this through the Consent and Respectful Relationships Education commitment of $83.5 million over 6 years (2022-23 to 2027-28).

In addition, the eSafety Commissioner has published a range of practical online resources with easy-to-follow advice about how technology and parental control settings can prevent children from accessing online pornography. This information can be found online at www.esafety.gov.au/parents/issues-and-advice/online-porn.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5156 on the responsibility of the banking sector to address scams. Your correspondence was referred to me for response.

In 2022, Australians lost an estimated $3.1 billion to scams. The Government is taking action and provided $86.5 million in the 2023-24 Budget for measures to combat scams and online fraud, including to:
establish a National Anti-Scam Centre (NASC) as a world-leading partnership between regulators, law enforcement and industry to detect, disrupt and prevent scams
establish Australia's first SMS Sender ID Registry, to help prevent scammers imitating trusted industry or government brand names—such as Linkt or myGov—in text message headers
boost work by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission to identify and take down investment scam websites.

The Government has also begun consultation on a proposed framework for tough new industry codes outlining the responsibilities of the private sector relating to scam activity, including the banking sector. These codes will place robust obligations on key sectors to protect consumers from scams.

I encourage consumers who are affected by a scam to report their experience to the Scamwatch website at www.scamwatch.gov.au. These reports help the NASC to identify and monitor scam trends, and are shared with law enforcement, regulators, and industry to help investigate and prosecute scammers.
I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
First Nations Australians
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your letter of 1 August 2023 referring petition EN5182, which requests the House conduct an Inquiry into First Nations funding and associated results of this spending. The following information may assist with this petition. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Indigenous Advancement Strategy (IAS) is the way the Australian Government funds and delivers a range of programs for Indigenous Australians. The IAS is administered by the National Indigenous Australians Agency (NIAA). IAS funding is directed to Closing the Gap and the Productivity Commission provides reporting on the effectiveness of the program. Currently four of the 19 targets on are on track to be met, the full report can be found here: pc.gov.au/closing-the-gap-data/annual-data-report.

The Australian Government is focused on improving the lives of Indigenous Australians. Details of 2023-24 Federal Budget measures to make a practical difference, help close the gap and deliver a better future, working together with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, are available in this media release: niaa.gov.au/news- centre/indigenous-affairs/2023-24-budget-investing-better-future-aboriginal-and-torres-strait- islander-people.

In February 2023, the Commonwealth Government outlined the strategic priorities for Closing the Gap over the following 12 to 18 months as part of our 2023 Implementation Plan, committing $424 million of additional spending. The Implementation Plan can be found online at: niaa.gov.au/resource-centre/indigenous-affairs/commonwealth-closing-gap- implementation-plan-2023. A full appendix of new and existing measures being undertaken by the Commonwealth to support Closing the Gap efforts is on the NIAA website, at niaa.gov.au/ctg-actions.

Program delivery and expenditure by all Australian Government agencies is subject to a range of scrutiny and integrity mechanisms, including through performance audits conducted by the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO). Since 2013, the ANAO has conducted 24 Indigenous-related performance audits and made numerous recommendations to relevant entities. These reports are available on the ANAO website.

The most recent completed performance audit of the National Indigenous Australians Agency focussed on the Agency's management of provider non-compliance and fraud. This report includes 7 recommendations, all of which were accepted by the Agency and are in the process of being implemented.
Thank you again for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Ms Burney
Australian Currency
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5222 on a vote and referendum to unify Australia and New Zealand under one currency treaty.

The Government is not currently considering unifying Australia and New Zealand under one currency treaty. However, Australia supports a strong and unified Pacific family and the important role of Pacific-led organisations, particularly the Pacific Islands Forum, through which we work collaboratively to address shared challenges. The strength of our engagement with countries and people in the Pacific is grounded in deep and longstanding personal, historical and cultural ties.

Pacific labour mobility is central to the Australian Government's commitment to build a stronger Pacific family. The Pacific Australia Labour Mobility (PALM) scheme is an important temporary migration program to address unskilled, low-skilled and semi-skilled labour shortages across rural and regional Australia, and agriculture nationally. The scheme offers Australian employers access to reliable, productive workers from the Pacific and Timor-Leste, and enables these workers to develop skills, earn income and support their families back home.

Through Australia's development program to the Pacific, the Government aims to reduce fiscal distress and help lay the foundation for economic growth. The Government is committed to strengthening the region's climate resilience and climate mitigation objectives and is investing in renewable energy and climate infrastructure projects through the Pacific Climate Infrastructure Financing Partnership. The Australian Government also works through the Pacific Islands Forum Economic Ministers Meetings (FEMM) to develop regional solutions to inflationary pressures in the Pacific region.

In Australia, the Government's economic plan is focused on easing inflation in our economy and providing targeted and responsible cost-of-living relief. Our $23 billion cost-of-living plan helps take some pressure off families by helping with their energy bills, making childcare more affordable, reducing the cost of medicines and making it easier and cheaper to see a doctor. Australian Bureau of Statistics data shows our cost-of- living policies took half of a percentage point off inflation through the year to the September quarter 2023, and Treasury estimates they will take ¾ of a percentage off through the year to June quarter 2024.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Electric Vehicles
Dear Chair

Thank you for referring a copy of petition EN5227 presented to the House of Representatives on 11 September 2023, regarding the banning of electric vehicles from our roads unless owners demonstrate they are not charged from the electricity grid. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government has developed a comprehensive strategy to improve reliability and affordability and reduce emissions from our electricity grid by transitioning it towards 82% renewable energy by 2030. This will be supported by cornerstone policies like our $20 billion Rewiring the Nation Plan to rebuild and modernise Australia's electricity grid to handle more renewable energy, and our expanded Capacity Investment Scheme, which will help unlock cleaner, cheaper, firmed renewable energy.

Australia's first National Electric Vehicle Strategy outlines the environmental, health and cost- of-living benefits of transitioning to EVs. My Department has been tracking the greenhouse gas emissions profiles of different types of vehicles. Even with largely fossil fuel-based electricity generation, the lifecycle emissions of EVs are over 35% lower than combustion engine vehicles. Lifecycle emissions will fall even further to around 70% lower than combustion engine vehicles under the government's plan to achieve 82% renewable electricity by 2030.
These estimates include emissions from vehicle manufacture, operational use and vehicle end- of-life.

We are committed to providing greater choice for Australians to drive cars that are cleaner and cheaper to run. The needs of Australian consumers will remain a key consideration for the Australian Government in the design of future policy to support the decarbonisation of Australia's transport sector.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Disability Parking
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence dated 11 September 2023, concerning petition number EN5243. The petition requests that the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (DDA) be validated to ensure all states and territories of Australia have the proper authority to initiate actions with regard to offenders occupying the designated disability parking bays displaying the International Symbol of Access.
The Australian Government aims to ensure people with disability live in accessible and well-designed communities with opportunity for full inclusion in all aspects of life.
Use of accessible car parking spaces is determined by the Australian Disability Parking Scheme (the ADPS), including the Australian Disability Parking Permit, rather than the DDA.

The Australian Disability Parking Permit is recognised nationally and establishes nationally consistent eligibility criteria and national minimum parking concessions to help reduce the barriers for permit holders when travelling interstate.

State and Territory Governments are responsible for the management of the ADPS. It is an offence in all states and territories to park in a designated disability parking spot without a Disability Parking Permit. Enforcement of such violations are the responsibility of state and territory authorities. Reports of illegal use of a Disability Parking Permit or parking space should be directed to the relevant State or Territory authority.
All enquiries about the ADPS should be directed to the relevant state or territory authority.

The DDA is in place to eliminate discrimination against people with disability as far as possible, and to promote community acceptance of the principle that people with disability have the same fundamental rights as all members of the community.

The DDA provides that direct and indirect discrimination on the basis of disability is unlawful in a broad range of areas of public life, including access to premises and access to goods, services and facilities.
