However, an act that is unlawful under the DDA does not generally constitute an offence, other than in limited circumstances related to victimisation, incitement, advertisements and the provision of data.

Where car parking is provided in or around a building, and the car park is associated with that building, the Disability (Access to Premises—Buildings) Standards 2010, which are supplementary to the DDA, require that accessible car parking spaces must be provided (other than in relation to Class 2 apartment buildings).

The Premises Standards came into effect on 1 May 2011 and apply to new public buildings of certain building classes, e.g. offices, schools, hospitals, hotels, theatres, and new work on existing public buildings of ce1iain building classes that require building approval.

The Premises Standards provide details of the number of accessible car parking spaces required in a car park depending on the classification of the building and based on the ratio to the total number of car parking spaces provided. However, there is nothing to prevent a developer or manager from providing a greater ratio than that required should they wish to do so.

The Minister for Industry and Science, in consultation with the Attorney-General, is required to review the effectiveness of the Premises Standards in achieving their objects every five years. During the most recent review in 2021, participants indicated that the availability of accessible car parking spaces remains a barrier to accessing public buildings. As a result, the 2021 review has recommended the Australian Government lead a regulatory impact analysis on whether current accessible car parking ratios in the Premises Standards are adequate.

The Department of lndustry, Science and Resources is currently implementing actions recommended by the 2021 review in a phased manner. The adequacy of accessible car parking ratios will be considered in conjunction with other regulatory impacts assessments around where automatic doors are used, and the adequacy of dimensions of openings and thoroughfares.
Further information about the Premises Standards and 2021 review can be found at: www.industry.gov.au.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus

subdebateinfo.title: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence

p.span: Physical and Sexual Harassment and Violence
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 enclosing Petition EN5250 regarding criminal justice responses to sexual violence, which requests the House direct the Attorney-General to mandate trauma-informed police training and exams in recruitment, comprehensively ensuring wellbeing. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

As you may be aware, the policing response to the majority of sexual assault related offences is a state and territory responsibility. Training and education within policing agencies remains the responsibility of individual state and territory police forces, under the respective Minister for Police. The Commonwealth support is trauma-informed policing responses, however does not consider it appropriate to mandate such training and exams in recruitment through the Australian Federal Police (AFP). I understand the AFP takes a victim-centric approach in its training and education for the response and investigation of sexual assault related offences. Training content is periodically reviewed, and where required amended, to ensure a best practice approach, particularly in relation to the interviewing of victims and evidence collection.
You and the Petitioner may be interested to know that the Attorney-General's Department (the department) is currently developing a number of measures that seek to:

Enhance law enforcement responses to family, domestic and sexual violence (FDSV) through the development and delivery of a national training package for the use of Commonwealth, state and territory police. This is funded under the National Plan to End Violence Against Women & Children 2022—2032 (National Plan).

Based on recent scoping study consultations, it is anticipated the training will include topics to address the impacts of trauma on FDSV victim-survivors, enhancing police 'soft skills' to provide a more trauma-informed response whilst better understanding victimology.

Deliver FDSV education and training for the justice sector. These activities align with the focus of the National Plan, to ensure responses to FDSV are trauma-informed and appropriate for all people. The department has engaged with the National Judicial College of Australia (NJCA), the Australasian Institute of Judicial Administration (AIJA), the Australian Institute of Family Studies (AIFS), the Law Council of Australia, law societies, relevant FDSV and First Nations organisations, victim-survivors and their advocates to deliver these measures. Measures focused on sexual violence include the following:

AIFS has been engaged to develop and deliver a national foundational educational resource, which will improve knowledge and understanding in the justice sector about the dynamics of sexual assault and its impacts on victims and survivors, and dispel common myths and misconceptions. It will be informed by consultation with a range of key stakeholders.

NJCA has been engaged to develop and deliver a national judicial training program on the nature and impacts of sexual assault, which is expected to commence in early 2024, with two training sessions held per year, and
AIJA has been engaged to deliver a national judicial conference on sexual assault, which is expected to be held in mid-2024.

Strengthen and harmonise sexual assault and consent laws, working closely with States and Territories, in order to improve criminal justice outcomes for victims and survivors in line with the Standing Council of Attorneys-General Work Plan to Strengthen Criminal Justice Responses to Sexual Assault 2022-2027.
Additionally, a new 12-month Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) inquiry into justice responses to sexual violence across Australia will commence in late 2023.

To inform the inquiry's terms of reference, on 23 August 2023, I convened a ministerial level national roundtable on justice responses to sexual violence, alongside the Minister for Women and Minister for Social Services. Participants included victim-survivors, service and advocacy sectors, other expe1is, and relevant Commonwealth, state and territory ministers discussed five key themes across the day: law reform and legal frameworks; supports and services within the justice system; policing; court processes; and alternative and transformative approaches to justice. Outcomes from the roundtable will directly inform the terms of reference for the ALRC inquiry and will drive nation-wide, cross-sector collaboration and the National Plan.

The inquiry will also be informed by other relevant inquiries and reviews at a national level, including the Australian Institute of Criminology's national review of sexual assault and child sexual abuse legislation, and the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs' Committee's inquiry into current and proposed sexual consent laws in Australia. The ALRC inquiry is intending to have a broader focus than these other national pieces of work, by focusing on justice responses to sexual violence beyond criminal law frameworks.

To support the inquiry, the Government is establishing a lived experience expert advisory group to ensure that victims and survivors' voices and lived experiences are centred in justice responses to sexual violence. It is expected to be established by the end of 2023, and run for two years to support the first year of the ALRC inquiry and the Government's response to its recommendations in the second year.

You are likely aware that the Senate referred an inquiry into current and proposed sexual consent laws in Australia to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs References Committee for inquiry and report. Recommendation 10 in the inquiry recommends that 'the Commonwealth Government, through the Police Ministers Council, develops principles to guide ongoing specialist education and training to state and territory law enforcement officers, to ensure culturally appropriate and trauma-informed responses to victim-survivors of sexual assault'. The department is currently finalising the Australian Government response to this, and will consider your Petitioner's recommendations in this process.

The department continues to identify and assess relevant research and work being undertaken outside of government, to inform future measures where appropriate. Through this work, I am aware that in 2024 Deakin University and the University of Tasmania are hosting a Trauma Informed Policing and Law Enforcement Conference which we will monitor the outcomes of with interest.

Thank you again for bringing the Petitioners' request to the Government's attention. I trust this information is of assistance, and outlines a number of key areas the department is working on to recognise and amplify the voices of victims and survivors, with the intent of enhancing the sector's response to FDSV.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Russian Imperial Movement
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding petition number EN5260, which asks the House to designate the Russian Imperial Movement (RIM) as a terrorist organisation under Division 102 of the Criminal Code Act 1995 (the Criminal Code), and sanction the organisation under Australia's autonomous sanctions regime.

Before an organisation can be listed as a terrorist organisation under the Criminal Code, the APP Minister must be satisfied on reasonable grounds that the organisation is either directly or indirectly engaging in, preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering the doing of a terrorist act, or that the organisation advocates the doing of a terrorist act.
In Australia, listing a group as a terrorist organisation does not enliven any additional tools to keep Australians safe, combat violent extremism or counter terrorist threats to national security.
It is the Government's longstanding practice not to comment on whether an organisation is being considered for listing as a terrorist organisation.

Since 18 May 2022, Australia has imposed counter-terrorism financing sanctions on RIM under Part 4 of the Charter of the United Nations Act 1945 (Cth) (COTUNA). Additional sanctions under Australia's autonomous sanctions framework would not impose any further measures against an entity already subject to counter-terrorism financing sanctions under Part 4 of COTUNA.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Consumer Protection: Event Ticketing
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5262, requesting the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) take action to address issues with online queue systems for popular events. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
The Government is committed to ensuring strong protections for Australian consumers.

The Australian Consumer Law (ACL) regulates the conduct of businesses, including ticket sellers. The ACL provides a single consumer protection law operating as a law of the Commonwealth and of each state and territory, and includes:

General protections that create and promote standards of conduct in trade or commerce across the economy, including prohibitions against misleading or deceptive conduct, unconscionable conduct and the use of unfair contract terms; and
Specific protections against certain unfair practices including false or misleading representations, consumer guarantees and product safety provisions.

Enhanced disclosure requirements for ticket resellers were also recently introduced by the Competition and Consumer (Australian Consumer Law—Electronic Ticket Resale Service) Information Standard. However, there are no specific regulations around ticket selling by the primary ticket provider in the ACL, and businesses are generally free to set the terms and conditions of the products they sell.

The ACCC together with state and territory consumer protection regulators, regularly share information on all consumer issues, including issues in the ticketing and events sector. The ACCC expects that ticket sellers should ensure they are prepared with sufficient customer service resources and adequate systems to cope with selling tickets to high demand events.

The ACCC has also published guidance on buying tickets to events. This guidance provides information on relevant consumer rights and guarantees, and the steps consumers may wish to take where an event is cancelled or significantly changed. This resource is available at: https://www.accc.gov.au/consumers/buying- products-and-services/buying-tickets-to-events.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
International Students
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 11 September 2023 enclosing Petition EN5263, with 309 signatures, concerning student work hours, workforce shortages, financial constraints and employer's exploitation. Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention, I apologise for the delay in responding.

The phased introduction of unrestricted work hours over the COVID-19 pandemic was a temporary measure to address critical workforce shortages at that time, given the reduced number of visa holders in Australia with work rights.

The Australian Government recognizes the important contribution that international students make to Australian society. The increase to 48 hours working cap per fortnight for students is equivalent to three days per week, allowing students to gain valuable work experience in Australia while they study. The Government considers 48 hours a fortnight as an appropriate balance between work and study, acknowledging that study is the primary purpose of the Student visa. Students are also able to work unrestricted hours during course breaks.

The number of Working Holiday Maker and Student visa holders in Australia have now returned to pre-pandemic levels. In addition to this, international students already working in the aged care sector as of the Government's announcement on 9 May 2023, have an exemption from the 48 hour per fortnight work limit until 31 December 2023.

I am also pleased to advise that on 21 February 2022, the Ministers for Education and Home Affairs jointly announced the extension of Temporary Graduate visa (485) Post Study work rights. The extension commenced on 1 July 2023, and allows eligible international graduates to work in Australia for an additional two years and subject to annual review. The extension applies to key industries including health, teaching, engineering, agriculture and ICT. Further information can be found at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/temporary-graduate-485.

Work restrictions for Student visa holders are designed to strike a balance between the opportunities for students to undertake limited work, without affecting their studies as the primary purpose of their stay.

To be eligible for a Student visa grant, an applicant must meet all the legislative requirements including, among other things, financial capacity. The purpose of the financial capacity requirement for Student visas is to reduce the risk of international students experiencing financial hardship while in Australia and ensure that international students have adequate financial support for the duration of their studies. Ensuring students have adequate funds to support themselves reduces the risk of vulnerability of students to exploitation in the workplace.

The Australian Government is steadfast in its commitment to address abuse of the migration system and to protect vulnerable community members. The Government has no tolerance for exploitation of vulnerable migrants, and is committed to combatting this abhorrent behaviour.

Student visa holders enjoy the same rights under Australian workplace law as all other employees, including access to the Fair Work Ombudsman (FWO). The Government is committed to ensuring all workers have the opportunity to make a positive contribution to the Australian economy, without fear of exploitation.
Measures to ensure migrant workers have the information they need to understand their workplace rights include:
providing information on workplace rights and entitlements in visa grant letters; and
providing dedicated migrant worker resources and information in multiple languages on the Fair Work Ombudsman (FWO) website.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5263 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Waste Management and Recycling
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5278 on rights of citizens to repair their own goods without hinderance from companies. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

As you may be aware, the Productivity Commission's Right to Repair Inquiry Final Report was tabled in December 2021. The focus of the report was on whether there are barriers to repair that may require a government response. In the keynote address to the 2022 Australian Repair Summit, the Hon Dr Andrew Leigh MP, Assistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury noted there are opportunities to further reduce barriers to repair for products in some markets. The Australian Government wants to pursue reforms that are evidence-based and target sectors where it will be most beneficial. You can read the speech at: https://ministers.treasury.gov.au/ministers/andrew-leigh-2022/speeches/keynote-address-australian-repair- summit-2022-canberra.

I also note the Circular Economy Ministerial Advisory Group has been established to guide Australia's transition to a more circular economy, by 2030. The Advisory Group advises the Australian Government, through the Minister for the Environment and Water, on:
opportunities associated with Australia's circular economy transition (nationally, and within specific sectors)
regulatory, commercial and other barriers to a more circular economy
best practice initiatives that show promise for adoption and/or expansion in Australia
circular economy research, development and innovation needs, and
effective measurement and communication about progress towards Australia's circular economy.
The Advisory Group has finalised its workplan with 7 meetings proposed over 2 years and right to repair may be discussed.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the petition presented to the House of Representatives regarding military assistance to Ukraine. I appreciate Mr Shuttleworth taking the time to raise these important matters.
The Australian Government has repeatedly condemned Russia's unprovoked and illegal invasion of Ukraine and continues to call for its withdrawal from Ukrainian territory.
The Government remains committed to providing military assistance to Ukraine to support its defence.

Australia's military assistance to Ukraine now totals approximately $730 million and includes over 200 vehicles, artillery, ammunition and training for Ukrainian military recruits. Australia has also deployed an E-7A Wedgetail aircraft to Germany in support of multinational efforts to protect a vital gateway of international humanitarian and military assistance to Ukraine.

The Hawkei is not yet accepted into ADF operational service. A combination of an ongoing brakes issues, and immature support and sustainment systems make it unsuitable for gifting to Ukraine at this juncture.
The Government is committed to empowering Ukraine to end this war on its own terms.
Itrust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
Skilled Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 enclosing Petition EN5284, with 12 signatures, concerning a request to provide permanent residence pathways for Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders, if they have at least one year of working in skilled employment or jobs closely related in their field of study.

Subclass 485 visa holders are eligible for a range of skilled visas where they have skilled work experience in Australia. Information about permanent work visas is available on the Department of Home Affairs website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/working-in- australia/permanent-work-visas.

Skilled visa applications are processed according to Australian Government policy priorities, which are outlined in Ministerial Direction No. 100. Ministerial Direction No. 100 prioritises applications where the applicant is outside of Australia, however permanent skilled visa applications are still being processed and visas granted for applicants inside Australia.

You may be aware that on 27 April 2023 the Government released for discussion the Outline of the Government's Migration Strategy {the Outline). The Outline proposes policy shifts to reform our migration system, including providing faster pathways to permanent residence for the skilled migrants and graduates we need. The Government will release its final Migration Strategy later in 2023.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5284 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence to the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP, concerning the petition 'Reducing unreasonably long processing time for offshore partner visa SC309 (EN5288)' which was presented to the Standing Committee on Petitions on 11 September 2023. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Firstly, I acknowledge the mental and financial impacts which may be experienced by Partner (subclass 309) visa applicants who are separated from their partners and other family members in Australia for extended periods while awaiting a decision on their visa application. The Australian Government remains committed to ensuring Partner visas processing backlogs are cleared as quickly as possible.

Concerning published processing times for the Partner (subclass 309) visa, these are available on the Department of Home Affairs website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-processing-times/global-visa-processing-times. Published processing times are periodically updated, usually on a monthly basis, and reflect the processing time for applications decided within the last completed month for each visa subclass. These processing times provide applicants and prospective applicants an indication on timeframe that they might expect for a visa to be processed.
However, as stated on the Department's website they are not a guarantee that an application will be finalised within the published timeframe.

Visa processing times vary depending on a number of factors that may include the quality and completeness of applications, the applicants' responsiveness to requests for information, and the complexity involved in assessing relationship, character, health and security requirements. In addition, checks may be carried out with other Government agencies or overseas entities to verify certain information or claims.

For the Partner (subclass 309) visa, 90 percent of visas finalised in July 2023 were processed in 32 Months, with the median processing time being 10 months. The Department is focused on reducing processing times for all Partner visas. However, as both new and older existing applications are being finalised, processing times may change each month.

Partner (subclass 309) visa applicants may request priority processing of their application where 'compassionate' and 'compelling' circumstances can be demonstrated. To request priority processing, applicants should utilise the Partner Visa Enquiry Form, available on the Department's website at https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/departmental- forms/online-forms/partner-processing-enquiry-form. Requests for priority processing for the Partner (subclass 309) visa on compassionate and compelling grounds are extremely common, particularly from applicants in regions of the world experiencing security and political unrest. Consequently, in order to receive priority processing, the threshold for circumstances presented as compassionate and compelling must be an exception to the daily circumstances faced by the majority of the caseload.

Concerning information available to applicants on the status of their Partner (subclass 309) visa, the Department does not provide status updates upon request, and will only contact visa applicants if and where additional information is required to assess the requirements of the visa, or when the visa application has been finalised. However, visa applicants may access information about the status of their application via IMMI Account, and provide additional information and documentation in support of their application before a decision is reached.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5288 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Medicare
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 concerning petition number EN5302, requesting.an increase in the number of physiotherapy sessions available to people with chronic conditions through Medicare.

The Medicare Benefits Schedule Review Taskforce recommended that more research is needed to develop an appropriate evidence base on patient needs and the appropriate number of services provided by allied health professionals for people with chronic. conditions through Medicare. The Chief Allied Health Officer is progressing work on this recommendation.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Industrial Relations
Dear Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 to the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, Minister for Social Services, regarding Petition (EN5304)—raising concerns regarding the rate of pay and working conditions for Disability Employment Services' consultants. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for reply.

The Government acknowledges the important contribution Disability Employment Services' consultants make to the lives of those they support. The Government funds Disability Employment Service providers to help people with disability, illness or injury find and keep a job.

The Fair Work Act 2009 sets the framework for minimum terms and conditions of employment for employees in the national industrial relations system. Responsibility for setting modern award wages and conditions sits with the independent industrial relations tribunal, the Fair Work Commission.

Applications to vary modern awards can be made by employers, employees or organisations covered by the award, or by an organisation that is entitled to represent the industrial interests of an employer or employee covered by the award.

Beyond modern awards, some employers and employees choose to bargain for enterprise agreements to set pay and conditions under the national system. The Government is working to ensure workers have access to a stronger workplace bargaining system that will help lift wages and improve job security. For instance, the recent reforms in the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Secure Jobs, Better Pay) Act 2022 removed barriers to single-enterprise bargaining and provided more options for business and employees to make multi-enterprise agreements.

The Government has also introduced legislation to close loopholes that some employers use to undermine worker pay and conditions. You can find more information about the Government's workplace relations reforms on the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations website at www.dewr.gov.au/closing-loopholes.
I have copied this letter to the Hon Bill Shorten MP, Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme and Minister for Government Services.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke
Housing
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5307 on Government collaboration on regulation of short-term rentals.

State, territory and local governments have responsibility for regulating short term rentals, such as Airbnb and Stayz. I note some state and local governments are implementing various initiatives with the intent of better balancing the properties available to be long- term rental homes and those used for short-term accommodation.

The Albanese Labor Government understands safe and affordable housing is central to the security and dignity of all Australians. Sadly, many Australians cannot find an affordable place to buy, rising interest rates have been difficult news for those with a mortgage and the rental market is also very tight with low vacancy rates and increasing rents across Australia.

That's why the Albanese Government has committed to an ambitious housing reform agenda which will boost the supply of all housing—more public and social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy.

These housing challenges didn't happen overnight and cannot be solved by one government alone. The Albanese Government is working with the state, territory and local governments to deliver better housing outcomes.
This includes the work being delivered through National Cabinet to provide more secure and affordable housing supply. Significant measures include:

The National Housing Accord that will support planning and zoning reforms, as well as investing $350 million in additional federal funding to deliver 10,000 affordable rental homes over five years from 2024—matched by the state and territories.
Federal funding of $2 billion through the Social Housing Accelerator to deliver thousands of social homes across Australia.

Federal funding of $3 billion through the New Homes Bonus to help incentivise states and territories to build more homes where people need them to meet a new national target of 1.2 million new homes over five years.

The National Housing Infrastructure Facility has been expanded making up to $575 million available to invest in new social and affordable homes. This fund will soon receive a further $1 billion to deliver more social homes.

A $500 million Housing Support Program for initiatives to help kick start housing supply including connecting essential services, amenities to support new housing development or building planning capability.
A National Planning Reform Blueprint with planning, zoning, land release and other measures to improve housing supply and affordability.
A Better Deal for Renters to harmonise and strengthen renters' rights across Australia.
These measures are in addition to the work we have already started.

The $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund (HAFF) has now started and will support 30,000 new social and affordable rental homes over its first five years. The Albanese Government has delivered on its commitment to establish the HAFF and it is the single biggest investment to support social and affordable rental housing in more than a decade.

The National Housing Infrastructure Facility (NHIF) has been expanded making up to $575 million available to invest in social and affordable rental homes, with projects already under construction as a result of this funding. The NHIF will also receive an additional $1 billion in federal funding to support more social housing.
We have delivered the largest increase to Commonwealth Rent Assistance in more than 30 years, with a 15 per cent increase in the maximum rate.
The Government has introduced legislation to deliver the Help to Buy scheme with state and territory governments to help thousands of Australians into home ownership.
Tax incentives have been provided to encourage more build-to-rent developments to boost new supply in the private rental market.
Work to deliver on a new National Housing and Homelessness Plan is underway to identify the short, medium and long-term steps that can be taken to address housing issues in Australia.

Finally, we have also established an interim National Housing Supply and Affordability Council to provide expert advice and an evidence base on how Government can improve housing supply and affordability, and legislation has passed the Parliament to create the Council as a permanent independent body.

As you can see, the Albanese Government's ambitious housing reform agenda is designed to boost supply, increase housing affordability and make positive and practical differences for Australians planning to buy a home.
We are doing this to make sure more Australians have an affordable place to call home.
The Albanese Government has added to its broad housing agenda at every opportunity.
It's a plan we are proud of and a er a decade of little action we are working hard to turn around the housing challenges in Australia today.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Australian Constitution: Freedom of Speech
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5318 seeking a referendum to enshrine freedom of speech in the Constitution.
The Australian Government is not currently proposing any changes to the Constitution in relation to freedom of speech.

I note that while the Australian Constitution does not contain any express right to 'free speech', the High Court has recognised an implied constitutional freedom of communication on government and political matters. This implied freedom can only be limited by laws that both have a purpose which is compatible with the system of representative government, and that are reasonably appropriate and adapted to advance that legitimate object.
In all relevant cases, the courts will interpret legislation having regard to the protection of fundamental common law rights, such as freedom of speech.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for the petition presented to the House of Representatives regarding military assistance to Ukraine. I appreciate Mr Catts taking the time to raise these important issues.
The Australian Government has repeatedly condemned Russia's unprovoked and illegal invasion of Ukraine and continues to call for its withdrawal from Ukrainian territory.
The Government remains committed to providing military assistance to Ukraine to support its defence.
Australia's military assistance to Ukraine now totals approximately $730 million and includes over 200 vehicles, artillery, ammunition, and training for Ukrainian military personnel.
Australia has also deployed an E-7A Wedgetail aircraft to Germany in support of multinational efforts to protect a vital gateway of international humanitarian and military assistance to Ukraine.

I appreciate your request that the Government provide tanks to the Ukrainian Armed Forces. The Government is considering options for further military assistance to Ukraine. We will continue to tailor our support to Ukraine's needs and complement the efforts of our partners.
The Government is committed to empowering Ukraine to end this war on its own terms. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Marles
First Nations Australians
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 12 September 2023 referring Petition EN5324 about a detailed financial analysis of tax payer funded Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander programs.

The Commonwealth Government is currently considering future approaches to reporting on the levels and patterns of government expenditure on services relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

The Indigenous Advancement Strategy (IAS) is the way the Australian Government funds and delivers a range of programs for Indigenous Australians. The IAS is administered by the National Indigenous Australians Agency. IAS funding is directed to Closing the Gap and the Productivity Commission provides reporting on the effectiveness of the program. Currently four of the 19 targets on are on track to be met, the full report can be found here: pc.gov.au/closing-the-gap-data/annual-data-report. The Australian Government is focused on improving the lives of Indigenous Australians.

Details of 2023-24 Federal Budget measures to make a practical difference, help close the gap and deliver a better future, working together with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, are available in this media release: niaa.gov.au/news- centre/indigenous-affairs/2023-24-budget-investing-better-future-aboriginal-and-torres-strait- islander-people.

In February 2023, the Commonwealth Government outlined the strategic priorities for Closing the Gap over the following 12 to 18 months as part of our 2023 Implementation Plan, committing $424 million of additional spending. The Implementation Plan can be found online at: niaa.gov.au/resource-centre/indigenous-affairs/commonwealth-closing-gap- implementation-plan-2023. A full appendix of new and existing measures being undertaken by the Commonwealth to support Closing the Gap efforts is on the NIAA website, at niaa.gov.au/ctg-actions.

Program delivery and expenditure by all Australian Government agencies is subject to a range of scrutiny and integrity mechanisms, including through performance audits conducted by the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO). Since 2013, the ANAO has conducted 24 Indigenous-related performance audits and made numerous recommendations to relevant entities.

These reports are available on the ANAO website. The most recent completed performance audit of the National Indigenous Australians Agency focussed on the Agency's management of provider non-compliance and fraud. This report includes 7 recommendations, all of which were accepted by the Agency and are in the process of being implemented.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Ms Burney
Defence Personnel
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding Petition EN5328 requesting the House extend the Defence Reparation Scheme.
The Albanese government acknowledges the significant contribution of Defence members and veterans to protecting the Australian people, Australia and its interests.

The Commonwealth Ombudsman is an independent statutory officer to whom Parliament has given a range of functions including as the Defence Force Ombudsman. From 2016, the functions of the Defence Force Ombudsman have included taking appropriate action to respond to reports of sexual abuse, serious physical abuse and serious bullying or harassment within Defence. Such actions can include facilitating counselling or restorative engagement, or making a recommendation to the Department of Defence in relation to a report of abuse.

The Defence Force Ombudsman's functions were expanded following recommendations in the 2016 final report of the Defence Abuse Response Taskforce (DART) that processes should be implemented to enable Defence members and veterans to continue to have their complaints responded to appropriately following the conclusion of the DART. The DART, which operated from November 2012 to March 2016, was itself established to implement recommendations from a review by the law film, DLA Piper, into allegations of sexual and other abuse in Defence, which lasted from April 2011 to June 2013. The DART was able to make reparation payments to complainants and at its conclusion had made $66.63 million in reparation payments to 1,723 complainants.

In December 2017, the Ombudsman Amendment (Functions of the Defence Force Ombudsman) Regulations 2017 amended the Ombudsman Regulations 2017 to establish the Defence Reparation Scheme. The Defence Reparation Scheme provided the Defence Force Ombudsman with an additional option when responding to reports of abuse, namely the discretion to recommend that the Defence Secretary make reparation payments of up to $50,000. In December 2020, the Ombudsman Regulations 2017 were further amended to extend the end date for reports of abuse, which would be eligible to receive a reparation payment, to 30 June 2022. Amendments also provided that a person could provide the Defence Force Ombudsman with written notice of an intention to make a report on or before 30 June 2022, and then make the actual report on or before 30 June 2023. These timeframes were intended to bring finality to the administration of reparation payments and bring a degree of financial certainty to the Commonwealth.

As at 31 October 2023, $84.13 million in payments to 2,026 repartees have been made under the Scheme. Work on finalising approximately 2,000 of the remaining reports under the Scheme continues and it is anticipated all payments under the Scheme will be finalised, at an estimated cost of $130 million, by the end of calendar year 2025.

Since the commencement of the Scheme in 2017, and following the earlier work of the DART, the Defence Force Ombudsman has undertaken the following public awareness campaigns to inform the community of the existence of the Scheme and timeframes. For example:

In early 2017, a campaign was conducted to promote the expansion of the Defence Force Ombudsman's functions to include taking appropriate action to respond to reports of abuse from serving and former Defence members, and civilians deployed on Defence operations (press, radio and social media).

In late 2017, a campaign was conducted to advise the expansion of the Defence Force Ombudsman's options to include recommending that Defence make a reparation payment in ce1iain circumstances (press and Facebook).

In April 2021, a campaign was conducted to advise of the extension of the Scheme deadline from 30 June 2021 to allow a fu1iher 12 months to make contact with the Defence Force Ombudsman (social media and mail-outs).

In April 2022, a further campaign was conducted to advise the final deadline for reports, and in particular, the 'Intent to Report' deadline of 30 June 2022 and the final deadline for reports of 30 June 2023 (press and mail-outs).
Throughout 2023, several mail-out campaigns were conducted to reach out to people who had lodged an 'Intent to Report but not the report itself.

In addition to the above public awareness campaigns undertaken by the Defence Force Ombudsman, the extension of the Scheme was advertised on the Department of Defence website in April 2021 and the Department of Veterans' Affairs website in November 2021.

Reports of abuse received after 30 June 2022, or after 30 June 2023 if an intent to report had been lodged with the Defence Force Ombudsman, are no longer eligible for a reparation payment recommendation. However, Defence members and veterans may continue to make complaints of sexual abuse, serious physical abuse and serious bullying and harassment within Defence to the Defence Force Ombudsman. The Defence Force Ombudsman's functions continue to include taking appropriate action to respond to such complaints, and the options available still include facilitating counselling or a restorative engagement conference.

If a person's complaint of abuse is assessed as being within the Defence Force Ombudsman's jurisdiction, the person is eligible to participate in the Defence Force Ombudsman's restorative engagement program. This program is designed to support people to tell their personal experience of abuse to a senior representative from Defence in a private facilitated meeting called a restorative engagement conference. The conference also gives Defence the opportunity to acknowledge and respond to the person's individual story of abuse.

The Defence Force Ombudsman can also facilitate a referral to counselling with Open Arms-Veterans & Families Counselling, a service which provides free and confidential nation-wide counselling and support for all current and former members of Defence who have at least one day continuous full-time service.

In addition, the Defence Force Ombudsman, including in their capacity as Commonwealth Ombudsman, can also make recommendations generally to Defence about an individual complaint or about a matter relating more broadly to complaints.
Information about making a complaint of abuse within Defence is available on the Commonwealth Ombudsman's website at https://www.ombudsman.gov.au/complaints/defence-force-complaints/reporting-abuse.
A number of other avenues are available for Defence members and veterans to seek redress for abuse experienced within Defence:

Litigation: Defence members and veterans can seek redress for abuse experienced in Defence through litigation. A person may engage an independent law from and initiate a common law legal claim, which may result in compensation and/or mediation.

National Redress Scheme: The National Redress Scheme, administered by Services Australia, was established in response to recommendations made by the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse. Defence is one of several participating institutions in this Scheme and payments of up to $150,000 may be made to survivors who were under the age of 18 at the time of the abuse.

Non-scheme Restorative Engagement: In addition to Ombudsman-led, Defence facilitated, restorative engagement activities, Defence also independently conducts similar restorative engagement activities for non-Ombudsman related abuse rep01ts. The Defence Restorative Engagement Program was introduced under Joint Secretary I Chief of Defence Force Directive 11/2017—Defence Participation in the Defence Force Ombudsman Restorative Engagement Program. While primarily related to the Defence Force Ombudsman's Restorative Engagement activities under the Defence Reparation Scheme, the Program also provides for restorative engagement activities to occur in cases refe1Ted via the National Redress Scheme, and referrals from Defence's Dispute Resolution and Litigation division. Cases need not have originated from any of the aforementioned schemes. Defence routinely receives complex case referrals from other avenues where a restorative engagement activity is assessed by the refe1ring agency as potentially of benefit to a member or veteran. Referring agencies include but are not limited to: Single Service Headquarters, the Office of the Inspector General-ADP, Defence's Sexual Misconduct Prevention and Response Office, the Ombudsman's Office (when not within the jurisdiction of the Defence Reparation Scheme), and even Ministerial referral.

Australian Defence Medal applications: Defence's Directorate of Honours and Awards assesses applications from veterans for the Australian Defence Medal where mistreatment may be a significant contributing factor to a person's separation from the Defence Force. The Australian Defence Medal Regulations 2006, provide for the awarding of the Australian Defence Medal where a former member of the Defence Force who, after 3 September 1945, has given qualifying service that is efficient service for a period or periods that total less than four years, being service that the member was unable to continue for reasons, including that the member ceased service in the Permanent Force or the Reserves of the Defence Force and mistreatment by a member of the Defence Force or an employee in the Department of Defence was a significant contributing factor.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5329 on access financial services. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Financial services providers must comply with legislative requirements to verify an individual's identity and beneficial ownership. These requirements are outlined in the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Rules Instrument 2007 (AML/CTF rule). The requirements are designed to assist banks to identify, mitigate and manage the money laundering and terrorism financing risks that they reasonably face.

The Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC) regulates bank compliance with the AML/CTF rule. The bank must be reasonably satisfied that an individual customer is who they claim to be and a customer who is not an individual (such as a company, association or trust) is a real entity and the details of its beneficial owners are known. Ultimately, banks make commercial decisions in regards to whom they provide banking services, taking account of the risks they face.

In relation to payment methods, while Australian banknotes and coins have legal tender status, a refusal to accept legal tender banknotes or coins is not unlawful. Providers of goods and services can specify what forms of payment they will accept prior to entering into a transaction. If a provider specifies other means of payment prior to the transaction, then there is no obligation for legal tender banknotes or coins to be accepted as payment.

In today's evolving banking landscape, there has been a noticeable shift towards telephone, online, and mobile app banking. These changes have resulted in a decrease in over-the-counter transactions, with more people turning to online banking options. This shift reflects changing consumer preferences and the influence of new technologies, but it has also led to banks reducing their branch networks.
The Government is concerned about the impact these changes have on communities in need of face-to-face banking services, as well as small businesses that rely on access to deposit and withdraw cash.

On 7 June 2023, the Government released its the 'Strategic Plan for Australia's Payments System', which details the policy priorities and objectives of the Government in relation to payments. One of the initiatives in the plan was 'Maintaining adequate access to cash'. As part of this, the Government will work with relevant agencies across the public sector and with industry to ensure that Australia has a sustainable cash distribution network that maintains adequate access to cash.

Finally, the Australian Government's response to the Privacy Act Review Report agrees in-principle that individuals should have greater transparency and control over their personal information. This includes through the creation of a new individual right under the Privacy Act 1988 enabling them to require a regulated entity to delete or de-identify personal information through a right to erasure. This agreement is subject to further engagement with regulated entities and a comprehensive impact analysis to ensure the right balance can be struck between privacy benefits for Australians and other impacts on regulated entities.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice

p.span: Australian Constitution: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 enclosing petition number EN5331 about the 14 October 2023 referendum.

On Saturday, 14 October 2023, Australians voted in an historic referendum about whether to change the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia by establishing a body called the Aboriginal and Torres Strait lslander Voice. This was the form of constitutional recognition sought by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

The referendum was not carried. The Government respects the decision of the Australian people and the democratic process that delivered it. The outcome of the vote does not affect work already underway across governments to create better outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

It does not affect the Government's commitment to reconciliation. The Government remains committed to listening and working in partnership with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities to achieve better outcomes. The National Agreement on Closing the Gap and other initiatives will continue to ensure practical progress in Indigenous health, education, employment and housing. The Government will make further announcements about its renewed commitment to Closing the Gap in the months ahead.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5332, which asks to halt the proposal of a windfarm off the coast of Newcastle and Port Stephens.

The Australian Government knows how important our ocean environments are to our culture, and our livelihoods. Australia's oceans are also home to some of the best offshore wind resources in the world. Harnessing this can help us provide emissions-free power to our communities for generations to come.

We are backing the offshore wind industry because it will pave the way for energy and job security. But in developing this industry, we know how important it is to balance the impact on industries and our environment.

On 12 July 2023, I declared an area offshore of the Hunter, New South Wales as suitable for the development of offshore renewable energy infrastructure. The declaration followed an extensive public consultation process that took place from 23 February to 28 April 2023.

The Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water undertook consultation from 23 February to 28 April 2023 to listen to the views of the community. The consultation was undertaken across the Port Stephens, Newcastle, Lake Macquarie and Central Coast regions using the following methods:
Advertising through newspapers, radio, and social media
Letterbox drop of flyers encouraging the community to make submissions
Detailed information about the proposal and how to make a submission on the department's website
Targeted stakeholder meetings with federal, state and local government agencies, industry, business, and community groups

Seven community drop-in sessions from 6 March to 9 March 2023 in Wamberal, Doyalson, Swansea, Newcastle, Bar Beach, Nelson Bay, and Hawks Nest to answer questions and to encourage the community to make submissions.

I received nearly 2,000 submissions from community members, local organisations and industries. Many submissions raised concerns on visual amenity, the safe management of shipping to and from the Port of Newcastle, and environmental matters, such as the potential impacts on marine life.
After considering the feedback, I decided on a smaller footprint than the originally proposed zone—balancing the views of the local community, local industries and marine users.

Listening to feedback and ensuring the zone can coexist alongside whale migration, bird and sea life, and our shipping industry, the zone has been moved to at least 20 km offshore and was reduced in area size by about a third. To help manage these concerns, I will place conditions on future feasibility licence holders requiring consultation with specific groups and users of the area. I also limited the height of turbines to a maximum of 260 metres.

This strikes an appropriate balance between harnessing the job and economic opportunities of establishing offshore wind in the Hunter, while maintaining the environmental protections that make this area such a unique and vibrant part of Australia.

Wind farm developers have applied for feasibility licences in the Hunter offshore wind zone, and these applications are now under review. Developers will need to specify how their proposed plans benefit local industry and the local economy.

Once granted feasibility licences, developers must undertake detailed assessments of their planned wind farm's impact on marine users and the environment, and have their projects approved under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999(EPBC Act). Offshore wind farm proposals that do not get EPBC Act approval will not proceed to construction.

During the feasibility licence stage, individual developers will work with communities and other marine users, such as the fishing industry, to refine their project proposals to ensure existing users can continue to use Australia's oceans, sharing the space with this new industry. It is also at this stage that specific project details, such as the number of turbines, will be determined.

Feasibility licence holders will be required to seek feedback on their proposed projects and must demonstrate, to the satisfaction of the Offshore Infrastructure Regulator, how they will share the area with existing users.

The Government is currently developing regulations that will set out the details and requirements of management plans to be developed in the feasibility stage, including the requirement for licence holders to undertake further consultation.

Restrictions may be placed around specific infrastructure to manage safety, as is the case with other marine infrastructure to ensure the safety of offshore workers and other users of the marine environment, and to protect vessels and the infrastructure from damage, as well as when any approved offshore wind projects are under construction to ensure safety for marine users and construction workers. However this will be done in consultation with existing sea users through management plans.

The exact details of these restricted areas will be determined on a project-by-project basis. Even once offshore wind farms become operational, safety zones can only extend to a maximum of 500 metres around individual turbines or substations. There will be no exclusion zones put in place around the whole of a wind farm, and recreational fishers will be free to fish between turbines.

The Hunter offshore wind zone opens the door for a new industry in the Hunter that could create over 3,000 construction jobs and another 1,560 ongoing jobs for the region and be a boost for the local economy. The Government expects projects to deliver for local communities and meet community expectations, and projects will be allowed to progress on that basis.
Thank you again for bringing these concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 11 September 2023 regarding petition EN5334, to cease any further progress on a proposed Port Stephens offshore wind zone and review the community consultation process.

The Government expects projects to deliver for local communities and meet community expectations, and projects will be allowed to progress on that basis.
Thank you again for bringing these concerns to my attention.
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Human Rights: India
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for sharing Petition EN5372 on reports of acts of violence and hate speech against Muslims and diminishing press freedom in India; and Petition EN5392 on reports of violence in Manipur and the persecution of Christians and other minorities in India.

The Australian Government values diversity, inclusion and human dignity, and our foreign policy must be an accurate and authentic reflection of our values and interests. We expect all countries to promote, protect and respect human rights. Australia continues to advocate for press freedom and support efforts to address religious, sexual and gender-based violence.

The Australian Government regularly engages with the Indian Government on human rights; India understands our strong position on such matters. When Australia and India have concerns with one another, we raise those concerns directly. Australia has expressed our concerns about freedom of expression and about ethnic and gender-based violence in Manipur to India.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Long COVID
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding petition EN5373 and Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) access to antiviral treatments for Long COVID.

The Australian Government recognises that some people have experienced a prolonged illness with persistent symptoms or post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 after infection with SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. This is commonly referred to as Long COVID.

The Government is committed to supporting a strong healthcare system that will deliver effective patient-centred care for people diagnosed with this condition, and the best possible health and wellbeing outcomes for patients. People experiencing Long COVID can access a range of existing supports through their GP and broader primary care arrangements, such as subsidised access to allied health services through Medical Benefits Chronic Disease Management items. Some people may also require other non-GP specialist input or integrated multidisciplinary team-based care. Additional information on care and treatment for Long COVID is available at www.health.gov.au/topics/covid-19/long-covid.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has granted provisional approval for nirmatrelvir and ritonavir (Paxlovid) and molnupiravir (Lagevrio) for the acute treatment of COVID-19, in adults who do not require initiation of oxygen due to COVID-19, and who are at increased risk for hospitalisation or death.

To date, there are no medications registered in Australia for the treatment or prevention of Long COVID. While there is evidence that treatment of COVID infections with antivirals may -reduce the onset of Long COVID, there is no conclusive evidence that it can prevent relapse of existing Long COVID.

Paxlovid and Lagevrio are both currently listed on the PBS for the treatment of acute COVID-19 for patients at increased risk of developing severe COVID-19, as recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). You may be interested to know that people 18 years or older can access PBS subsidised Paxlovid and Lagevrio if they have been previously hospitalised from COVID-19 and are re-infected. Further information about the eligibility criteria, is available at www.pbs.gov.au and searching by drug or brand name.

The current PBS listings reflect the evidence that has been submitted to the PBAC to date. Under legislation, the Government cannot list a new medicine on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of its listing. Similarly, the Government relies on the advice of the PBAC when considering changes to the circumstances under which existing PBS medicines are listed.

Paxlovid and Lagevrio have not been considered for PBS listing for the treatment of Long COVID. Generally, medicines are not made available on the PBS to treat conditions for which they have not been approved by the TGA. Extending the TGA approved indications for COVID antivirals to include a specific rationale for use to prevent relapse of Long COVID would require supporting data to be submitted for evaluation. The PBAC's consideration is usually initiated when the pharmaceutical company responsible for a specific medicine applies to the PBAC. The Government cannot compel companies to apply to the TGA or the PBAC.

You may be aware that in September 2022, the House Standing Committee on Health, Aged Care and Sport's (Committee) commenced an Inquiry into Long COVID and Repeated COVID Infections (Inquiry). On 19 April 2023, the Committee's final report to the Inquiry was tabled in Parliament. Within its final recommendations, the Committee recommended the PBAC regularly review the benefits of antiviral treatments for COVID-19 in accordance with emerging research with a view to expanding the list of groups eligible to access these treatments through the PBS. More information including the final report, is available at:
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary Business/Committees/House/Health Aged Care and Sport/LongandrepeatedCOVID/Report.

As an initial response to the findings from the Inquiry, the Government announced a $50 million investment from the Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF) for research into Long COVID. This research funding will help improve our knowledge of Long COVID and generate evidence to inform policy and clinical guidance, improve health outcomes and increase awareness of the condition in the community. The Department of Health and Aged Care has developed a National Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID-19 Plan to provide a framework for the Commonwealth health portfolio's response to Long COVID in Australia. Additional information is available at www.health.gov.au/resources/publications using the search term 'MRFF Post-Acute Sequelae of COVID-19 Research Plan'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Skilled Migration
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 to the Hon Andrew Giles MP, Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, regarding petition number EN5377 on the timeliness of VETASSESS' skills assessment services. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for reply.

As the Minister for Skills and Training, I approve relevant assessing authorities to undertake skills assessments for migration. VETASSESS, one of 39 assessing authorities, is approved to assess 341 occupations on the Skilled Migration Occupation Lists.

While assessing authorities are responsible for setting their own assessment standards, processes, fees and timeframes, the Australian Government is committed to ensuring fair, timely and quality skills assessments that meet the needs of both employers and migrants.

In line with findings from the Review of the Migration System, the Government is working to improve the accountability, transparency, and integrity of skills assessments through enhanced assurance and new standards for assessing authorities, including VETASSESS.

On 11 September 2023, the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations released the Draft Best Practice Principles and Standards for Skilled Migration Assessing Authorities public discussion paper to underpin a new assurance framework. Submissions closed on 31 October and will inform the design of new best-practice standards. The framework is expected to be implemented by mid-2024.
I thank you for bringing this matter to my attention, and trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Skills and Training, Mr O'Connor
Diabetes
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding Petition EN5378—Australian Government subsidy of i-Port injection devices through the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS).
The Australian Government is committed to supporting Australians with diabetes and their families.

The Government provides considerable financial support to people with diabetes through the subsidy of essential medicines, like insulin, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme {PBS) and other diabetes-related products, like blood glucose test strips, through the NDSS.
In 2022-23, PBS expenditure on medicines for diabetes was $869 million and expenditure on products for diabetes supplied through the NDSS was over $282 million.

The NDSS provides subsidised syringes and needles, blood glucose test strips, urine ketone test strips, continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) products and insulin pump consumables to people with diabetes. It also provides educational and information services to assist in the best use of products and self-management of diabetes.
For a new product type, such as the i-Port product, to be included on the NDSS, the product sponsor would need to make an application to the Department of Health and Aged Care.

Applications for listing of new product types, that are not within an existing product category on the NDSS Product Schedule, may be considered by the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC), as the designated Health Technology Assessment body for diabetes-related products seeking subsidisation under the NDSS. More information about the MSAC can be found online at www.msac.gov.au.
Any decision to fund a new product type is a decision for Government and would need to be considered through the Federal Budget process.
Further information about the NOSS, including the range of products currently subsidised under the scheme, is available at www.ndss.com.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Veterans
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding Petition EN5380, which was presented to the House of Representatives on 16 October 2023.

I have sought advice from the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) on this matter. DVA has advised that the 'Medical Adviser opinion' wording in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) determination letters was removed in 2020, and the process has been updated to include reference to Medical Advisers only when advice has actually been sought.

The issue at hand relates to the inclusion of incorrect standard wording in letter templates and does not impact on the evidence received or used in the investigation, nor the subsequent decisions made.

In effect, a claim was able to be determined in those cases with evidence available to DVA delegates, without the need for advice from a Medical Adviser. The fact that advice from a Medical Adviser may have been referenced in some cases does not change the validity of the decision in any way, as the same decision would have been made regardless of whether the problematic wording auto-populated or not.
Any veterans who feel they have been impacted are entitled to appeal the decision through DVA's appeal process, by requesting that a review be conducted by the Veterans' Review Board.
DVA continues to focus on delivering business improvements to better support the veteran community.
Thank you for providing me with Petition EN5380. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours faithfully,
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Keogh
Food Additives: Folate
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 enclosing petition EN5381 regarding a petition to change the food regulations to fortify foods with folate instead of folic acid.

The request asks the House of Representatives to put forward regulations that require foods to use natural folate instead of folic acid in the mandatory fortification of foods in Australia as there is concern folic acid may be detrimental to the health of those with a variant of the methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) gene.

Folate is a B vitamin and is considered an essential nutrient. It is obtained through the diet from dietary sources such as lentils and dark green leafy vegetables, in fortified foods such as bread or can be taken in the form of a supplement. Folate is a general term referring to a group of chemical forms that occur naturally. Folic acid refers to a group of chemical forms used to fortify foods or in dietary supplements.

The MTHFR gene is involved in the production of the MTHFR protein, which helps the body process folate into a form the body can use. While those with a variant of this gene may accumulate less blood folate when consuming the same amount of folic acid as those without the MTHFR gene variant, there is insufficient evidence to suggest folic acid is toxic to those with the variant. Evidence suggests those with the MTHFR gene variation can process all types of folate, including folic acid, arid generally do not experience health problems if they consume enough folate.

Folate is crucial in pregnancy as it is involved in the development of the neural tube, which develops and fuses during the third and fourth weeks of pregnancy. The neural tube is responsible for the development of the brain and spine. Lacking folate while pregnant can lead to neural tube defects (NTDs), where the neural tube does not fuse completely. Folic acid is proven to reduce the risk of NTDs. Mandatory fortification of bread flours was introduced in 2009 in Australia to reduce incidence of NTDs. Monitoring has shown there has been a significant decrease in the prevalence of NTDs since then. Regardless of the presence of the MTHFR gene variant, adequate intake of folic acid has been shown to protect against NTDs during pregnancy ana may also reduce the risk of cleft lip and palate.

The safety of folic acid in mandatory fortification has been extensively monitored since 2009. No harmful effects have been associated with the amounts of dietary folate consumed in foods or fortified foods. Folic acid is considered safe to consume by Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ), the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, and the National Health and Medical Research Council and is an important part of Australians' diets.

FSANZ is the independent statutory authority responsible for the development and maintenance of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (Code), which sets out legal requirements for food produced or imported for sale in Australia and New Zealand. The Code permits 2 chemical forms of folic acid to be added to food including bread. The Code can be changed through an application or a proposal. Applications to change the Code to permit additional chemical forms of folic acid can be made by companies or members of the public.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding the online petition EN5383—Division of People.

Australia is founded on the rule of law and has a strong tradition of respect for the rights and freedoms of every individual. In addition, Australia is a party to the seven core United Nations treaties that protect human rights. Human rights are recognised and protected across Australia through a range of laws at the federal and state and territory levels, the Australian Constitution, and the common law.

The Australian Government is committed to protecting and promoting traditional rights and freedoms, including freedom of speech, opinion, religion, association and movement. These rights and freedoms are protected by the common law principle that legislation should not infringe fundamental rights and freedoms unless the legislation expresses a clear intention to do so and the infringement is reasonable.

The Government also believes all Australians have the right to live their lives free from discrimination. Commonwealth anti-discrimination laws make it unlawful to discriminate on the basis of a number of protected attributes including age, disability, race, sex, intersex status, gender identity and sexual orientation in certain areas of public life, including education and employment.

The Government has referred Australia's Human Rights Framework to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights (the Committee) for review and report by March 2024. The Committee will consider whether the Framework remains fit for purpose and if improvements can be made. The Government will consider the Committee's recommendations in due course.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
COVID-19: Response
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 referring a copy of petition number EN5385.

On 21 September 2023, the Prime Minister the Hon Anthony Albanese MP announced an independent inquiry into Australia's response to the COVID-19 pandemic and appointed an Independent Panel of three eminent people, with extensive experience across public health, health, social care, government and economics, to conduct the inquiry. Members of the Independent Panel have committed to engaging broadly and openly to ensure that the inquiry draws on diverse experience and perspectives—including individuals, community groups, unions, businesses, peak bodies and experts across a range of fields.

The inquiry will review the Commonwealth Government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic and make recommendations to improve response measures in the event of future pandemics. It will consider opportunities for systems to more effectively anticipate, adapt and respond to pandemics in areas of Commonwealth Government responsibility.
Specific areas of review may include, but are not limited to:

Governance including the role of the Commonwealth Government, responsibilities of state and territory governments, national governance mechanisms (such as National Cabinet, the National Coordination Mechanism and the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee) and advisory bodies supporting responses to COVID-19.
Key health response measures (for example across COVID-19 vaccinations and treatments, key medical supplies such as personal protective equipment, quarantine facilities, and public health messaging).
Broader health supports for people impacted by COVID-19 and/or lockdowns (for example mental health and suicide prevention supports, and access to screening and other preventive health measures).

International policies to support Australians at home and abroad (including with regard to international border closures, and securing vaccine supply deals with international partners for domestic use in Australia).
Support for industry and businesses (for example responding to supply chain and transport issues, addressing labour shortages, and support for specific industries).
Financial support for individuals (including income support payments).

Community supports (across early childhood education and care, higher education, housing and homelessness measures, family and domestic violence measures in areas of Commonwealth Government responsibility).

Mechanisms to better target future responses to the needs of particular populations (including across genders, age groups, socio-economic status, geographic location, people with disability, First Nations peoples and communities and people from culturally and linguistically diverse communities).

The inquiry will consider the findings of previous relevant inquiries and reviews and identify knowledge gaps for further investigation. It will also consider the global experience and lessons learnt from other countries in order to improve response measures in the event of future global pandemics.
The inquiry's final report will be delivered by 30 September 2024.

More information about the Inquiry, including about how to engage in its public consultation processes, can be found on its webpage: www.pmc.gov.au/domestic-policy/commonwealth- government-covid-19-response-inquiry.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding petition EN5394 which asks to reject any proposal to declare an area suitable for offshore wind off the coast of Port MacDonnell, South Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.
