The Australian Government knows how important our ocean environments are to our culture, and our livelihoods. Australia's oceans are also home to some of the best offshore wind resources in the world. Harnessing this can help us provide emissions-free power to our communities for generations to come.

We are backing the offshore wind industry because it will pave the way for energy and job security. But in developing this industry, we know how important it is to balance the impact on industries and our environment.

On 28 June 2023, I proposed an area of the Southern Ocean offshore from Warnambool in Victoria to Port MacDonnell in South Australia as potentially suitable for the development of offshore renewable energy infrastructure.

The Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water undertook consultation from 28 June to 31 August 2023 to listen to the views of the community. The consultation was undertaken across the Warnambool, Port Fairy, Portland regions in Victoria and the Mount Gambier and Port MacDonnell regions in South Australia using the following methods:
Advertising through newspapers, radio, and social media
Letterbox drop of over 33,000 flyers encouraging the community to make submissions
Detailed information about the proposal and how to make a submission on the department's website
Targeted meetings with federal, state and local government agencies, industry, business, First Nation and community groups

Five community information sessions from 1 to 3 August 2023 in Warnambool, Port Fairy, Portland, Mount Gambier and Port MacDonnell to answer questions and to encourage the community to make submissions.

I received nearly 3,285 submissions from community members, local organisations and industries. Many submissions raised concerns on visual amenity, commercial and recreational fishing, and environmental matters, such as potential impacts on marine life.

I will be giving careful consideration to the issues raised in submissions before making a decision to declare all, part or none of the area. I want to ensure that the region is able to share in the job and economic opportunities of establishing offshore wind in Australia, without sacrificing existing industries that already use our oceans, while also maintaining the environmental protections that make this area such a unique and vibrant part of Australia.
If I declare an area, wind farm developers will be invited to apply for feasibility licences. Developers will need to specify how their proposed plans benefit local industry and the local economy.

Once granted feasibility licences, developers must undertake detailed assessments of their planned wind farm's impact on marine users and the environment, and have their projects approved under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). Offshore wind farm proposals that do not get EPBC Act approval will not proceed to construction.

During the feasibility licence stage, individual developers will work with communities and other marine users, such as the fishing industry, to refine their project proposals to ensure existing users can continue to use Australia's oceans, sharing the space with this new industry. It is also at this stage that specific project details, such as the number of turbines, will be determined.

Feasibility licence holders will be required to seek feedback on their proposed projects and must demonstrate, to the satisfaction of the Offshore Infrastructure Regulator, how they will share the area with existing users.

The government is currently developing regulations that will set out the details and requirements of management plans to be developed in the feasibility stage, including the requirement for licence holders to undertake further consultation.
Thank you again for bringing these concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Multiculturalism: Pasifika
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 enclosing Petition EN5395, with 34 signatures, concerning the creation of Pacific Island Cultural hubs.

Australia is one of the most successful multicultural societies in the world. Our Pacific Islander communities are part of our vibrant multicultural society, and I recognise and welcome their positive contribution to our society.

The Department of Home Affairs' Community Liaison Officer (CLO) network actively engages with the diverse Pacific communities in Australia, including through two dedicated Pasifika CLO positions: one in Queensland and one in New South Wales. There are about 40 CLOs around Australia who also engage with Pasifika Australian communities. Between 1 October 2022 and 30 September 2023, CLOs conducted more than 430 engagements with Pasifika Australian communities and with other related stakeholders. It is worth noting that during some of these engagements, interests of multiple Pasifika Australian communities were discussed or represented.

In regards to this proposal, the Australian Government is currently focused on progressing the Multicultural Framework Review. This is considering strategies to promote multiculturalism, social cohesion and inclusion, and reviewing the effectiveness of government services designed to support multicultural Australia. Further information about the Review is available on the Department's website at: https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/about-us/our-portfolios/multicultural-framework-review/.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5395 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Workplace Relations
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding petition number EN5396 regarding the provision of menstrual leave. This petition asks that the House of Representatives support the introduction of a mandatory 10 days of paid menstrual leave, in addition to 10 days of personal/carer's leave, for all working women in Australia.

The Australian-Government recognises that menopause and-reproductive health issues (menstrual-related pain including endometriosis and abnormal uterine bleeding, preventative reproductive health care, fertility treatment) may affect women's experience of and participation in the workforce. The Office for Women is working with stakeholders across government and the private sector to gain a fuller understanding of these impacts and how accommodations can be applied to a wide range of workplaces, both in the public and private sectors.

A recent Senate inquiry report 'Ending the Postcode Lottery—Addressing barriers to sexual, maternity and reproductive health care in Australia', recommended the Government consider commissioning research and policy responses on the impact of reproductive health on women's participation in the workforce and the adequacy of existing leave entitlements under the National Employment Standards. A Government response to the full report is being led by the Department of Health and Aged Care.

In addition, on 6 November 2023, the Senate referred an inquiry into the issues related to menopause and perimenopause to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee for inquiry and report by 10 September 2024. Further information on this inquiry can be found at www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate/Community_Affairs/Menopause.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke

subdebateinfo.title: Consulate-General of the Russian Federation: New South Wales

p.span: Consulate-General of the Russian Federation: New South Wales
Dear Chair
Thank you for conveying a petition (EN5399) that calls on the House of Representatives to seek the closure of the Russian Consulate-General in Sydney.

The Australian Government will always act firmly and consistently to protect our national security interests. In June this year, the Parliament enacted legislation to terminate Russia's lease of its proposed site for a new diplomatic presence in Yarralumla to protect Australia's national security interests. This legislation denies Russia access to that site.

The Government has limited all bilateral cooperation with Russia since its illegal and immoral full-scale invasion of Ukraine; our bilateral relationship is not 'business as usual'. We continue to condemn Russia's actions and are working closely with our international partners to impose significant economic and political costs on Russia and those supporting its invasion.

Despite its increasing isolation, however, Russia remains a global power with influence, including as a permanent member of the UN Security Council. Diplomatic channels enable us to convey our opposition to Russia's war in Ukraine, condemn Russia's reckless nuclear threats, and advocate for the interests of Australians.

Like many countries with an embassy in Canberra, Russia maintains a Consulate-General in Sydney, including to provide services for consular clients and its diaspora community in Australia. The Australian Government has been clear about our commitment to ensuring that the number of accredited Russian diplomats and consular officials in Australia will reflect our national interests.

Regarding the activities of Mr Simeon Boikov, the Government's position is that he should face the criminal charges that have been laid against him. He is not a member of the Consulate-General's staff and does not enjoy privileges or immunities. However, under international and domestic law, consular premises are inviolable.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding petition EN5402, to cancel the proposed Illawarra offshore wind farm. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The offshore wind industry is well established internationally and is now an emerging industry in Australia. It offers large-scale, year-round reliable generation capacity and can replace energy provided by retiring coal fired power stations to help power Australia's homes and businesses into the future. It is intended that offshore wind will work alongside other forms of renewable energy, such as solar and onshore wind, to secure Australia's energy supply and help us achieve net zero by 2050.

I announced a public consultation for the proposed Illawarra offshore wind area on 14 August 2023. During this period the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water undertook a comprehensive program of community information sessions, targeted meetings with existing sectors such as fisheries and the tourism industry, and meetings with local government and First Nations representatives. The consultation process aimed to seek feedback from people in the region about whether the area is suitable for offshore wind and how offshore wind could share the area with other existing users and interests such as shipping, defence, fishing, and the environment.
When deciding whether to declare an area for offshore wind in this region, I will consider the matters raised by community, and industry on their merits.

The declaration of an offshore renewable energy area is the first stage of the government's regulatory process. If an area is declared, individual developers will then be able to apply for feasibility licences that will allow them to undertake further investigations and seek other approvals to test the feasibility of project proposals. There are no approved offshore wind· projects in the Illawarra at this time.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that the development of the offshore wind industry in Australia is undertaken in an environmentally sustainable and responsible way. During the feasibility licence stage, developers will work with the community and other marine users, such as the commercial and recreational fishing industry, community members and traditional owners, to refine their project proposals to ensure existing users can continue to use Australia's oceans, sharing the space with this new industry. It is also at this stage that specific project details, such as the number of turbines, will be determined. This is an important part of the process to ensure that community members can get the best outcomes from these developments, with reduced adverse impacts.

Developers of offshore wind projects must undertake extensive environmental assessments and obtain approval under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). This includes an assessment of any impacts, including the impact to birds, whales and other marine life. Experts within the Nature Positive Regulation Division of the department review these assessments. Where the department and Minister for the Environment are not satisfied that the studies submitted are adequate or do not demonstrate that a project will be able to avoid or mitigate environmental impacts to an acceptable level, approval under the EPBC Act will not be provided and a project will be unable to proceed.
Further information on offshore wind is available on the department's website at:
www.dcceew.gov.au/energy/renewable/offshore-wind.
Thank you again for bringing the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Workers Compensation Insurance
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding Petition EN5403—Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification (ANZSIC) categories for workers' compensation schemes.
The petition raises concerns about the classification of certain businesses for the purpose of workers' compensation arrangements in Queensland and other states and territories.

Workers' compensation arrangements are, for the most part, the responsibility of state and territory governments. Each state and territory has its own scheme and an authority that oversees it. The Commonwealth is responsible for workers' compensation schemes covering Commonwealth employees and private employers licensed to self-insure under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, as well as a defined group of seafarers and military personnel. The Commonwealth Government has no power to intervene in state and territory workers' compensation matters.

Each state or territory workers' compensation scheme sets their own premiums and industry classifications, although most schemes use a classification system based on the ANZSIC system. The Australian Bureau of Statistics is responsible for the ANZSIC system, and have confirmed to the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations that residential cleaning is ordinarily classified to either ANZSIC class 7311—Building and Other Industrial Cleaning Services or ANZSIC class 9531—Laundry and Dry-Cleaning services.

I would encourage the Standing Committee on Petitions to refer the petitioners to their workers' compensation scheme regulator to discuss their concerns about industry classification and how this may relate to premiums under the relevant scheme.
I trust this information is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Burke
Parliamentary Standards: Lobbyists
Dear Ms Templeman
Response to Petition EN5411 concerning lobbyists' access to Parliament House

On 16 October 2023, the House Petitions Committee published Report 16 pf 2023, which contained Petition EN5411, referring to lobbyists' access to Parliament House. It requested that the House 'limit open access passes to Parliament House to Government Employees, Contractors and Elected members only'.
At 30 September 2023, there were 11,833 Access Card holders to Australian Parliament House across all pass types. Of those total passholders, 2,020 have sponsored passes.

Sponsored passes are issued to any member of the public with a need to access the building for regular business. The sponsored pass category applies to a range of people, not just lobbyists. For example, the parents of children who use the childcare centre in APH hold this type of pass. There are parts of the building which remain only accessible to Senators and MPs; for example their offices, the chamber and other spaces. Security measures are in place to ensure improper access to Members and Senators suites does not occur; for example office suite doors may be locked and security can be rung if unwanted entry to offices occurs.

Checks and balances on the pass system do exist; for example a police check is required for all sponsored pass holders. The Senator or Member must also have had a relationship with the passholder for at least twelve months in order to sponsor their access card. I believe that Senators and Members take their responsibilities to sponsor passes seriously.

I am satisfied that the current approach balances the various needs of access to the building. I have concerns about changing the terms of passholders retrospectively when passes have already been issued to individuals. I will continue to review any new information raised with me on this topic, and I assure petitioners that I take any issues of security and integrity in this building seriously. Since becoming a Presiding Officer I have introduced integrity measures including banning fundraisers in bookable spaces and supporting changes to the House Standing Orders to improve standards of behaviour.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Dick
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair
Thank you for bringing to my attention the signed petition EN5429 of 16 October 2023, calling for constitutional protections for the right to freedom of speech.

The Australian Government recognises that all people are entitled to respect, dignity and the opportunity to participate in society regardless of their personal attributes, and acknowledges that to enjoy civil and political rights on an equal basis with others, people need to be able to do so free from discrimination. The Sex Discrimination Act 1984 prohibits discrimination on the grounds of gender identity, sexual orientation and intersex status in many areas of public life. In this context, the Australian Government recognises that individuals may identify and be recognised within the community as a gender other than the sex they were assigned at birth or during infancy, or as a gender which is not exclusively male or female.

The Government believes all Australians have the right to exercise their freedom of speech in a manner that respects the individual and collective rights enjoyed by other Australians, and which allows others to live in dignity. While the Australian Constitution does not explicitly protect freedom of expression, the High Court has held that an implied freedom of political communication exists as an indispensable part of the system of representative and responsible government created by the Constitution. It operates as a freedom from government restraint, rather than a right conferred directly on individuals.

The Government has referred Australia's Human Rights Framework to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights for review and report by March 2024. More information is at https://www.aph.gov.au/joint_humanrights/.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Pornography
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter dated 16 October 2023, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning Petition EN5435 which calls for a ban on explicit content.

The National Classification Scheme is run jointly between the Australian Government and the states and territories. It commenced in 1995 and covers the classification of films, computer games and some publications.

Under the National Classification Scheme, films that contain actual sexual intercourse and other sexual activity between consenting adults (commonly known as pornographic films) are given a special, legally restricted classification, X18+. The exhibition, sale and/or hire of X18+ material is illegal in all Australian states, however, it is permissible to own such material for person use. The sale and/or hire of X18+ material is permitted in the Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory to persons aged 18years and over. Law enforcement agencies in each jurisdiction are responsible for enforcing classification restrictions.

Films that meet ce1iain criteria—for example which depict child sexual abuse, or sexualised violence—can be Refused Classification. Refused Classification material cannot be sold, hired, advertised or legally imported in Australia.

span.span: Measures in the Online Safety Act which restrict access to pornography

p.span: The Albanese Government is committed to minimising the harm that comes from children accessing content online that is not appropriate for them, including online pornography. The Online Safety Act 2021 (the Act) imposes a range of measures to protect children from exposure to adult content. Additionally, the Government has recently delivered its response to the eSafety Commissioner's Roadmap for Age Verification, which considered further measures to mitigate the impact of online pornography on children.

The Act establishes an Online Content Scheme, which empowers the eSafety Commissioner to request or require takedown of illegal and restricted online content. Most pornographic content falls under the eSafety Commissioner's powers to respond to material that is, or is likely to be, classified as R18+, X18+ or Refused Classification under Australia's classification framework.
The hosting of pornographic material by Australian online service providers is prohibited under Australian law. As a result, most pornographic material accessed by Australians is hosted overseas.

For material hosted in Australia, the eSafety Commissioner can respond to X18+ material by issuing a removal notice to the service provider, and to R18+ by requiring that the material can only be accessed by adults by placing the content behind a Restricted Access System (RAS). The purpose of a RAS is not to prevent access to age-restricted content, but to ensure access is limited to people who are 18 years and over.

For material that is illegal or seriously harmful that is, or would likely be, Refused Classification (such as child sexual abuse material), the eSafety Commissioner has a stronger set of powers to require removal of this material no matter where it is hosted.

On 31 March 2023, the eSafety Commissioner delivered the Roadmap for Age Verification (the Roadmap) to the Australian Government. The Roadmap explores if and how age verification and other measures could be used to prevent and mitigate harm to children from online pornography.

The Roadmap found that currently, age verification and age assurance technologies are new and still evolving and come with privacy, security, and governance considerations. The Roadmap made a number of recommendations, including that the Government invest in research, education, awareness, and resources, that the eSafety Commissioner continue work to implement the Online Safety Act, and that the Government should pilot age assurance technologies, before seeking to mandate them.

In developing its response to the Roadmap, the Government focused on what actions are likely to lead to tangible and practical protections for children from pornography. I have asked the eSafety Commissioner to commence work on a set of mandatory, enforceable industry codes to address children's access to online pornography as soon as practicable. These codes are the most effective lever to deliver improved protections for children in the short- to medium-term.

The codes are required under the Act, and for the first time will require platforms to do more to protect children from exposure to online pornography. Importantly, these codes will be mandatory, and will apply to all different sections of the digital industry- including social media platforms, app stores, content hosting services, internet service providers and device manufacturers. With a complex challenge such as this, we need all parts of the online ecosystem to play a role.

These codes will be critical in lifting industry's standards. The code development process will also provide vital information on what a pilot of age assurance technologies might look like in the Australian context. The Government will seek further advice from the eSafety Commissioner once the codes are on track, including in relation to how a pilot might supp01i and complement the codes.

The Government is also taking action to strengthen our online safety framework. On 22 November, I announced the start of consultation on proposed amendments to the Online Safety (Basic Online Safety Expectations) Determination 2022, which is established under the Act. The Determination articulates Government's minimum expectations for online service providers to improve protections for users, including from harmful content. The eSafety Commissioner has the power to require service providers to report on their compliance with these expectations, driving transparency around industry's actions.

Under the proposed amendments, industry would be expected to consider the best interests of children in the design and operation of their services. An amendment would also make explicit that age assurance technologies are an important tool to prevent harm to children online. It is clear that some age assurance technologies and complementary measures are already being deployed across commercial platforms to prevent a range of harms to children and the Government wants to see industry continue to develop and invest in these technologies.

Countries around the world are grappling with the problem of age assurance and how best to prevent children from harmful content. The Government is closely monitoring international and industry developments, and on 10 November 2023 Australia joined the governments of France, Belgium, Denmark, Estonia, the Netherlands, Spain and the United Kingdom in a joint statement at the Paris Peace Forum, calling for global initiatives to reinforce the protection of children online.

We also want to make sure children and young people can access age-appropriate consent and respectful relationships education, and are providing this through the Consent and Respectful Relationships Education commitment of $83.5 million over 6 years (2022-23 to 2027-28).

In addition, the eSafety Commissioner has published a range of practical online resources with easy-to-follow advice about how technology and parental control settings can prevent children from accessing online pornography. This information can be found online at www.esafety.gov.au/parents/issues-and-advice/online-porn.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely,
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Housing
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5440 requesting the House to put forward a royal commission into housing/rental crisis. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

I note the suggestion to request a Royal Commission into the housing and rental markets. The Senate has recently considered evidence on a similar matter. On 22 June 2023, the Senate referred an inquiry into the worsening rental crisis in Australia to the Community Affairs References Committee for inquiry and report. The terms of reference for this inquiry included:
a. the experience of renters and people seeking rental housing,
b. rising rents and rental affordability;
c. actions that can be taken by governments to reduce rents or limit rent rises;
d. improvements to renters' rights, including rent stabilisation, length of leases and no grounds evictions;
e. factors impacting supply and demand of affordable rentals;
f. international experience of policies that effectively support renters;
g. the impact of government programs on the rental sector; and
h. any other related matters.
The Committee published the final report for this inquiry on 7 December 2023. The Australian Government is currently working through and considering all recommendations ahead of its response.

The Albanese Labor Government understands safe and affordable housing is central to the security and dignity of all Australians. Sadly, many Australians cannot find an affordable place to buy, rising interest rates have been difficult news for those with a mortgage and the rental market is also very tight with low vacancy rates and increasing rents across Australia.

That's why the Albanese Government has committed to an ambitious housing reform agenda which will boost the supply of all housing—more public and social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy.

These housing challenges didn't happen overnight and cannot be solved by one government alone. The Albanese Government is working with the state, territory and local governments to deliver better housing outcomes.
This includes the work being delivered through the National Cabinet to provide more secure and affordable housing supply. Significant measures include:

The National Housing Accord that will support planning and zoning reforms, as well as investing $350 million in additional federal funding to deliver 10,000 affordable rental homes over five years from 2024—matched by the state and territories.
Federal funding of $2 billion through the Social Housing Accelerator to deliver thousands of social homes across Australia.

Federal funding of $3 billion through the New Homes Bonus to help incentivise states and territories to build more homes where people need them to meet a new national target of 1.2 million new homes over five years.

A $500 million Housing Support Program for initiatives to help kick start housing supply including connecting essential services, amenities to support new housing development or building planning capability.
A National Planning Reform Blueprint with planning, zoning, land release and other measures to improve housing supply and affordability.
A Better Deal for Renters to harmonise and strengthen renters' rights across Australia.
These measures are in addition to the work that is being delivered.

The $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund (HAFF) has now started and will support 30,000 new social and affordable rental homes over its first five years. The Albanese Government has delivered on its commitment to establish the HAFF and it is the single biggest investment to support social and affordable rental housing in more than a decade.

The Albanese Government has now introduced legislation to establish the Help to Buy scheme and we are working with the states and territories for them to pass their own legislation in order for the scheme to operate in their state or territory. The Help to Buy Scheme will support up to 40,000 low and middle income families to purchase a home of their own. This will bring home ownership back into reach for thousands of Australians who have been locked out of the housing market.

The National Housing Infrastructure Facility (NHIF) has been expanded making up to $575 million available to invest in social and affordable rental homes, with projects already under construction as a result of this funding. The NHIF will also receive an additional $1 billion in federal funding to support more social housing.

Housing Australia's liability cap has been increased by $2 billion to provide lower cost and longer-term finance to community housing providers through the Affordable Housing Bond Aggregator. The largest increase to Commonwealth Rent Assistance in more than 30 years is being provided, with a 15 per cent increase in the maximum rate.

Tax incentives are being introduced to encourage more build-to-rent developments to boost new supply in the private rental market. Federal funding of $1.7 billion has been provided for a one-year extension of the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement with States and Territories, including a $67.5 million boost to homelessness funding over the next year.
Work to deliver on a new National Housing and Homelessness Plan is happening to identify the short, medium and long-term steps that can be taken to address housing issues in Australia.

More than 86,000 people have been helped into home ownership since the election of the Albanese Government through the Home Guarantee Scheme, including more than 13,000 through the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee. The scheme has now been expanded significantly—changes will see friends, siblings, and other family members eligible for joint applications under the First Home Guarantee and the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee.

We've also established the National Housing Supply and Affordability Council to provide expert advice and an evidence base on how Government can improve housing supply and affordability, and legislation has passed the Parliament to create the Council as a permanent independent body.

As you can see, the Albanese Government's ambitious housing reform agenda is designed to boost supply, increase housing affordability and make positive and practical differences for Australians planning to buy a home.
We are doing this to make sure more Australians have an affordable place to call home.
It's an agenda we are proud of and after a decade of little action we are working hard to turn around the housing challenges in Australia today.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms Collins
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding petition EN5442—offshore wind turbine developments in the Illawarra and Greater Newcastle regions. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The offshore wind industry is well established internationally and is now an emerging industry in Australia. It offers large-scale, year-round highly reliable generation capacity and can replace energy provided by retiring coal fired power stations to help power Australia's homes and businesses into the future. Itis intended that offshore wind will work alongside other forms of renewable energy, such as solar and onshore wind, to secure Australia's energy supply and help us achieve net zero by 2050.

In both the Illawarra and Hunter regions, the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water undertook a comprehensive program of community information sessions, targeted meetings with existing sectors such as fisheries and the tourism industry, and meetings with local government and First Nations representatives. The consultation process seeks feedback from people in the region about whether the area is suitable for offshore wind and how offshore wind could share the area with other existing users and interests such as shipping, defence, fishing, and the environment.

When deciding whether to declare an area for offshore wind in this region, I consider the matters raised by community, governments, unions, and industry on their merits rather than solely relying on the number of submissions supporting or opposing the proposal.

I declared an offshore wind area off the Hunter on 12 July 2023. In response to feedback from the community I reduced the size of the area by a third from what was originally proposed. I am still considering submissions made to the Illawarra consultation process.

The declaration of an offshore renewable energy area is the first stage of the government's regulatory process. If an area is declared, individual developers will then be able to apply for feasibility licences that will allow them to undertake further investigations and seek other approvals to test the feasibility of project proposals. There are no approved offshore wind projects in the Illawarra or the Hunter areas at this time.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that the development of the offshore wind industry in Australia is undertaken in an environmentally sustainable and responsible way. During the feasibility licence stage, developers will work with the community and other marine users, such as the commercial and recreational fishing industry, community members and traditional owners, to refine their project proposals to ensure existing users can continue to use Australia's oceans, sharing the space with this new industry. It is also at this stage that· specific project details, such as the number of turbines, will be determined. This is an important part of the process to ensure that community members can get the best outcomes from these developments, with reduced adverse impacts.

Developers of offshore wind projects must undertake extensive environmental assessments and obtain approval under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). This includes an assessment of any impacts, including the impact to birds, whales, and other marine life. Experts within the Nature Positive Regulation Division of the department review these assessments. Where the department and Minister for the Environment are not satisfied that the studies submitted are adequate or do not demonstrate that a project will be able to avoid or mitigate environmental impacts to an acceptable level, approval under the EPBC Act will not be provided and a project will be unable to proceed.
Further information on offshore wind is available on the department's website at:
www.dcceew.gov.au/energy/renewable/offshore-wind.
Thank you again for bringing the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 21 November 2023 regarding petition EN5444—plans to approve wind turbines being built off the Illawarra coast. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The offshore wind industry is well established internationally and is now an emerging industry in Australia. It offers large-scale, year-round baseload generation capacity and can replace energy provided by retiring coal fired power stations to help power Australia's homes and businesses into the future. It is intended that offshore wind will work alongside other forms of renewable energy, such as solar and onshore wind, to secure Australia's energy supply and help us achieve net zero by 2050.

I announced a public consultation for the proposed Illawarra offshore wind area on 14 August 2023. During this period the Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water undertook a comprehensive program of community information sessions, targeted meetings with existing sectors such as fisheries and the tourism industry, and meetings with local government and First Nations representatives. The consultation process aimed to seek feedback from people in the region about whether the area is suitable for offshore wind and how offshore wind could share the area with other existing users and interests such as shipping, defence, fishing, and the environment.
When deciding whether to declare an area for offshore wind in this region, I will consider the matters raised by community, and industry on their merits.

The declaration of an offshore renewable energy area is the first stage of the government's regulatory process. If an area is declared, individual developers will then be able to apply for feasibility licences that will allow them to undertake further investigations and seek other approvals to test the feasibility of project proposals. There are no approved offshore wind projects in the Illawarra at this time.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that the development of the offshore wind industry in Australia is undertaken in an environmentally sustainable and responsible way. During the feasibility licence stage, developers will work with the community and other marine users, such as the commercial and recreational fishing industry, community members and traditional owners, to refine their project proposals to ensure existing users can continue to use Australia's oceans, sharing the space with this new industry. It is also at this stage that specific project details, such as the number of turbines, will be determined. This is an important part of the process to ensure that community members can get the best outcomes from these developments, with reduced adverse impacts.

Developers of offshore wind projects must undertake extensive environmental assessments and obtain approval under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). This includes an assessment of any impacts, including the impact to birds, whales and other marine life. Experts within the Nature Positive Regulation Division of the department review these assessments. Where the department and Minister for the Environment are not satisfied that the studies submitted are adequate or do not demonstrate that a project will be able to avoid or mitigate environmental impacts to an acceptable level, approval under the EPBC Act will not be provided and a project will be unable to proceed.
Further information on offshore wind is available on the department's website at:
www.dcceew.gov.au/energy/renewable/offshore-wind.
Thank you again for bringing the petition to my attention.
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Capital Punishment
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 regarding petition EN5445, which requests the House debate legalising the death penalty for persons convicted of child sexual abuse.

The Government acknowledges the devastating impact child sexual abuse has on the Australian community. It takes immense courage for victims and survivors to report child sexual abuse. Too often, they face significant challenges coming forward, including institutional and social barriers. It is our collective responsibility to make sure they are believed, protected and supplied, and that perpetrators are held accountable. Every child and young person has the fundamental right to be protected and safe from sexual abuse.

The Government's National Strategy to Prevent and Respond to Child Sexual Abuse 2021-2030 (the National Strategy) provides a 10-year, whole-of-nation framework to establish a coordinated and consistent approach to preventing and better responding to child sexual abuse in all settings. The National Strategy was a key recommendation of the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse (Royal Commission) and responds to approximately 100 other Royal Commission recommendations to address child sexual abuse in all settings. $307.5 million has been committed over four years from 2021-22 for the National Strategy's initial implementation.

The National Office for Child Safety within the Attorney-General's Depa1iment leads the development and implementation of national priorities to protect children and young people from child sexual abuse, and support victims and survivors. Some of the National Strategy's priorities include:
preventing child sexual abuse through building child safe capability in organisations
delivery of a national awareness raising campaign on child sexual abuse
enhancing support for victims and survivors of child sexual abuse, including by developing minimum practice standards for, and baseline mapping of, specialist and community support services
developing trauma-informed and culturally appropriate resources and approaches for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples
improving the evidence base on the prevalence, nature, causes and impacts of all forms of child maltreatment in Australia.

The National Strategy also includes measures focused on early intervention and management programs for potential and existing offenders to support the criminal justice response. These programs seek to prevent offending, intervene before offending occurs and reduce repeat offending. Preventing offending from happening is the best way to protect children, and programs that intervene before a child or young person has been harmed also mean law enforcement can focus resources on particularly harmful or high-risk offending.

In addition, the Attorney-General's Department engages closely with law enforcement, eSafety and prosecutorial agencies to prevent, combat and strengthen responses to, child sexual exploitation and abuse. In 2018, the Australian Centre to Counter Child Exploitation (ACCCE) was established to bring together capabilities from across the public and private sectors and civil society to drive a collaborative national response to counter the epidemic of child exploitation in Australia. The Australian Federal Police-led ACCCE focuses on countering online child sexual exploitation, including organised child exploitation networks operating in the online environment.

While states and territories have primary responsibility for legislating on matters related to child sexual abuse within their jurisdiction, the Criminal Code (Cth) includes a robust framework of offences relating to child sexual abuse and child abuse material. This includes aggravated offences that carry maximum penalties of up to life imprisonment and have mandatory minimum sentences of up to 7 years' imprisonment.

The Government is committed to ensuring that serious crimes are met with appropriate penalties but has a long-standing policy of opposition to capital punishment. As a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and its Second Optional Protocol, Australia has an obligation not only to abolish the death penalty in its jurisdiction, but also to ensure that our laws and policies are consistent with this obligation.

In 1973 the Commonwealth Parliament passed the Death Penalty Abolition Act 1973 (Cth) and subsequently passed laws in March 2010 to extend the application of the Commonwealth prohibition on the death penalty to state and territory laws. This ensures that the death penalty cannot be reintroduced anywhere in Australia in the future.
Thank you for bringing petition EN5445 to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Disability Services: Child Care
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 November 2023 regarding Petition EN5446, requesting action to address discrimination in early childhood education and care (ECEC) against children with disabilities and complex medical needs.
The Australian Government acknowledges the importance of accessible ECEC for all children, including children with disabilities and complex needs.

For families who have a child with a disability, the Government's Inclusion Support Program (ISP) prioritises support for children with additional needs. The ISP supports eligible mainstream ECEC services to build their capacity and capability to include children with additional needs, so all children have genuine opportunities to access, participate and achieve positive learning outcomes.

The Government commissioned the Productivity Commission (PC) to conduct an inquiry into Australia's ECEC system to help chart a course for universal, affordable ECEC. The PC released its draft report on 23 November 2023. The PC draft report noted achieving a universal ECEC system accessible to all children and families will require tackling availability, affordability and inclusion gaps. In support of that, it outlined draft recommendations, including amendments to the Disability Standards for Education 2005 (the Standards) to include all ECEC providers. The Australian Government committed to action such amendments to the Standards following the 2020 Review of the Standards and is working with state and territory governments and education authorities to implement them. The Government encourages the community to provide feedback to the PC on the PC draft report, which will inform the development of the PC final report, due to Government by 30 June 2024.

Petitioners may be interested in the work of the Australian Education Research Organisation (AERO), which is Australia's independent education evidence body. AERO's vision is for Australia to achieve excellence and equity in educational outcomes for all children and young people through effective use of evidence. Each year, AERO sets out its research agenda, and in 2023 this includes a focus on addressing educational disadvantage, including for children and young people with disabilities.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Early Childhood Education, Dr Aly
Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 1 December 2023 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, about a petition presented in the House of Representatives on 27 November 2023 (EN5455) seeking an increase to the Assistance for Isolated Children (AIC) Scheme's Basic Boarding Allowance. The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.

The Australian Government recognises there are significant costs associated with children who need to board away from home in order to access education, as they do not have daily access to an appropriate school in their local area.

The intent of the AIC Scheme Basic Boarding Allowance is to provide a non-means tested contribution towards the costs incurred by families in boarding a student away from home. From 1 January 2024, students eligible for the Basic Boarding Allowance, and the means-tested Additional Boarding Allowance, can receive up to $12,816 a year to support their boarding costs. These AIC boarding allowances, which are indexed on 1 January each year, are not intended to cover the full cost of attending boarding schools.
Individual states and territories also provide a range of allowances that eligible rural and remote families can access that contribute towards the costs of boarding school for their children.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Services, Ms Elliot
Paid Parental Leave Scheme
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence dated 1 December 2023 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning the petition to amend the Paid Parental Leave scheme from 20 weeks to one year (EN5473). The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.
Paid Parental Leave is an important mechanism for providing support to working families and improving women's economic outcomes.

The October 2022-23 Budget measure Boosting Parental Leave to Enhance Economic Security, Support and Flexibility for Australia's Families provides for the expansion of the Paid Parental Leave scheme to 26 weeks by 1 July 2026, the most significant expansion of the scheme since it was introduced in 2011.

The Paid Parental Leave scheme is intended to complement and supplement parents' existing entitlements to employer-provided paid and unpaid leave, such as access to 12 months' unpaid parental leave under the National Employment Standards for long-term employees.

Parents can take Parental Leave Pay before, after or at the same time as employer-provided paid or unpaid maternity or parental leave, or other employer-funded leave entitlements (such as annual leave or long service leave).

Parents may be able to extend the amount of time they spend with their baby up to 52 weeks or longer, through a combination of Paid Parental Leave, employer-provided paid leave and unpaid leave. According to the Workplace Gender Equality Agency, in 2022-23, 63 per cent of employers offered paid parental leave.

More information about the Paid Parental Leave scheme, including Parental Leave Pay, and other family assistance can be found on the Services Australia website at www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/raising-kids or by phoning Services Australia on 13 6150.
The Minister appreciates you bringing this matter to her attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Services, Ms Elliot
Assange, Mr Julian Paul
Dear Chair
Thank you for your referral of petition EN5493 regarding Mr Julian Assange and targeted sanctions on the UK and the US.

I understand there is strong interest in Mr Assange's case and a depth of community sentiment. The Australian Government has been clear in its view that Mr Assange's case has dragged on for long enough and should be brought to a close. The Prime Minister and I have expressed this view directly to the governments of the United Kingdom and United States.

As we do for other Australians facing legal proceedings overseas, the Government is following Mr Assange's case closely and is offering consular assistance. The Government will continue to convey our expectations that Mr Assange is entitled to due process, humane and fair treatment, access to proper medical care and access to his legal team.

The Australian Government is unable to intervene in another country's legal or court processes, just as they are unable to intervene in Australia's. While we are doing what we can between the Australian Government and other governments concerned, ultimately this is a matter for Mr Assange and his legal representation. In a comparable case, a resolution by government was only possible once legal processes had been concluded.
Thank you for taking the time to present this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Live Animal Exports
Dear Chair

Thank you for referring the petition of 27 November 2023, calling for an investigation into live export businesses (Petition number: EN5496). I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government takes the welfare of all animals very seriously and understands its importance to the Australian community. The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry regulates livestock exports in accordance with the Export Control Act 2020 and the Export Control (Animals) Rules 2021 and remains strongly committed to ensuring high welfare standards are maintained in this trade.

Information about how the trade is regulated, as well as details on previous reviews, reform work and changes to regulatory requirements is available to Members of Parliament and the general public on the department's website: agriculture.gov.au/biosecurity- trade/export/controlled-goods/live-animals.

Regarding providing livestock with space for them to walk around, the Australian Standards for. the Export of Livestock (ASEL) set the minimum requirements for exporting livestock, including ensuring animals are provided sufficient space to maintain positive animal welfare outcomes. ASEL is regularly reviewed to ensure it reflect the best available science and evidence. You can access a copy of the current version of ASEL on the department's website: agriculture.gov.au/biosecurity-trade/export/controlled-goods/live-animals/livestock/australian- standards-livestock.

Accredited veterinarians (AAV) already play an important role in the live export trade from Australia. AAV's help prepare animals for export and may accompany livestock on the voyage. The ASEL sets out health and welfare standards for livestock exports and includes when an AAV needs to accompany livestock on an export voyage.
More information on AAVs can be found on the department's website at agriculture.gov.au/biosecurity-trade/export/controlled-goods/live-animals/1ivestock/accredited-veterinarian.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Watt
Medicare
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 regarding petition EN5528 requesting an increase to the Medicare Benefits rebate by an amount that would allow GPs to bulk bill everyone and to legislate that GPs must bulk bill for all.

While the Australian Government is responsible for setting Medicare fees and rebates, GPs operate their practices as private businesses and are free to determine the fees they charge for their services, including whether they bulk bill some or all their patients or charge a co-payment.

The Government encourages doctors to bulk bill patients under 16 years of age and those with Commonwealth concession cards by providing a bulk billing incentive payment in addition to the Medicare rebate for the consultation. The Medicare bulk billing incentive payments are targeted to support those patients who generally use more GP services and have higher needs, including higher levels of chronic and complex conditions and socioeconomic disadvantage.

The 2023-24 Budget included $6.1 billion in measures to strength n Medicare, revamp primary care and increase affordability for patients. Among the measures were a $3.5 billion investment to triple the bulk billing incentive for the most common GP consultation items and an indexation boost to Medicare rebates of more than $1.5 billion. Both of these measures commenced on 1 November 2023.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Nuclear Energy
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 regarding petition EN5544 to separate nuclear fusion and nuclear fission in legislation.

The Australian Government has committed.to reducing emissions to 43 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030 and to net zero by 2050. Nuclear fusion remains an experimental technology and will be developed and commercialised too slowly to help Australia meet these targets. The International Atomic Energy Agency, for example, reports that the construction and operation of demonstration electricity-producing fusion power plants could occur by 2050, depending on funding and technical advancement.

The GenCost 2022-23 Report, prepared by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator, shows that renewables are the cheapest form of generation for Australia, even when additional costs for storage and new transmission are included. Renewable technologies are quicker to build and cheaper to operate than nuclear power facilities.

The legislative prohibition on the approval of nuclear power plants under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 does not differentiate between nuclear technologies. The Australian Government has no plans to change the longstanding moratorium on nuclear power in Australia, or the laws which prohibit its deployment.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen

subdebateinfo.title: National Disability Insurance Scheme: First Nations Australians

p.span: National Disability Insurance Scheme: First Nations Australians
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 1 December 2023, regarding House of Representatives Petition EN5549, seeking consideration of an additional budget component for First Nations participants of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS).

By way of background, the NDIS provides eligible Australians under the age of 65, who have a permanent and significant disability, with reasonable and necessary supports to pursue their goals. These goals may include greater independence, community involvement, employment and improved wellbeing.

The NDIS seeks to take a lifetime approach, investing in people with disability early to improve their outcomes later in life. The NDIS also provides people with disability, their family and carers with information and referrals to existing support services in the community. I would like to assure you that improving the responsiveness of the NDIS for First Nations people, ensuring they can live a life that has meaning for them, is a key focus of the Australian Government.

As you may know, the Government commissioned an independent NDIS Review panel in October 2022 to engage extensively with people with disability, carers, and the disability sector, as well as state and territory governments around Australia, to look at ways we might improve the effectiveness of the NDIS and make a positive impact on the lives of people with disability, including First Nations peoples. The Review panel received almost 4,000 written submissions and engaged directly with thousands of people.

Following delivery of the final Report to Commonwealth and state and territory disability Ministers, the final Report was released to the broader community on 7 December 2023. Governments will consider and respond to the Report as quickly as possible to support to ensure the NDIS achieves better outcomes for all participants and is sustainable into the future.

In addition to considering the report of the Review, as part of the 2022-23 Budget, the Government announced the Alternative Approaches to Commissioning for Remote and First Nations Communities" initiative (Alternative Commissioning). A critical challenge for NDIS participants, including many First Nations people living in remote areas is the availability of services and supports to be purchased with their NDIS funds. Alternative Commissioning is about partnering with communities to pilot alternative approaches to improve access to NDIS supports in remote and First Nations communities. It will create opportunities for more culturally appropriate and sustainable services to strengthen the First Nations disability sector and build a sustainable supply of NDIS supports in remote areas.

These approaches are being developed and piloted, in partnership with First Nations representatives and remote communities. They will be co-designed solutions developed from the ground up based on community needs. Alternative Commissioning will deliver a more active and flexible approach to market stewardship that will drive better outcomes for participants and communities.

In addition, The Government is also carefully considering the Disability Royal Commission's final report and its 222 recommendations. The Government will carefully consider the final report before commenting on individual recommendations.
The Government is committed to providing appropriate services for all First Nations peoples, whether they are participants of the NDIS or not, and thanks you for your referral of this petition.
Yours sincerely,
from the Minister for National Disability Insurance Scheme, Mr Shorten
Refugee And Humanitarian Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 6 March 2023 enclosing Petition PN0554, with 73 signatures, concerning Temporary Protection visa (TPV) and Safe Haven Enterprise visa (SHEV) holders. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government has provided a permanent visa pathway to existing TPV and SHEV holders. This permanent visa pathway, through the permanent Resolution of Status (RoS) (subclass 851) visa, has been made available from 14 February 2023.

People granted a permanent RoS visa will be afforded the same rights and benefits as all permanent humanitarian residents. Providing a permanent visa pathway to existing TPV and SHEV holders will empower them to move forward with their lives and to more fully contribute to Australia, gain secure employment, grow businesses, study more easily, sponsor eligible family members under the family stream of the Migration Program to Australia and pursue a pathway to Australian citizenship.

The Government is committed to implementing this measure in an efficient and effective manner to ensure the majority of the caseload are granted a RoS visa within 12 months of processing commencement.

Persons who do not engage protection obligations, who are not awaiting a merits or judicial review outcome, and who have exhausted all avenues to remain in Australia, are expected to depart Australia voluntarily and may be provided assistance to depart.

Australia is committed to its international obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol and other international human rights conventions to which it is a party. Australia does not return individuals to situations where they face persecution or a real risk of torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, arbitrary deprivation of life or the application of the death penalty.

Further information regarding the TPV/SHEV transition to permanent visas can be found on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a- visa/visa-listing/resolution-of-status-851#About.
Thank you for bringing Petition PN0554 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
