Opioid Dependence
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 12 November 2023 regarding petition PN0571 concerning a request for the House to re-examine the changes to the access arrangements for opioid dependence treatment (ODT).

The Australian Government is committed to reducing patient costs and improving access to Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) medicines to treat opioid dependency. The Government, having listened to the views of patients through extensive consultations, and the Post-Market Review of ODT medicines, has reformed opioid dependency treatment arrangements to put the interests of patients first.

As of 1 July 2023, new and existing patients with opioid dependence are accessing the medicines they need on the PBS. For the first time, patients are paying the usual PBS co-payment for their medicines and the amount paid contributes towards their PBS Safety Net threshold. Patients accessing their treatment from a PBS community pharmacy are no longer paying $150-200 a month in high, unregulated, out-of-pocket fees.

The inclusion of ODT medicines under the Section 100 Highly Specialised Drugs (HSD) Program is intended to address the core issues of patient affordability and equitable access to ODT medicines through the PBS, such that access to PBS subsidised ODT medicines aligns with usual PBS arrangements.

On 8 June 2023 the Prime Minister, the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, agreed for the Australian Government to continue to pay pharmaceutical companies directly for ODT medicines supplied to private ODT clinics and other non-PBS dosing sites for a transition period to 30 November 2023.

This transition period for the supply of ODT medicines has been extended to 30 June 2024. This means private clinics and non-PBS dosing sites can continue to order directly from the pharmaceutical wholesaler/distributor and receive stock at no cost until 30 June 2024.

These transition arrangements allows time for state and territory governments to transition patients to the Section 100 HSD Program or make other suitable arrangements to ensure patients can continue to access their ODT medicines.

State and territory governments continue to operate individual ODT programs in their respective jurisdictions, and these programs are governed by the respective policies, guidelines, and regulations within each of those jurisdictions. There is no requirement for states and territories to reduce or withdraw their own funding support for ODT.

The Department of Health and Aged Care is continuing to work with state and territory officials on the transition arrangements for private clinics and other non-PBS dosing sites (including Aboriginal Medical Services, GP clinics, and correctional facilities) to ensure patients can access affordable PBS-subsidised medicines for opioid dependence as quickly and safely as possible.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Consumer Law
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4838 on the listed price for the selling of goods or services. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Government supports an efficient payments system with clear price signals which support consumers and businesses to make choices that best suit their needs. The Competition and Consumer Amendment (Payment Surcharges) Act 2016 was passed by Parliament to protect consumers from excessive surcharges when undertaking card transactions. Retailers are permitted to surcharge up to the amount the individual payment system costs the merchant to process. This surcharging allows the merchant to recoup the cost of accepting the payment from the customer who makes it. Additionally, when all available payment methods are subject to a surcharge, the business must include the minimum surcharge payable in the displayed price. This occurs when a business does not accept cash and the business applies a surcharge to all card payments.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is the primary regulator of these requirements. The ban on excessive card surcharging ensures customers are charged no more than the amount necessary to recover the merchant's costs of acceptance. The ACCC is responsible for enforcing the ban on excessive surcharging and considering related complaints.

The card surcharge requirements do not extend to time-related surcharges on menu items, such as those imposed on weekends and public holiday. Businesses are permitted to impose surcharges of this kind but must follow regulations about how they are displayed. Where a business imposes a surcharge, they must prominently display the following words on their menu: "A surcharge of (percentage) applies on (day or days)".

The Government supports merchants being able to recoup their costs but only in a way that is fair, transparent and visible for all market participants. In a situation where a consumer believes the merchant has not acted within the guidelines, the consumer should report them to the ACCC. The Government will continue to monitor the issue and consider any further necessary regulatory changes.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Banking And Financial Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter enclosing the Petition EN4951 recently presented in the House concerning the banning of financial sector directors and executives in certain circumstances.

The Australian financial system is well positioned to weather shocks and support the economy. Australian banks entered the recent challenging environment for global financial stability in a strong position.

Australia's unquestionably strong prudential requirements, updated in January 2023, exceed international standards in several areas. As a result, Australian banks have strong capital positions, liquidity coverage and a robust domestic regulatory framework.

I certainly share the petitioners' expectations for accountability in relation to financial sector misconduct. That is why the Government is establishing a Financial Accountability Regime (FAR), to enhance accountability and support higher quality governance within the financial sector, in keeping with the recommendations of the 2019 Financial Services Royal Commission.

Under the FAR, which will be administered by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, the regulators will have the authority to disqualify senior executives and directors if they fail to comply with their obligations. The FAR will also impose financial consequences for failing to meet obligations, including civil penalties for accountable entities.

Legislation establishing the FAR commenced on 15 September 2023. It will apply to accountable persons in the banking sector from 15 March 2024, and in the insurance and superannuation sectors after a further twelve months, reflecting that the banking sector is already subject to similar requirements under the Banking Executive Accountability Regime (which remains in effect until 15 March 2024).

The FAR builds on the general framework already in the corporations law, including the requirements under the Corporations Act 2001 that board members exercise their powers and fulfill their duties with a degree of care, diligence, and in the best interests of their corporation. Failure to meet these obligations can result in criminal charges, carrying penalties of up to 15 years of imprisonment or fines, as well as potential contravention of civil penalty provisions. I consider these general, principles-based approaches are preferable to any specific rule that ties disqualification to an event such as a banking failure.
I trust this information will be of assistance to the House and the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Human Rights
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5140 for a proposed 'Mercy Amendment' to the Corporations Act 2001 (the Corporations Act). I appreciate the petitioners are very concerned about whistleblowing protections for victims of human rights breaches such as disability discrimination.

The whistleblower regime under the Corporations Act provides protection to whistleblowers against detriment related to the making of an eligible disclosure. Criminal offences and civil penalties may apply to companies or individuals that cause or threaten to cause detriment to a whistleblower or for breaching a whistleblower's confidentiality. Eligible whistleblowers include employees of a regulated entity and their spouse or relative. Regulated entities include companies and incorporated associations.
The private-sector whistleblowing regime sets out four key criteria that must be met for protection as a whistleblower:

1. The role of the whistleblower—people who can make disclosures include officers of a company or other regulated entity, employees, supplier, associate of the company or regulated entity, or their relatives. In all cases, the whistleblower holds the right to remain anonymous.

2. The company or organisation to which the disclosure relates—the regulated entities that the disclosure is about can include companies, bank (Authorised Deposit-taking Institutions), general or life insurers, or superannuation funds and trustees.

3. To whom the disclosure is made—disclosures must be made to certain recipients to be protected including a director, auditor (or member of an audit team), actuary, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) or the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA).

4. The subject of the disclosure—whistleblowers must have reasonable grounds to suspect that the information they are disclosing about the company or regulated entity concerns misconduct or improper states of affairs or circumstances.

This information can be about the company or organisation, or an officer or employee of the company or organisation, engaging in conduct that breaches the Corporations Act or other financial sector laws, is an offence against any other law of the Commonwealth punishable by imprisonment for a period of 12 months or more, or represents a danger to the public or the financial system.
ASIC is Australia's corporate regulator. More information about whistleblower eligibility and protections, and information on how ASIC handles reports are available at:
https://asic.gov.au/about-asic/asic-investigations-and-enforcement/whistleblowing/.

The whistleblower regime under the Corporations Act will soon be the subject of a statutory review which will provide an opportunity to consider issues related to the proposed 'Mercy Amendment'. The review must take place as soon as practicable after 1 July 2024. It will examine the effectiveness of the whistleblowing regime and whether any further changes should be made to protect and promote whistleblowing. As part of this review, interested parties will have the opportunity to submit their views.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Animal Welfare
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 about petition EN5408 presented to Parliament seeking the establishment of a National Wildlife Patrol Service dedicated to preventing the illegal shooting of wildlife.

The Australian Government takes the welfare of all animals, especially Australia's wildlife, seriously. Australia's native species are protected under both the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act), and relevant state and territory legislation, including animal welfare legislation. The EPBC Act provides a strong legal framework to protect and manage Australia's land and marine biodiversity, threatened species, ecosystems, environment and heritage.
State and territory governments have primary responsibility for managing kangaroos and other wildlife, including animal welfare and for human safety within their jurisdiction.
All state-managed harvest of kangaroos and wallabies for international export must have an approved wildlife trade management plan or wildlife trade operation under the EPBC Act.
My department is responsible for assessing and approving wildlife trade management plans and operations under the EPBC Act.

There are two national codes relevant to kangaroo harvest—the National Code of Practice for the Humane Shooting of Kangaroos and Wallabies for Commercial Purposes (the Code), approved by the Australian Government in 2020, sets minimum standards that must be met to achieve an acceptable level of animal welfare, and the National Code of Practice for the Humane Shooting of Kangaroos and Wallabies for Non-commercial Purposes. The state and territory governments are responsible for managing compliance with these codes. They provide shooter licenses where required, investigate reports of illegal harvesting and non- compliance with the codes, manage education programs, undertake field monitoring, and where necessary undertake enforcement activities. Civil and criminal penalties also apply for breaches of the legislation.
At this time, the Australian Government is not seeking to establish a National Wildlife Patrol Service dedicated to preventing the illegal shooting of wildlife, specifically kangaroos.

The Australian Government will continue to work with the state and territory governments to ensure the necessary action is taken to investigate potential illegal shooting of kangaroos and to ensure that appropriate action is implemented where illegal shooting is proven.
We encourage the public to report potential illegal shootings to the relevant state and territory government for investigation.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Water, Ms Plibersek
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 enclosing petition number EN5419 about the 14 October 2023 referendum.

On Saturday, 14 October 2023, Australians voted in an historic referendum about whether to change the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia by establishing a body called the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice. This was the form of constitutional recognition sought by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

The referendum was not carried. The Australian Government respects the decision of the Australian people and the democratic process that delivered it. The outcome of the vote does not affect work already underway across governments to create better outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.

The Government remains committed to listening and working in partnership with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and communities to achieve better outcomes. The National Agreement on Closing the Gap and other initiatives will continue to ensure practical progress in Indigenous health, education, employment and housing.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus

from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Aviation Industry
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 1 December 2023 regarding petition number EN5453 in relation to allowing additional flights from reputable airlines under Australia's bilateral air services arrangements.

Air services agreements are treaty level agreements between countries that are determined in the national interest. Every country in considering opening further access to its aviation market makes decisions in this way and Australia is no different.

Australia has air services agreements with more than 100 countries facilitating international travel to and from Australia. These international agreements are enabling Australians wishing to travel internationally, or visitors coming to Australia, to access nearly 2,000 international flights per week.
Many countries, including Qatar, seek changes to these agreements from time to time.
The Australian Government has decided not to approve the Qatar Civil Aviation Authority's requests for additional services at this time.
This is not the first time Australia has refused capacity increases in such negotiations and of course Australia has also been denied capacity for its airlines to access key markets abroad.

As the airline industry continues to recover from the pandemic, we are seeing a large amount of additional capacity come into the international market. Emirates, Qantas, Cathay Pacific Singapore Airlines and China Southern are all introducing additional flights to Australia. Airlines of Vietnam and Turkiye have also indicated that they wish to operate new flights to Australia which will be facilitated by recently updated air services arrangements agreed with civil aviation officials of these respective countries.
All scheduled international airlines operating to Australia are also required to meet international aviation safety and security requirements.

The forthcoming Aviation White Paper—due to be released in the first half of 2024—will set the scene for the next generation of growth and development across the aviation sector out to 2050. This includes considering as a priority the economic reforms needed to improve productivity across the sector, to facilitate the delivery of aviation services for the Australian public and international visitors out to 2050, as well as protecting secure Australian jobs and better rights and protection for consumers.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms King
Endometriosis
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 regarding Petition EN5454 seeking to list Visanne(R) (dienogest) on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for endometriosis.

The Australian Government is taking active steps to address the significant burden endometriosis places on Australian women and girls. We are focussed on improving endometriosis and pelvic pain diagnosis and primary care support, helping more women to find appropriate care and better manage the impact of endometriosis and pelvic pain. Since the release of the first National Action Plan for Endometriosis (Action Plan) in July 2018, the Government has committed approximately $87.19 million to support implementation activities. This includes $8.57 million for awareness and education, over $49.65 million for clinical management and care and over $28.97 million for research. The Endometriosis Progress Report 2023 Update provides further information on these implementation activities and can be found on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au/topics using the search term, 'what we're doing about endometriosis'.

The Government is committed to ensuring Australians have access to affordable medicines by listing medicines recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) on the PBS. The PBAC is an independent, expert body comprising of doctors, health professionals, health economists and consumer representatives. Its primary role is to advise me, as the Minister for Health and Aged Care, about medicines and medicinal preparations that should be funded on the PBS. Under legislation, the Government can only list a new medicine on the PBS when the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of its listing.

When considering a medicine proposed for PBS listing, the PBAC is legally required to consider the comparative effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the medicine compared to other available therapies. The PBAC's consideration is generally initiated by the pharmaceutical company responsible for supply of the medicine, as the pharmaceutical company usually holds the scientific data and other information necessary to inform the PBAC's consideration.

A stocktake of medicines listed on the PBS for the treatment of endometriosis and related conditions was considered by the PBAC in December 2022, to identify potential gaps between medicines subsidised through the PBS and medicines available to patients privately (at full cost). The PBAC noted that dienogest is Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) registered for endometriosis and its use is supported by clinical guidelines but is not PBS-subsidised.
Further information about the PBAC's consideration and outcome is available at:
www.pbs.gov.au/info/industry/listing/elements/pbac-meetings/pbac outcomes/recommendations-made-by-the-pbac-december-2022-intracycle.

Currently, there are four brands of dienogest that are TGA-registered. The pharmaceutical company responsible for Visanne is Bayer Australia Ltd (Bayer), and the pharmaceutical company responsible for the other brands is Arrotex Pharmaceuticals Pty Ltd (Arrotex).

In 2023, the Department of Health and Aged Care wrote to Bayer and Arrotex to seek an expression of interest in applying for the PBS listing of these products for. he treatment of endometriosis. To date, the PBAC has not received a submission requesting the PBS listing of dienogest. You may wish to contact Bayer and Arrotex to ask if they intend to apply to the PBAC to list dienogest on the PBS for the treatment of endometriosis. Bayer can be contacted by phone on 1800 008 757 and Arrotex can be contacted on 1300 927 769.

Pharmaceutical companies are private businesses that make their own decisions about the pricing of their medicines and whether they will market them exclusively on the private market or apply for subsidy through the PBS. The Government cannot compel pharmaceutical companies to seek PBS subsidies for their medicines.

Where a medicine is not listed on the PBS, private health insurers are free to pay benefits, under general treatment cover, for the full price of the medicine. Health insurers may choose to offer this cover as a value-added feature of their policies, subject to any terms and conditions they choose to set. This is a commercial decision for the health insurer.

All aspects of patient care, including recommendations about appropriate treatments, are the responsibility of the treating doctor. Individuals may wish to discuss with their treating doctor whether there are suitable treatment alternatives available for their condition under the PBS.

The Government has also established a National Women's Health Advisory Council (Council) to provide strategic advice and recommendations directly to Government to improve health outcomes for Australian women and girls. The Council is also providing advice on the implementation of the National Women's Health Strategy 2020-2030, which outlines a national approach to reducing inequalities and improving health outcomes for all women and girls particularly those at greatest risk of poor health. The Government acknowledges the Senate inquiry into universal access to reproductive healthcare report, Ending the postcode lottery: addressing barriers to sexual, maternity and reproductive healthcare in Australia, tabled on 25 May 2023. The Government is considering the report recommendations and will respond in due course.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Aviation Industry
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 1 December 2023 regarding petition EN5456, presented in the House of Representatives, requesting the Australian Government implement a passenger compensation scheme in the aviation sector.
I thank the signatories to this petition for their engagement on this important issue.

The Government has committed to delivering an Aviation White Paper (the White Paper) to set the scene for the next generation of growth and development across the aviation sector. This includes considering as a priority the economic reforms needed to improve productivity across the sector, such as addressing skills shortages and competition between airports and airlines. The White Paper process will also consider and explore consumer protection issues.
The Aviation White Paper is due to be released in mid-2024. Further information is available at:
www.infrastructure.gov.au/infrastrncture-transport-vehicles/aviation/aviation-white-paper.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government Member for Ballarat, Ms King
Health Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 regarding petition EN5461 to introduce a minimum legal age for purchasing caffeinated energy drinks.

Caffeine is a mild stimulant, and is found in many natural sources, such as tea leaves, coffee beans and cocoa, but can also be added to processed foods, such as cola drinks, sports supplements and energy drinks.
The Australian Government is aware of the risks of consuming too much caffeine, particularly for children.

The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (Code) restricts how much caffeine can be added to energy drinks and cola-type soft drinks. Currently, the Code (Standard 2.6.4) specifies that a formulated caffeinated beverage (an energy drink) must contain no more than 320mg/L of total caffeine from any source. For reference, this concentration is comparable to the amount of caffeine in a cup of espresso style coffee. Standard 2.6.4 also outlines the labelling requirements for energy drinks. Products must carry a statement to the effect that the food is not recommended for children, pregnant or lactating women and individuals sensitive to caffeine.

The Code includes labelling requirements for other foods containing added caffeine. Foods containing added caffeine must have a statement on the label that the product contains caffeine. Foods containing guarana (a South American plant with high levels of natural caffeine) must also be labelled as containing caffeine. This is to help people avoid caffeine either for themselves or their children. Additionally, pure and highly concentrated caffeine products are banned from retail sale in Australia.

There is no recognised health-based guidance, such as an Acceptable Daily Intake level for caffeine. A Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) working group found evidence for increased anxiety levels in children at intakes of about 3 mg of caffeine per kilogram of bodyweight per day. This amount for children aged 9-13 corresponds to a caffeine intake of 120 mg per day (approximately two cans of cola).

While research undertaken by FSANZ has confirmed that caffeine intakes in the general population remain at appropriate levels, there are some limitations with this research. The food consumption data used for this dietary intake assessment came from the 2011-12 Australian National Nutrition and Physical Activity Survey and may not reflect current consumption patterns. The next national nutrition survey is currently under way and will inform a new assessment of caffeine intakes in the population.

FSANZ is also currently reviewing (through Proposal P1056) the permissions for caffeine in sports foods and general foods. This review is considering the risk caffeine poses to sensitive sub-populations such as children. This work includes several public consultation periods, the first of these closed on 13 February 2023.

FSANZ is currently considering these submissions which will help inform the final regulatory recommendations for caffeine. Any regulatory recommendations, including proposed drafting for the Code, will be provided in the second round of consultation to be released later this year. There is more information about this work on the FSANZ website www.foodstandards.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Environment: Japan
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 regarding the two petitions, EN5462 and EN5463, concerning Japan's release of Advanced Liquid Processing System- treated water from the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station.

The Australian Government is committed to the ongoing protection of the Pacific Ocean. We have confidence in the process that has led to the decision by Japan to release the treated water. The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency issued advice on 11 July 2023 supporting the International Atomic Energy Agency's (IAEA) assessment that the proposed discharge would not adversely impact people or the environment.

We also have confidence in the IAEA's independent, impartial, and science-based technical advice. The IAEA has committed to providing ongoing monitoring and periodic review until all treated water has been discharged, and the IAEA and Japan have signed an agreement for IAEA monitoring to continue for the duration of the release. The IAEA is maintaining an on-site monitoring presence at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station for the duration of the release and has launched a website to provide regularly updated data.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Mental Health
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 regarding petition number EN5465, presented to the House of Representatives on 27 November 2023, regarding increasing the number of Medicare-subsidised mental health sessions.
The Australian Government is committed to creating a mental health system in which all Australians can access quality and affordable healthcare when and where they need it.

The Government received an evaluation of the 'Better Access to Psychiatrists, Psychologists and General Practitioners through the Medicare Benefits Schedule' (Better Access) initiative. The Better Access evaluation found many Australians—particularly people with lower incomes and those living in regional, rural and remote areas -were missing out on much-needed care.

Additionally, the temporary addition of 10 Medicare-subsidised sessions introduced during the COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated access and equity challenges and meant many Australians missed out on support altogether. An additional 45,000 people have received Better Access sessions in 2023—since the 10 sessions ceased on 31 December 2022.

While this is a positive step, more work is needed so all Australians, no matter where they live or what their circumstances, can get the mental healthcare they need. To support this work and to provide advice to Government, I established the Mental Health Reform Advisory Committee (Advisory Committee) to help shape the Government's response to the Better Access evaluation and longer-term mental health reforms. To date, the Advisory Committee has considered solutions to a range of issues: from how to make services more accessible and affordable, to the best ways to deliver comprehensive, person-centred care for people with severe and complex needs.

Advice has already informed the investment of $475.1 million over six years outlined in the 2023-24 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook. Most notably, the Government has made investments in digital mental health services, including funding to core national services, to ensure funding stability and so consumers continue to have high-quality and safe services while broader digital mental health reforms are underway. I look forward to continuing this work to further reform the mental health system over the coming months. Further information on the Advisory Committee can be found at:
www.health.gov.au/committees-and-groups/mental-health-reform-advisory-committee.

The National Suicide Prevention Leadership and Support Program also provides a range of programs to facilitate leadership, strategic partnerships and collaboration in the suicide prevention sector by building a suicide prevention evidence base, reducing stigma and raising awareness of suicide prevention as well as building community capacity to contribute to suicide prevention. They also provide support and care to people at heightened risk of suicide.

Other initiatives include the National Mental Health and Suicide Prevention Agreement, where the Government is working with states and territories and in partnership with the sector and people with lived experience, to provide a universal suicide aftercare service for all Australians discharged from hospital following a suicide attempt. These national suicide postvention services support those bereaved or impacted by suicide, and help people experiencing psychological distress, including co-funding distress brief support trials in New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria.

The Government is addressing some of the key drivers of distress through providing energy bill relief, increased eligible working age and student payments, and supports for eligible disability workers. Other supports include increased bulk billing incentives and cheaper medicines to enable easier access to healthcare, and increased funding to tackle housing insecurity and homelessness; address domestic, family and sexual violence; reduce harms caused by gambling; continue support for alcohol and other drugs programs; providing natural disaster-related relief; and funding to ease family and other relationship distress.

The Government is also working hard to meet the current and future workforce demands of the mental health system through a collaborative Government initiative, the 10-year National Mental Health Workforce Strategy (Strategy), which has been developed in recognition of the need to build a mental health workforce. The Strategy considers the quality, supply, distribution and structure of the mental health workforce that can meet the needs of all Australians, including young people, Australian farmers, and those at risk of suicide.

In line with this Strategy, the 2023-24 Budget invested $109.1 million to grow the availability and capability of our mental health workforce to support equitable access to critical services. This includes addressing bottlenecks in the psychology training pipeline through additional postgraduate psychology places, internships and supervisor training places and upskilling the broader health workforce in mental health to alleviate system pressure and deliver high-quality mental health treatment and support.

For people at risk of suicide and those impacted by suicide, the Government is investing over $720 million which includes funding for targeted regional initiatives for suicide prevention in all 31 Primary Health Networks (PHNs). People who have used all their Better Access services or experiencing financial hardship, arid have, or are at risk of mental illness, can access PHNs. In addition, they can access a national network of Head to Health Adult Mental Health Centres, and headspace which provides support to young people aged 12-25 years. Further, there are a range of free or low-cost Government-funded digital mental health services which include crisis support, helplines, peer warmlines and webchat, clinician-supported online therapy, self-directed education programs and tools, and moderated peer support forums.

I note your concerns on the cost of mental health sessions. While the Government is responsible for setting the level of Medicare rebates for services, professionals are free to set their own fees and, some of these may exceed the level of Medicare rebates.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Geoengineering
Dear Chair
Thank you for your referral of 1 December 2023 of a petition for an inquiry into geoengineering (EN5472). I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government accepts the scientific facts of climate change. The government receives its primary advice on climate science from the Bureau of Meteorology and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). The scientific advice from these agencies aligns with information provided by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and other trusted national and international organisations, such as the Australian Academy of Science, the World Meteorological Organization, the National Academy of Sciences, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

These world-leading scientific organisations have found that the Earth's climate is changing and that humans are primarily responsible, due to emissions of greenhouse gases from the combustion of fossil fuels and land use change. These findings are informed by long-term, real- world scientific observations of air temperatures, atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, the heat content of the ocean, changes to vegetation, glaciers, ice sheets and sea ice and many other climate variables.

The IPCC is a trusted source of scientific advice, and its work continues to inform the government. The recent IPCC Sixth Assessment Report provides an update on the latest climate science, and options for mitigating and adapting to climate change. In this report, the IPCC concluded that all proposed forms of climate geoengineering are 'speculative technologies' (section 1.4.3 of www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg3/chapter/chapter-

/https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/we3/chapter/chapter-1/), and that there are no available technologies that could be used to affect the global climate (section 4.6.3 of www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/chapter/chapter-4/).

The government is aware of the possible climatic, environmental, social, cultural and economic risks of proposed climate geoengineering technologies. In October 2023, the government successfully secured a decision under the United Nations Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer for researchers to consider risks and uncertainties for the ozone layer in any scientific studies or assessments related to high-altitude climate geoengineering (stratospheric aerosol injection), where small particles are released high in the atmosphere to reduce solar radiation and warming (Decision XXXV/4, 2023). Under this decision, member countries will also be provided updates on developments in stratospheric aerosol injection to assist with understanding of the potential impacts of this technology on the ozone layer.

Additionally, Australia is a party to the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity, which includes an agreement to restrict climate geoengineering unless it is for small-scale scientific research, or unless the risks and scientific basis are appropriately considered (Decision X/33, 2010).

Australia does not have a specific domestic regulatory framework for geoengineering activities. There is, however, legislation at the national and state level that provides protection for the environment against unacceptable environmental impacts of all types of activities. This includes the Commonwealth Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 and the Great Barrier Ree/Marine Park Act 1975.

As part of the government's commitment to protecting the World Heritage-listed Great Barrier Reef, the government is funding a research project into solar radiation engineering. Climate change is the biggest threat to the Reef, and many World Heritage sites globally. The Reef Restoration and Adaptation Program (RRAP)is investigating the use of marine cloud brightening, where salt from sea water is sprayed into the air to help form clouds, to prevent or reduce localised bleaching stress on coral reefs by reducing the amount of sunlight reaching the Reef. More information on this program is available on the RRAP website at gbrrestoration.org/program/cooling-and-shading/.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Pensions And Benefits
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 11 December 2023 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning a petition (EN5477) that refers to relationship status considerations in social security payments. The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.

Eligibility for social security payments is assessed under the Social Security Act 1991 (the Act). The Act provides for different rates of payment, depending on whether a person is single, or a member of a couple. This is based on the principle that couples are able to pool their resources and share living costs for their mutual benefit. Couples generally share their expenses, such as various utilities including electricity, gas, telephone and water.

A person is a member of a couple under the Act if they have a relationship with another person as their partner, whether they are legally married, in a registered relationship, or in a de facto relationship.

When assessing a relationship between 2 people, all relevant information about the relationship is considered in an objective manner. The aspects considered in determining whether a relationship means a person is a member of a couple are:
the financial aspects of the relationship;
the nature of the household;
the social aspects of the relationship;
the presence of a sexual relationship; and
the nature of the commitment.
No single factor determines whether a relationship exists. It is the complete picture which is considered.

Section 24 of the Act enables Services Australia to decide there is a 'special reason' not to treat a partnered person as a member of a couple. The discretion to treat a partnered person as not being a member of a couple may be exercised where a full consideration of all the circumstances relevant to the individual's case would make it unjust or unreasonable not to do so.
I trust the information provided will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Services and Assistant Minister for the Prevention of Family Violence, Ms Elliot
Aviation Industry
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 22 December 2023 regarding Petition EN5483—subsidised air travel, service enhancement and expanded accessibility.

The Australian Government has committed to an Aviation White Paper to set the scene for future growth and development of the aviation sector. The Aviation White Paper will include consideration of the competition and consumer protection within the sector, as well as disability access to aviation services.

On 7 February 2023, the Government released the Aviation White Paper Terms of Reference which outlines the scope, themes and key deliverables. Since then, the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts has heard from over 160 organisations and received over 2000 written submissions, many of which covered issues related to flight services and accessibility, particularly on regional routes. Consultation on the Green Paper will be considered during the development of the White Paper, which is expected to be released in mid-2024.
Further information on the Aviation White Paper can be found at:
www.infrastructure.gov.au/infrastructure-transport-vehicles/aviation/aviation-white-paper/.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from theMinister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government Member for Ballarat, Ms King
Domestic And Family Violence
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 4 December 2023, concerning petition EN5490 and the Australian Government's commitment to tackle family, domestic and sexual violence (FDSV) in the Northern Territory (NT).

The safety of women and children experiencing FDSV is a national priority for the Government. We are committed to investment in women's safety going towards areas of greatest need, and data tells us that the NT has higher rates of FDSV.

On 17 October 2022, the Australian, state and territory governments released the National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children 2022-2032 (National Plan), which sets the national policy agenda for addressing violence against women and children in Australia for the next 10 years. The National Plan sets out the vision to end gender-based violence in Australia in one generation.

The National Plan is supported by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Action Plan 2023-2025 (the Action Plan), the First Action Plan 2023-2027 and the Outcomes Framework, all of which were launched on 16 August 2023 and set the roadmap for how we will work to achieve the vision of the National Plan.

It is critical that our national policy response to addressing violence in First Nations families and communities is led by First Nations peoples. The Action Plan is the first dedicated First Nations plan recognising that First Nations experiences of FDSV is different because of entrenched disadvantage, poor education, poorer health and access to support services in Indigenous communities. More than 1,800 people from across Australia were engaged in consultation to inform this Action Plan, with hundreds of responses also received on its framework. As a result, this Action Plan was directly informed by First Nations people and communities and contain specific, concrete actions for governments.

The Albanese Government invested a record $2.3 billion across the 2022-23 and 2023-24 Budgets towards achieving the outcomes of the National Plan, including $262.6 million in the 2023-24 Budget to support the dedicated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Action Plan 2023-2025 and early investment into a standalone First Nations National Plan.

In the 2023-24 Budget, the Government committed $159 million to extend support to the states and territories under the National Partnership on Family, Domestic and Sexual Violence Responses (FDSV National Partnership), including $28.835 million for the NT Government, which is a significant share of total funding. This funding is provided to state and territory governments to support them to deliver frontline FDSV services. Under the FDSV National Partnership, the NT will receive 4.65 per cent of total funding across Australia, which is significantly higher than the NT would receive under a per capita allocation. This includes an additional $10.73 million for the NT Government in 2022-23 to support frontline services. I understand the NT Government is currently working to deliver this funding.
In total, the NT receives significant current investment of at least $147.8 million from the Commonwealth, in recognition of the unique needs of the NT.

This includes $71.285 million, which the Commonwealth provides directly to local FDSV service providers in the NT including the Tangentyere Council Women's Family Safety Group, NPY Women's Council Aboriginal Corporation, Yugal Mangi Development Aboriginal Corporation, and other specialist family violence prevention and legal services.

The Government's investment also includes the NT's funding of $7.023 million to deliver new frontline workers, as well as $3.4 million to support innovative perpetrator responses—with all jurisdictions receiving the same amount of funding for this measure.

In regards to additional housing for FDSV victim-survivors, the Government has invested $72.6 million over 2020-21 to 2024-25 in the Safe Places Emergency Accommodation Program (Safe Places). Safe Places provides capital grants to fund the building, renovation or purchase of new emergency accommodation for women and children experiencing family and domestic violence. Approximately 8.1 per cent of the total funding under Safe Places ($5.66 million) has been allocated to Safe Places in the NT. This will provide 36 safe places, assisting up to 144 women and children experiencing family and domestic violence each year. Tenanting is expected to commence in March 2024.

As part of the National Plan, the Government has committed $100 million over 5 years to continue funding under the Safe Places program through the Safe Places Inclusion Round (Inclusion Round). The objective of the Inclusion Round is to increase the number of new and appropriate emergency accommodation places for women and children experiencing family and domestic violence. The Inclusion Round focuses on improving access for First Nations women and children, women and children from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds, and women and children with disability, including those who experience the intersection of racism, ableism and sexism.

In addition, the Albanese Government has committed to an ambitious housing reform agenda, which will boost the supply of all housing—more public and social housing, more affordable housing, more homes to rent and more homes to buy. This includes the $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund (HAFF) that will support 30,000 new social and affordable rental homes over its first five years, with 4,000 of these new social and affordable rental homes helping support women and children impacted by domestic violence or older women at risk of homelessness. In addition, the HAFF will provide a further $100 million in funding to support crisis and transitional housing options for women and children impacted by domestic violence, and older women at risk of homelessness, over its first five years.

The Albanese Government has also committed that the HAFF will support a range of acute housing needs over its first five years, including $200 million for the repair, maintenance and improvements of housing in remote Indigenous communities.

The Government has recently commenced consultation on draft amendments to the Housing Australia Investment Mandate Direction (the Investment Mandate). The Investment Mandate will empower Housing Australia to deliver the Government's commitment to help fund the construction of 30,000 new social and affordable dwellings under the HAFF and a further 10,000 affordable dwellings through the National Housing Accord over five years from 2024-25. The draft Investment Mandate will require Housing Australia to make financing from the HAFF and the Accord available across the states and territories and across regional, rural and remote areas. This requirement is intended to ensure that dwellings are equitably delivered across Australia.

In addition, the Investment Mandate will require Housing Australia to deliver a minimum of 1,200 new social and affordable dwellings in each state and territory over five years. The Investment Mandate does not specify purposes for the 1,200 dwellings, but Housing Australia will be required to consider whether projects are servicing areas of acute housing need, including victim-survivors of FDSV.

Needs-based funding is an important conversation that the Government is continuing to have with states and territories. Any needs-based funding methodology would require careful development. Determining need would require support from all state and territory governments, including significant data development consideration for jurisdictions.
Both the matters of funding and a peak body fall within the portfolio responsibilities of the NT Minister for the Prevention of Domestic, Family and Sexual Violence, the Hon Kate Worden MLA.
I trust the information provided is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Services and Assistant Minister for the Prevention of Family Violence, Ms Elliot
International Relations: Australia And India
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for sharing Petition EN5499 on allegations of foreign interference and threats to the Sikh community in Australia.

India and Australia are comprehensive strategic partners. We are building a relationship that enables us to speak directly and respectfully about issues that matter, whilst we advance our shared economic and security interests.

Australia has consistently expressed concern publicly and to India regarding these allegations. It would not be appropriate to comment further given ongoing law enforcement investigations into these matters. Australia holds a principled position that all countries should respect sovereignty and the rule of law. We remain closely engaged with partners on these developments.

We understand these reports will be particularly concerning to some Australian communities. The Indian diaspora are valued contributors to Australia's vibrant and resilient multicultural society, where all Australians can peacefully and safely express their views.

The Australian Government does not tolerate foreign interference, violence or threats of violence. Australian law enforcement agencies will respond to any breaches of Australian law. The Australian Government's Guidelines to Counter Foreign Interference act to protect Australia's national interests and build resilience to foreign influence.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
International Health Regulations
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 regarding Petition EN5509 and Petition EN5517.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is, and remains, a Member State-led organisation. Australia participates in WHO decision-making processes as a member of the WHO Executive Board and through the World Health Assembly (WHA). WHO reports to, and is accountable to, its Member States, including Australia, through the WHA. Under international law, Member States such as Australia retain sovereignty regarding their public health policies. The WHO has no legal authority to force countries to accept any of its recommendations and can only provide aid and assistance at Member States' request. Australian law can only be changed by an act of the Parliament.

The Australian Government is dedicated to strengthening national and global pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response and is committed to working with the Australian public and the international community to be better prepared for the next pandemic. As referred to in the two Ministerial Petitions referenced above, one of the reforms through the WHO currently under consideration is targeted amendments to strengthen the implementation of the International Health Regulations (2005) (IHR). This process will work to close gaps identified through independent reviews of the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The IHR is an international instrument that defines countries' rights and obligations in handling infectious disease outbreaks, public events and emergencies that have the potential to cross borders. In May 2022, Member States, including Australia, agreed at the WHA to establish a working group to consider targeted amendments to the IHR (Working Group on Amendments to the IHR, or WGIHR). These amendments are intended to enable the IHR to remain responsive to evolving public health threats and strengthen the ability of countries to co-operate internationally to prepare for and respond to infectious disease outbreaks. At this stage, none of the proposed amendments are agreed. For further information about the work of the WGIHR please see:
www.who.int/health-topics/international-health-regulations.

Any agreed amendments to the IHR will be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and consideration by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties (JSCOT). As part of its process in scrutinising proposed treaties, JSCOT undertakes further consultation on major treaty actions by inviting submissions from stakeholders and members of the public. Any changes to Australian law to implement the package of IHR amendments would also have to be considered and passed by Parliament.

As referenced in Petition EN5517, the proposed change to Article 59 will reduce the timeframe for future changes to the IHR to take effect from 24 to 12 months, and to reduce the timeframe for rejection of, or reservation to, future changes to the IHR from 18 months to 10 months. Following agreement by WHO Member States at the WHA in 2022, the change was referred to JSCOT for consideration. JSCOT reported the amendments were expected to have negligible legal, financial, or practical impact on Australia; endorsed the changes to Article 59 of the IHR as a minor treaty action; and agreed that binding treaty action be taken. The deadline for Parties to the IHR to reject or make a reservation to changes to Article 59 was 1 December 2023. As Australia did not reject or lodge a reservation to the changes to Article 59, they will come into force for Australia in May 2024.
For further information about the above global health reform processes please see:
www.health.gov.au/our-work/strengthening-global-health-and-international-pandemic- response.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Glioblastoma
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN5518 requesting that the House approves the use of Tumour Treating Fields such as the Optune device for use in Australia.

I am happy to advise you that the Optune device is approved for supply in Australia. The Optune device was included on the Australian Register for Therapeutic Goods (ARTG) in February 2022. The ARTG entry '384111' provides detailed information on the approval.
The Optune device approved is intended for the treatment of:

Adult patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) after surgery and Radiotherapy (RT) with adjuvant Temozolomide (TMZ), concomitant to maintenance TMZ. Treatment should be started more than four weeks after surgery and radiation therapy with adjuvant TMZ. Treatment may be given together with maintenance TMZ and after maintenance TMZ is stopped.

Adult patients with recurrent GBM who have progressed after surgery, RT, and TMZ treatment for their primary disease. The treatment should be started more than four weeks after the latest surgery, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy.

To access treatment with the Optune device, patients should discuss with their healthcare provider or specialist who can guide them through the appropriate channels. The Australian Government is committed to ensure timely access to treatment options for rare cancers, including GBM.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
COVID-19: Mortality
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 1 December 2023 regarding Petition EN5529 asking the House of Representatives to instruct the Department of Health and Aged Care to release weekly COVID-19 death numbers.

I appreciate that the petitioners are very concerned about deaths from and with COVID-19. As they are aware, the department moved to reporting COVID-19 information monthly, from weekly, in November 2023. This decision was made to reflect the move away from emergency settings and the decreased public interest in the reports. Emergency arrangements were put in place at the start of the pandemic and these are no longer sustainable or required. The change was also necessary due to changes in the ways that jurisdictions were receiving and reporting COVID-19 data.

The daily and weekly reporting of COVID-19 cases were appropriate during the earlier stages of the pandemic. However, in the current environment, reporting deaths on a weekly basis is disproportionate to the risk and severity to public health. Whilst I acknowledge that COVID-19 is still prevalent in the community, we have not seen significant increases in the number of deaths recorded. Continuing to place a strong focus on COVID-19 reporting may inadvertently diminish other public health messaging. It also drives resources away from other priorities.

In addition to reporting from the department, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) publishes extensive and frequent statistics and analysis of mortality in Australia, including dedicated publications for COVID-19 mortality. ABS data is readily available on their website at www.abs.gov.au/statistics/health/causes-death.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Aviation Industry
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 1 December 2023 regarding petition number EN5537 seeking additional capacity under Australia's bilateral air services arrangements with Qatar.

Air services agreements are treaty level agreements between countries that are determined in the national interest. Every country in considering opening further access to its aviation market makes decisions in this way and Australia is no different.

Australia has air services agreements with more than 100 countries facilitating international travel to and from Australia. These international agreements are enabling Australians wishing to travel internationally, or visitors coming to Australia, to access nearly 2,000 international flights per week.

Many countries, including Qatar, seek changes to these agreements from time to time. The Australian Government has decided not to approve the Qatar Civil Aviation Authority's requests for additional services at this time.
This is not the first time Australia has refused capacity increases in such negotiations and of course Australia has also been denied capacity for its airlines to access key markets abroad.

As the airline industry continues to recover from the pandemic, we are seeing a large amount of additional capacity come into the international market. Emirates, Qantas, Cathay Pacific Singapore Airlines and China Southern are all introducing additional flights to Australia. Airlines of Vietnam and Turkiye have also indicated that they wish to operate new flights to Australia which will be facilitated by recently updated air services arrangements agreed with civil aviation officials of these respective countries.

It is expected that global international passenger traffic will return to pre-COVID-19 levels over the next twelve months and this additional demand will stimulate competition and encourage more competitive air fares on international routes.

The forthcoming Aviation White Paper -due to be released in the first half of2024—will set the scene for the next generation of growth and development across the aviation sector out to 2050. This includes considering as a priority the economic reforms needed to improve productivity across the sector, to facilitate the delivery of aviation services for the Australian public and international visitors out to 2050, as well as protecting secure Australian jobs and better rights and protection for consumers.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from theMinister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government Member for Ballarat, Ms King
First Nations Australians
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 6 December 2023 regarding Petition Number EN5555 and providing an opportunity to respond.

The Australian Government delivered on its commitment to hold a referendum on the principle of recognising Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in the Constitution through a Voice on Saturday 14 October 2023. The referendum did not pass. The Australian Government accepts the decision of the Australian people and the democratic process that delivered it. It also acknowledges the reasons a majority of Australians voted no are complex and varied.

The referendum result does not change the Australian Government's commitment to seek better outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We are already working to ensure the provision of facilities and improve outcomes for First Nations people on remote communities. The 2023-24 Budget invests $1.9 billion in initiatives for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and communities. This includes $111.7 million under a new one-year partnership with the Northern Territory Government to accelerate the building of new remote housing, targeted at addressing the worst over-crowding, and $38.4 million to support high quality and culturally appropriate education for First Nations boys and girls in remote areas.

The Australian Government is also working with state and territory governments, the Australian Local Government Association and the Coalition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peak Organisations on the National Agreement on Closing the Gap (National Agreement). The National Agreement establishes 17 national socio-economic outcomes and 19 socio-economic targets that address key transition points in an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander person's life course (from school to employment), as well as supports needed at all stages of life (flourishing cultures and languages; safe homes and communities, and adequate housing). Access to essential services (including electricity and water) is also an outcome under the National Agreement, through the Community Infrastructure Target (Target 9b).

Released on 13 February 2023, the 2023 Commonwealth Closing the Gap Implementation Plan (Implementation Plan) outlines specific, tangible actions the Commonwealth will take to meet its commitments to closing the gap over the next 12 to 18 months. The Implementation Plan can be accessed at niaa.gov.au.
Thank you for referring this matter to me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Ms Burney
Parliament
Dear Ms Templeman

span.span: Response to Petition EN5562 concerning prayers in the House of Representatives

p.span: Thank you for your letter of 27 November 2023, requesting a response to Petition EN5562 relating to the prayers read at the commencement of sittings of the House of Representatives.

As you know, the requirement for the Speaker to read prayers, and the form of those prayers, is set out in the standing orders. The standing orders may be amended by the House, if a majority of Members support the change.

The prayers have remained largely unchanged since Federation, although some additional words were introduced in 1918 for the duration of the war. The practice of starting most sittings with prayers has been examined on a number of occasions but change has not been supported. The House added an acknowledgement of country at the start of sitting days in 2010.
As amendments to the standing orders are a matter for the House as a whole, it is only if a majority of Members wish it that change will occur.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Dick
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I want to note that two of the petitions—one paper based, with 12,872 signatures, and one electronic, with 185,795 signatures—concern the conflict in Gaza. From the size of both those petitions, I can only imagine the effort that people have put into the collection of these signatures, and that reflects very strong feelings about this issue.
DELEGATION REPORTS

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the 44th ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly

p.span: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the 44th ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly

Ms MASCARENHAS (Swan) (10:02): I present the report of the Parliamentary Delegation to the 44th ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly held from 5 to 11 August 2023. I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.
Leave granted.

Ms MASCARENHAS: I am pleased to present the report of the Parliamentary Delegation to the 44th ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly, or AIPA. The 44th assembly was hosted by the Republic of Indonesia and was held between 5 and 11 August last year in Jakarta. It was a pleasure to be joined by the member for Lyne to form a two-member delegation. This year marks the 50th anniversary of Australia's relationship with ASEAN. It was back in 1974 that Australia became one of ASEAN's first dialogue partners. We were one of 10. The cooperation continues to this day. Australia recognises that continued dialogue and cooperation are important in order to foster stability and economic security in the region. It also recognises that ASEAN is at the centre of that dialogue. Its role is critical to providing a stable, peaceful and prosperous region, which is why it was a pleasure and honour to lead the delegation.

The theme of the 44th assembly was 'Responsible parliaments for a stable and prosperous ASEAN'. It was opened by Her Excellency Dr Puan Maharani, Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Republic of Indonesia and the President of the 44th AIPA. Her Excellency highlighted the ongoing need for commitments to create peace and prosperity in South-East Asia. Her Excellency also highlighted the role of AIPA as a vehicle for its member states to find a middle ground in achieving these commitments.

I was pleased to make a statement on behalf of the delegation. It was a statement that reinforced the important relationships that Australia has in the region and the importance of South-East Asia as an economic, trade, defence and cultural partner to Australia. The statement acknowledged the important role of Indonesia in its ASEAN chair year. It also reinforced Australia's report for the road map of Timor-Leste's full membership in ASEAN. I recognised the significance to Australia of the ASEAN-Australia Comprehensive Strategic Partnership in combating climate change, building health security and advancing the ASEAN outlook on the Indo-Pacific.

The themes of addressing climate change and the transition to clean energy were consistently raised through AIPA and I appreciate the opportunity to observe this discussion. The need for addressing supply chain insecurity due to the war in Ukraine and continuing post-pandemic recovery efforts were also a focus. Australia is an observer country to AIPA and, as such, was invited to participate in a dialogue with other member countries chaired by Mr Ravindra Airlangga MP, from the House of Representatives for the Republic of Indonesia. During the week, four bilateral meetings were held with delegations from Ukraine, Lao PDR, Indonesia and the United States of America. In making recommendations for the next assembly, Australia recommended that future delegations seek further engagement in other aspects of the program as observers or contributors, if agreed.

The delegation wishes to thank the Indonesian House of Representatives for hosting the event. The delegation would also like to congratulate the Republic of Indonesia on their successful year as ASEAN chair and a successful and productive 44th AIPA. Thank you to the team who made the delegation a success—Jeff Norris, Tom Coghlan, the Australian Mission to ASEAN and the Australian Embassy Indonesia.

Dr GILLESPIE (Lyne) (10:06): It was a great pleasure for me to represent Australia at the 44th ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Assembly held in Jakarta and to be accompanied and led by the member for Swan. This is a really important strategic meeting of parliamentarians, and it is coming up for its 50th anniversary. All the ASEAN members were there, but I note that Myanmar did not attend. We were welcomed by the Secretary-General of AIPA, and the President of Indonesia, Joko Widodo, gave a keynote address focusing on a prosperous and stable ASEAN as a driver of global economic growth. He really focused on the power of ASEAN, as a calm middle power across the world, as a force for good. Peace, prosperity and stability are the aims of everyone in ASEAN.

I found it very interesting to have the formal dialogues as well as the informal dialogues. In Indonesia we met many very senior politicians who will be very prominent in the current election cycle. Accents were put on our comprehensive strategic partnership with ASEAN, and we also noted we give not just ASEAN nations but South-East Asian and East Asian nations aid to the tune of $1.24 billion annually. We do make, with our ASEAN-Australia Comprehensive Strategic Partnership, a contribution of $204 million and we've also been heavily involved in the Indo-Pacific endeavour since 2017.

Many people in this building don't focus as much on these really important ASEAN and Asian focused diplomatic events, but it is critical to our wellbeing that we foster deeper ties with all the ASEAN members. In meetings and in private conversations, Brunei Darussalam, Lao PDR, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Vietnam thanked us for our help for them during the COVID pandemic—with both PPE and vaccines. I would like to thank Jeff Norris and the other members of the secretariat who accompanied us and made it such a smoothly run show from our side, and I thank the Australian embassy. Congratulations to Indonesia for putting on a really good meeting.
COMMITTEES
Intelligence and Security Joint Committee
Report

Mr KHALIL (Wills) (10:10): On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security, I present the committee's report entitled Annual report of committee activities 2022-2023. I'm pleased to present the committee's annual report on the activities of 2022-23. In line with the requirement under section 31 of the Intelligence Services Act 2001 that the committee report annually on its activities, this report provides details of the committee's work in the financial year ending on 30 June 2023.

Following the May 2022 election, the committee was established on 7 September 2022 and immediately recommenced work on four statutory and oversight reviews that carried over from the previous parliament. The committee's workload then grew steadily in the ensuing months. In its 10 months of operation during the reporting period, the committee worked on 14 inquiries and reviews—that's a lot. We held 50 meetings and briefings and seven public hearings and also undertook three site visits within Australia. The committee completed eight reviews and reported to parliament on them.

Key matters before the committee during the review period included the review of 13 terrorist listings under the Criminal Code and overlapping work on two annual reviews of intelligence agencies' administration and expenditure. The committee also completed four bill inquiries referred by ministers, which have since been passed by parliament and become acts. These were the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and Other Legislation Amendment (Modernisation) Bill 2022; item 250 of the National Anti-Corruption Commission (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2022; the National Security Legislation Amendment (Comprehensive Review and Other Measures No. 2) Bill 2023; and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Amendment Bill 2023.

Between September 2022 and June 2023, the workload of the committee grew steadily to what I would probably say as an understatement was a high pace of activity which continued throughout the remainder of 2023. Management of a consistently heavy workload remains a challenge for our committee. Legislation presently before parliament that would further expand the oversight responsibilities of the committee promises a further significant increase in the demands on all members going forward. In this light, the committee has encouraged the government to be realistic in its expectations, particularly in relation to requested time frames for bill reviews. In a kind and polite way, just give us a bit of breathing space because there are a lot of reviews underway at the one time. A healthy democratic process and quality national security oversight requires that wherever possible the committee be provided the appropriate time and space necessary to do its work well.

The committee looks forward to continuing to exercise its functions in the remainder of the 47th Parliament. On behalf of the committee I wish to thank all those who made contributions to the various inquiries and reviews undertaken over the 2022-23 financial year, with a special mention to the very hardworking staff of the secretariat. Obviously, we couldn't do our job without them. They were exemplary. I also thank all of the member of the committee who worked so hard, in a largely bipartisan way, as we worked towards the best possible recommendations for the government for the best possible results for the national interest. I commend the report to the House.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Criminal Code Amendment (Telecommunications Offences for Suicide Related Material—Exception for Lawful Voluntary Assisted Dying) Bill 2024

p.span: Criminal Code Amendment (Telecommunications Offences for Suicide Related Material—Exception for Lawful Voluntary Assisted Dying) Bill 2024
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Ms Chaney.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Ms CHANEY (Curtin) (10:14): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
I am pleased to introduce this bill today because unlike many issues we face in this House, this is a policy problem with a simple solution.
Currently, doctors and pharmacists are at risk of criminal prosecution if they use telehealth, email, text or phone calls in relation to any lawful voluntary assisted dying services.
This means people who are:
terminally ill and suffering;
and have the right to VAD services
have to travel for face-to-face appointments.
Even worse, patients that rely on telehealth services due to distance or discomfort don't have equal access to end-of-life services that are supposed to be available to anyone who qualifies.
This problem can be fixed by passing this bill, which makes a minor amendment to the federal Criminal Code to make it clear that voluntary assisted dying is not suicide.
This change has the broad backing of the states, medical professionals, academics and patient advocate groups.
It is simple and could be done today.
So what's the problem the bill aims to fix?
Let's look at four facts.

span.span: First: VAD is an accepted part of our health system

p.span: Since 2019, every state has passed legislation allowing VAD under strict conditions, with territories expected to legislate soon.

Within this legislation, every state already has strong safeguards—at least three requests that are voluntary and enduring, at least two assessments by medical practitioners, the consideration of all treatment options and detailed processes set out to ensure this very serious decision is given appropriate weight.

span.span: is an integral part of our health system

p.span: Telehealth has been hugely important in improving the access of people in rural and remote Australia to a variety of health services, especially where specialists are needed.

span.span: Criminal Code that prevents telehealth from being used for anything

p.span: An amendment to the Commonwealth Criminal Code Act was passed in 2005, making it an offence to counsel, promote or provide instruction on suicide through the use of a carriage service. That was 12 years before any jurisdiction in Australia had a VAD law. The stated intent of the amendment was to target pro-suicide websites, internet chat rooms and online cyberbullying.
'Suicide' is not defined in the code, but has been construed in its literal sense as 'intentional self-killing'.
The federal Criminal Code over-rides state legislation so the laws made by the states allowing telehealth VAD services do not protect doctors and other medical practitioners.
But VAD is not suicide.

There is a huge difference between the act of a desperate person who takes their own life because they see no other way out and a rational decision made by a terminally ill person enduring intolerable suffering, after discussion of their options with their medical professionals.
Voluntary assisted dying is not about a choice between life and death.
It's a choice between a painful, drawn-out and possibly traumatic death, or a peaceful death with dignity.
Those who access VAD services are making a choice between a hard death or a calm death.
